He had died by 5 October 1626, when his widow Anneken Lemmens (the sister of the painter Jacques Lemmens, who had been his apprentice) empowered the procureur of the Court of Holland to defend her on appeal  in a suit brought by Gillis Smissaert (of R 30704) concerning a painting representing a Cunstcamer, to which good artists (frayen kunstenaers) had contributed. According to a verdict of the Court of 12 October 1624, this painting was to be sold bij executie by Hendrick van Sijl in the name of Smissaert (Briels, ibid.) Johanna Artsen has not been identified.
Intro Text: Op ten 30 septembris 1608 is ten versoecke van Johanna Artsen van Antwerpen vercoft de goederen  geteijckent + , ende die resterende ten versoecke van Jaques van der Lamen. Postscript: Den 5den ocktober 1608 is betalt aen Johanna Artsen dese boven geschreven partien geteijckent met de +, bedragen(de) 490 gl. ende daer blijft noch haerentwegen die bovenste partyen die sij seijde haer toecomende, bedraeght 24 gl. Signed Johanna Artsen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Felix van Lun
Residence: In de Vogel steech in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Opten 2e Octobris 1609, zyn ten versoecke van Felix van Lun vercoft de naevolgende goederen.

Purpose: Mainly a book sale sold at auction
Biographical Notes: The proceeds were paid to the wife of the anonymous owner.
Intro Text: Opten 11 Octobris 1608 syn ten versoeck van [left blank] vercoft dese naevolgende goederen. Postscript: Dese penninge sijn aen de vrou betaelt.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Valerius van der Hoeve
Residence: Op d'achterburchwal by de [...]steechbruch in Amsterdam.
Biographical Notes: On Valerius van der Hoeve, painter, see the notes to R 20019 in Montias2 and the text to R 607 in Montias1.
Intro Text: Op ten 29 octobris 1608 syn ten versoecke van Valerius van der Hoeve vercoft de navolgende schilderye.. Postscript: Dese suijffere overschietende penningen syn aen Valerius betaelt als by quitantie blycken sal aende sedel daer van sijnde. Hoeve betaelt, den 18 Decembris 1608 met mr. Gerrit Jacobsz. gerekent ende 't salaris ontfangen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Heijnrickgen Gerrits alias Graeffin
Biographical Notes: The introduction to this inventory is the key to the identification of the well known uitdraagster who went by the name of Graeffin. As Isabella van Eeghen was the first to point out, she was first married to Cornelis Pietersz., carpenter, later to Reyer Reyersz., varentman, and finally to Andries Pietersz., likewise carpenter, who survived her. She died in 1629, he in 1633. Her religion was R.C. (for further details, see R 20362 of Montias2).
Intro Text: Ten selven dach [2e marty 1602] syn opt versoeck van Heijnrickgen alias Graeffin vercoft 't aenvolgende goed op 6 wecken.

Additional Names: goods sold at the request of his widow
Occupation: Artist |a Painter; Retail merchant |a Art dealer
Biographical Notes: The painter and art dealer Hans van de Velde was born in Antwerp around 1552, became a citizen of Amsterdam in 1586, was married to Cathalyn van Schoor, and was buried on 5 January 1609. He was the father of Esaias van de Velde and the brother of Anthony van de Velde (of R 29027). See also the notes to R 30502 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Op ten 23 february 1609 zyn ten versoecke van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de naervolgende schilderyen [crossed out: de naervolgende goederen]. Postscript: Den 10en april syn de boven geschreven penneijnghen betaelt aende weduwe van [left blank]. The address on the Sleutelsbrugge confirms that the goods sold were the paintings and other atelier stock belonging to the painter and art dealer Hans van de Velde (Briels, Vlaamse schilders, 1997, p. 397).

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Pieter Loduwycxs
Biographical Notes: On 22 November 1593, Pieter Lodewycksz. and his wife Mari Jans had their twins Lodewijck and Jan baptized in the N.K. (DTB 38/319). Jan Pietersz., cited in the inventory, one of the buyers in this sale (R 29265 of Montias2), seems to have been one of the twin sons of Pieter Lodewycksz. He would have been 16 years old at the time of the sale. In her testament passed on 24 May 1605, Gierte Claes, the daughter of Claes Lambertsz. (of R 35924 of Montias2) named Pieter Lodewijksz., the son of her half sister, as her universal heir, in case the children of her brother Zacharias Claesz. (of INVNO 846) were to die first. The attractive possibility that Jan Pietersz. was the goldsmith, son of Pieter Lodewyx van den Eeckhout, who became the father of the Rembrandt pupil Garbrandt van den Eeckhout, must be rejected because the goldsmith was 22 years old in 1606 and thus born several years before the twins (cf. Briels, Vlaamse schilders, p. 324).
Intro Text: Opten 24e february 1609 zyn ten versoecke van Pieter Loduwycxs vercoft de naevolgende goederen. Postscript: Dese penningen sijn betaelt als by quitancy blyckt.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Nicolaes Balestel
Residence: In de Oude Mannen poort in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Nicolaes Balestel de jonge, at whose request the goods were sold, was a merchant (1577-1650). On 31 October 1608, Nicolas Balestel de jonge, from Utrecht, 31, was betrothed to Christina Wolpherts, from Antwerp, 25, assisted by her parents  Gerard Wolphertsz. and Anna Gabri, living on the Rouansche Kaij (DTB 413/311). Her father, Gerard Wolphertsz. van Diemen, was a leather merchant.On 9 December 1614, Jenne, daughter of Nicolas Balestel (de oude), from Atrecht, 29, was betrothed to Jean Gilles. She was assisted by her parents Nicolas Balestel (de oude) and Isabeau Paien (Van Dillen,      Het oudste aandeelhoudersregister, p. 227.) In 1631, Isack Bevelot was taxed 66 f. 13 st. for the heirs of Nicolas Balestel, living on or near the Warmoesstraet (Kohier, fol. 10, p. 4). This may have been Nicolas Balestel de oude (assuming the death year of Nicolas Balestel de jonge, given in Elias, Vroedschap, p. 329, is correct.) A brother of Jean Gilles, named  Samuel, married Elisabeth van Peenen, 26, assisted by her mother Margriete de Latfeur, in 1616. The daughter of another brother of Jean Gilles, named Brisse, married Samuel Chavatte (or Savaet) in 1616. (On Samuel Savaet, see R 26634 of Montias 2). (Van Dillen, op.cit. p. 227). Nicolaes Balestel de jonge was a buyer of art at Orphan Chamber auction (R 36475).
Intro Text: Op ten 11 Aprilis 1609 zyn ten versoeck van Nicolaes Balestel vercoft dese naervolgende goederen. Postscript: Dese penninghen sijn betalt als by quitancje blijckt.

Additional Names: goods sold at the request of Claes Euwouts
Residence: Op de O.Z. Voorburchwal op de hoeck van de Backerstraet in Amsterdam.
Biographical Notes: The painters Claes and Reynier Eewouts (or Euwouts), some times called De Bout, were the sons of Ewout Claesz. den Bout (buried in April 1606), who lived op 't Hooft, and of Catharina Cornelis. Ewout Claesz. was captain in the service of the Admiralty.  They were the brothers of Magdalena Ewouts den Bout, who was betrothed on 2 April 1595 to  Palick van Heerdt (Aelburg 1568-1617), captain in the service of the Admiralty. Claes Ewoutsz. was married to Gijsbertge Huybertsdr. (information kindly suppled by S. Middelhoek). For further bio data on Claes and Reynier Eewouts or Euwouts, see R 29021 of Montias 2.
Intro Text: Op ten 20e may 1609 zyn ten versoeck van Claes Euwouts vercoft de navolgende goederen. Postscript: Dese penningen syn aen Claes Eewouts ende syn broeder Reynier betalt.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Valerius van der Houve (Hoeven)
Residence: Op den Dam naest de Drie Viseltges in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 13 April 1602, Valerius van der Hoeven, painter from Antwerp, about 30 years old, assisted by his brother Felix and his sister Cathelyntje, was betrothed to Sophia Raesvelt from Aachen, 27, living in the Pieter Jacobsdwarsstraet (DTB 665/205). In 1606, 1608, and 1610, children of the couple were baptized in the Lutheran church. On 12 October 1619, he was again betrothed to Baeyken (Barbara) Hendrix (de Grove), 36 years old (DTB 424/19). The couple's testament is dated 25 September 1625. He witnessed a document on 27 April 1627 (Bredius, Künstler-inventare, vol. III, pp. 1038-9). Valerius was the brother of Felix van der Hoeve (of R 31605) and probably of Matheus van der Hoeve (of R 20575). De drie viseltgens was located on the Dam, on the corner of the Vischmarckt.
Intro Text: Op ten 23 meij 1609 syn ten versoeck van Valerius van der Hoeven vercoft de naevolgende goederen. Postscript: Dese suyver overschietende peneijnghen sijn aen  Valerius van der Hoeve betalt als by quijtancij aende seel daer van sijnde.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Lucas Lus (Luce)
Biographical Notes: On Lucas Lus or Luce, at whose request the goods were sold, see the notes to R 20173 in Montias2.
Intro Text: Opten 16e mart 1610 syn ten versoecke van Lucas Lus vercoft de naevolgende goederen en schilderyen.

Additional Names: paintings sold at request of Cornelis van der Voort I
Residence: Op de O.Z. Voorburchwal by de Oude Kerck in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On Cornelis van der Voort, see N. de Roever, Drie Amsterdamsche schilders, Oud Holland, vol. 3 (1885), pp. 187-204, TEXT of R 464 and NOTES to R 20793 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Op ten 15 aprilis 1610 zyn ten versoecke van Cornelis van der Voort vercoft de naevolgende schilderyen.Postscript: De penningen ... betaelt aen Cornelis van der Voort den 10 july 1610.

Residence: Op de Bierkay in de Pau in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: In 1606, Jan Andriesz.  Kaen, bierstecker (beer distributor) in de Pau on the O.Z. Voorburgwal, bought lots in the Haarlem lottery. The collector was Philips Lenertsz., bierstecker, of R 29712 and of INVNO 1228, who was also one of the buyers at the present sale (GAA, 9/41 F 56). On 2 March 1612, Wouter Coensz., balance maker, lodged a complaint (insinuatie) against Jan Andriesz. Caen (NA 422, film 6438).  On 20 January 1621, the children of Jan Jansz. Kan (of R 29717? of Montias2), heirs of Jan Andriesz. Kaen, sold a house situated outside the St. Anthonijspoort (GAA, WK 5073/913). In addition to Jan Jansz. Kan, Jan Andriesz. is known to have had the following children: Andries  Jansz. Kan, of INVNO 668 and of  R 29738 of Montias2; and Aaltje Jans Kaen who married Thomas Pietersz. of R 21127 of Montias2. Willem Jansz. Kan (or Kaen) of R 27915 of Montias2 may also have been his son.
Intro Text: Op ten x marty 1614 zyn ten ordre van den heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Jan Andries Kaen biersteker in de Pauw. Postscript: De weesmeesteren ordeneren Gerrit Jacobsz. Harinck de suyvere penningen van dese vercopinge .. te tellen aen Jan Willemsz. Verschoor de testamenteur van de voors. Jan Andriesz. Caen. Actum 1 july 1614. Is betaelt aen Jan Willemsz. Verschoor als by de cedel [blyckt].

Residence: ten huyse van G. Jacobsz. in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 3 July 1604, Guillame van Lochum, from Antwerp, tailor (kleermacker), 21 years old, was betrothed to Anneken van Hoof (DTB 411/255). Their child Bartholomeus was baptized in the Oude Kerck on 21 October 1607 in the presence of Henrick Verstraten and Fransijntjen van Lochom (Oud Holland 3(1885), p. 160). Hendrick Verstraten (of R 29681 of Montias2) was married to Grietje van Lochum, the sister of Guillame van Lochum, on 22 July 1595 (Oud Holland 3(1885), p.160).   On 7 August 1613, the masters of the Orphan Chamber appointed Hans Jansz., silversmith (of R 21745 and INVNO 714) and Abraham (Jansz.) van Soest (I)  as guardians over over the child of Anna van Hove, whose father was  Guillame van Lichum, tailor. As in the INTRO above,  Hans Jansz. was said to be the uncle of the child. He was probably the brother of Michiel Jansz., who in turn was said to be the uncle of Bartholomeus van Lochum of R 21745 of Montias2. From this it can be inferred that Guillame and Bartholomeus van Lochem were probably  brothers. Van Soest, when he was appointed guardian, was said to be the child's neve. On 23 October 1615, Hans van Soest de jonge (Hans van Soest II)  replaced his brother Abraham (Jansz.) van Soest as guardian (WK 5073/513). Abraham van Soest was a wealthy  merchant on the Turfmarkt, whose widow paid a tax of 180 f. in 1631 (Kohier, fol. 167 vo., p. 29).
Intro Text: Op den 24 february 1614 zyn ten ordre van den heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Guillam van Lichem. Postscript: De weesmeesteren ordonneren Gerrit Jacobsz. Harinck de suyvere penningen van dese vercopinge aen Hans Jansz. den oom ende Abraham van Soest de voochden van't kindt van Guillem van Lochem om daermede de schulden van den boel te betalen ... 7 august 1614.

Residence: ten huyse van G. Jacobsz. in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op ten 8en aprilis 1614 zyn ten ordre van den heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by [left blank]. Postscript: Is betaelt by affirmatie van Gerrit Jacobsz.

Additional Names: goods left by Grietge (Ariens), the widow of Jan van Aken
Residence: In de Pieter Jacobsz. steech in Aken in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 24 September 1587, Jan van Aken, wine dealer, and his wife Griet Ariens had their child Lijsbeth, baptized. The witness was Marten Spijs (Spil ?)  (DTB 1/336). Marten Spil, who was also a wine dealer, was a buyer at R 31708.  Another individual, also named Jan van Aken (perhaps his father) married Claerken van Solt (a close relative of Hans van Solt I of R 29281), widow of Ramaker, in Cologne in 1601 (De Navorscher 84(1935), p. 35).  On 13 June 1635, notary Hoogeboom brought an obligation for 8,400 f. to the Orphan Chamber  for the heirs of Hans van Solt I (of R 29281) in dato 6 April 1635, on behalf of Clara van Solt and Jan Ramaker ... as heirs of Pauwels van Solt, their grandfather (WK 5073/789). Pauwels van Solt was presumably one of the brothers of Hans van Solt I.  Janneken Arents, who was probably the sister of Griet Ariens, bought lots for 18 st. in the Haarlem lottery of 1606, at which time she was living at the house of Jan van Aken daer Aken uijthangt (GAA, 5/19 F 33). An inventory of the goods of Griet Aerents, widow of Jan van Aken de oude, was taken on 24 January 1614, without evaluations (NA 527). Only two painting in this post-mortem inventory could be matched with one of the works of art sold two months later. One was a painting of the city of Cologne (R 38411 of Montias2),  which sold for 3 f. 4 st.; the other was a painting of the 5 sinnen (R 29758), which sold for 2 f. 6 st. The other paintings, prints, and maps were untitled.
Intro Text: Op ten 17e Mary 1614 zyn ten ordre van den heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Grietge de weduwe van Jan van Aken. Postscript: Is betaelt by de cedel aen Arent Willemsz. ende Jannetge Cornelisdr.

Additional Names: and Jannetge Cornelis
Biographical Notes: Pieter Hendrixsz. was perhaps the merchant Pieter Hendrickxssen who freighted one ship between 1590 and 1602 (IJzerman, Economisch Historisch Jaarboek 17 (1931), p. 270.) On 10 October 1598, Pieter Heynricsz., widower of Grietge Korssen, living on the Kalverstraet, was betrothed to Jannetge Cornelis, widow of Jan Tonisz. basket maker (DTB 408/398). On the baker Gerrit Harmensz., who was one of the recipients of the proceeds of the sale,  see R 29770 of Montias 2.
Intro Text: Op ten 10 aprilis 1614 zyn ten ordre van den heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Pieter Hendrixsz. ende Jannetge Cornelis. Postscript: Betaelt als blict by de cedel onder de onderteyckening van Gerrit Harmensz. backer, Jacques van den Eijcken ended Anthonis Joannis chirurgijn.

Residence: Op de O.Z. Voorburgwal in the Noortseboer
Biographical Notes: The late Joost Pietersz. may be the silk dyer of that name, living in de Witte Roos on the Vlooienburch, born in Antwerp, who invested 2000 f. in the first subscription for V.O.C. shares. He was one of the outstanding members of the Lutheran community (Van Dillen,     Het oudste aandeelhoudersregister, p. 245). An individual named Joost Pietersen freighted one ship between 1590 and 1602 (IJzerman, Economisch Historisch Jaarboek 17 (1931), p. 270). An entry in the baptismal books of the Lutheran Community shows that Joost Pieterssen was the father of a child named Susanna, baptized on May 14, 1593, in the presence of the witnesses Augustijn Pijn and Volcker van Surck (DTB 138/12). Another child, named Joost, was baptized on 7 September 1592, in the presence of Jacques Abelijn and Jacomijntje Helemont (DTB 138/15) and one named Cornelis on 27 May 1598 in the presence of Hans Pieters  and Maria de Copers (DTB 138/20). As usual in the baptismal records of the Lutheran church, the mother's name was not recorded. Hans Pietersz. of R 29891, who was a witness at the baptism of Cornelis, the son of Joost Pietersz., and Pieter Pietersz. of R 29293, were probably brothers of Joost Pietersz. It is possible that the Remonstrant Pieter Joosten,  who attended a meeting of a conventicle of Remonstrants in February 1618 together with Pieter Pietersz. (his uncle ?), was the son of Joost Pietersz.
Intro Text: Op ten 14e aprilis [1614] zyn ten ordre van den heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Joost Pietersz. Postscript: De weesmeesteren ordonneren G. J. Haringh de suyvere penningen van dese vercopinge te betalen aen Pieter Pietersz. ende Hillebrant Roo omme ten behoeve van de voors. Joost Pietersz te besteden den 25 july 1614, alle de weesmeesteren (present sijnde), is aen de voors. Pieter Pietersz. ende Hillebrant Roo betaelt, den 16 july 1614.

Residence: Op de Rouanse kay in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Steven Pinel, merchant from Antwerp, was first noted in Amsterdam in 1590 (Gelderblom, Zuid-Nederlandse kooplieden p. 311). He invested 5400 f. in V.O.C. shares in the first subscription in 1602. On 25 March 1605, Steven Pinel, born in Antwerp, widower of Geertruyd Reygers, was betrothed to Maria Berwijns, born in Antwerp, 23 years old, assisted by her father Bernard Berwijns (DTB 411/451). He must have died shortly before 10 April 1614 when the Orphan Chamber appointed Bartelemeus Moer (of R 21230) and Abraham van Beeck as guardians over his two children (WK 5073/513). The bankruptcy (or near-bankruptcy) of Abraham van Beeck in 1610 had evidently not been an obstacle to his appointment as guardian four years later (Gelderblom, op. cit., p. 231).   On 22 January 1615, thus four months after the above-mentioned sale, Maria Berwijns remarried with Steven Geerards from Dordrecht (Van Dillen, Het oudste aandeelhoudersregister p. 119). Jacob Leeuwen and Jacob Symonsz. Lou to whom a part of the proceeds of the sale were paid may have been Steven Pinel's creditors. On Jacob Leeuwen, see R 20369. Jacob Symonsz. Lou is likely to be the soap boiler named Jacob Symonsz. cited in an act of 22 September 1605 (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven R.G.P., 69(1929), p. 632). Jacob Symonsz. was also the guardian of the children of Ael Huygens, widow of Cornelis Herwayer of INVNO 901.
Intro Text: Opten iii september 1614 zyn ten ordre van den heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Steven Pinel. Postscript: By ... quitans boven (?) dese betalt te syn aen Jacob Leeuwens 301 guld. 18 st. 10 pen., aen Jacob Symonsz. Lou 910 gul. 1 st. de reste betalt per affirmatie van Gerrit Jacobsz.. Actum den 9 mey 1616 present (?) Reael ende Van Pol [weesmeesteren]

Biographical Notes: On 8 August 1592, Dirck Dierten, ships carpenter, 25 years old, assisted by his sister Griet Dierten, was betrothed to Gierte Claesdr. (DTB 665/53). The late Griet Dierten was the sister of Dirck Dierten, ship carpenter. Gerrit Claesz. Leyenaer, the guardian of the child, was a director of the Brabants compagnie founded in 1599. He invested 3600 f. in the first subscription to V.O.C. shares and had an account of 2 folios at the Wisselbank in 1615 (Van Dillen, Het oudste aandeelhoudersregister, p. 238). On the same day some goods left by [blank] were sold at request of Gerrit Claesz. Leyenaer. The only art objects were 1 schildery van de lotery van Leyden sold to Martyn for f 1: 3:-- and some bortges for f -: 9:-- sold for cash. The total proceeds were only 141 f. 13 st. 8 penn. Since the address given was op de Zeedijck as was the immediately following sale of Griete Dierten, it is possible that these goods had also belonged to her.
Intro Text: Ten selven dage [6 october] zyn vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Griete Dierten. Postscript: Gerrit Jacobsz. is geordonneert de suyvere penningen van dese vercopinge te betalen aen Gerrit Claesz. Leyenaer de kints voocht ... act den 17 december 1614. Is by quitancie van Gerrit Claesz. Leyenaer gebleken.

Additional Names: and his wife Jannetge Gerrits
Residence: In 't Waterschip by de Colck in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Opten viertienden maert 1617 syn dese naervolgende goederen vercoft achtergelaten by Willem Cornelisz. ende Jannetge Gerrits.

Residence: Op de Ouwe Varcke Marckt in de Oude Pool in Amsterdam.
Intro Text: Opten 17en april 1617 zyn de naervolgende goederen vercoft nagelaten by Grietge Reynders.

Additional Names: late wife of Andries Isbrantsz.
Residence: Op de Fluwele Burchwal by 't Princenhoff steechgen in Amsterdam.
Biographical Notes: On 17 January 1607, Andries Ysbrantsz., 25 (?) years old, living in the Ridderstraet, assisted by Pieter Joosten, his stepfather (behouden vader), and his mother Betgen Claes, was betrothed to Marritge Walighs, 28, living on the Nieuwe Dijck, assisted by her brother Pieter Walighs and her sister Duyfgen Walighs (DTB 412/152). Pieter Wallighs (or Wallichsz.), married to Baesgen Tysdr., had a son named Mathys Pietersz., whose guardian was Philips Tysz. of R 30694  of Montias2 (WK 5073/789 of 1 July 1638.)  Andries Ysbrantsz., already living on the Ridderstraet, bought lots for 3 f. 18 st. in the Haarlem lottery of 1606 (GAA, 89/7 F 668). He was a buyer at auction in 1609 (R 29509.) On Pieter Joosten see  the NOTES to R 29509 in Montias2. On 29 August 1634, the honorable Oede Dircx, a daughter of Aeltge Willems, who was herself a daughter of Willem Willemsz., a son of Aeltge Waligs, the sister of Maritge Wallichs, both of whom were daughters of Walich Gerritsz. van Oostgeest, transferred a vicariate created by Rutger van Oostgeest in Leiden to her oldest son Pieter Danckertsz., for him and for his heirs (NA 596, fol. 180, Not. Lamberti). Aeltge Willems, married to Pieter Laurensz. Spiegel de jonge (perhaps of R 7612), was the daughter of the soap boiler Willem Willemsz. (see the NOTES to R 7612 of Montias2) and of Nelletge Bartouts, who were Roman Catholic. Vicariates were created as interest-bearing obligations by R.C. churches before the Alteration. Most beneficiaries in later periods were R.C.
Intro Text: Opten 24en april 1617 zyn dese naervolgende goederen vercoft naergelaten by Marritje Walichs. Postscript: Betaelt aen Andries Isbrants de weduwer als by de cedel blyckt.

Residence: Op de Achterburchwal over de Hoyberch in Amsterdam.
Biographical Notes: Machtelt Jans has not been identified. She was presumably the mother of the children of whom Cornelis Felt had been appointed guardian. Cornelis Felt was a merchant who freighted one ship between 1590 and 1602 (IJzerman, Economisch Historisch Jaarboek, 17 (1931), p. 269). In 1621, he was appointed by the Orphan Chamber guardian over the children of the late Jan Cuyper (of R 29736 of Montias2). Cornelis Feldt was a signatory to the Remonstrant petition of 1628.
Intro Text: Opten 28en april 1617 zyn vercoft de goederen nagelaten by Machtelt Jans. Postscript: By quitancie van Cornelis Felt gebleken betaelt te syn.

Additional Names: and his wife Tryn Dirxdr.
Biographical Notes: Jan Jansz. Appel, scheepstimmerman, who bought lots for 5 f. 8 st. at the Haarlem lottery of 1606 may have been the son of Jan Jorisz. Appel (GAA, 149/37 F 1075).
Intro Text: Op den 23en juny 1617 zyn vercoft dese goederen achtergelaten by Jan Jorisz. Appel ende Tryn Dirxdr. Postscript: Gerrit Jacobs is by weesmeesteren geordoneert te betaelen aen Griet Symons van 400 gulden. Quitancie van Willemtje Roberts.

Additional Names: and his wife Judith Sorij
Biographical Notes: On 22 October 1611, Pieter Stoffelsz., collecteur op de Rode, 22, living the Barbaradwarsstraet, assisted by his mother Katelyne Gheerlofs, was betrothed to Judith Sorij, from Delft, living on the Singel near the Gasthuyspoort, 22 years old (DTB 416/23). In addition to the goods sold at auction, noch zyn de volgende goederen by de voochden by mond vercoft, including een schilderijtken etc.. for 34 f. to Claertgen, de suster van de vrou zal. Claertgen was also a buyer at the auction (R 29909 of Montias2).
Intro Text: Opten 19 july 1617 zyn ten ordre van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft dese naevolgende goederen achtergelaten by Pieter Soffelsz. ende Judith Sorij.

Biographical Notes: Jannetje Verschuijl was betrothed to Gerrit Rijckelsma on 1 March 1586. She was born in Eindhoven and lived at one time in Haarlem. She invested 600 f. in the original subscription for V.O.C. shares (Van Dillen, Het oudste aandeelhoudersregister, p. 245). On 12 May 1595, Gerrit Rijckelsma sold to Abraham Pietersz. a house on the Warmoesstraet, called de Orangeboom for f. 2,400 (Kam, Waar was dat huis in de Warmoesstraat?, 36/11). He moved to another house on the Warmoesstraet called de Koning David. On 4 August 1606, Jannetje Verschuijl leased,  on behalf of her husband, some ground formerly belonging to the Karthuizerklooster, to Huygh Gerritsz. Harinck (the brother of the auctioneers Jacob Gerritsz. and Thomas Gerritsz. Harinck), for use as a place to make roof tiles (pannebakkerij)  She was buried in the O.K. on 11 February 1608 (I. van Eeghen, Van Karthuizerklooster tot Karthuizerhof, Jaarboek Amstelodamum 81(1989), pp. 52 and 53).  Van Eeghen suggested that Gerrit van Rijckelsma might be identical with Gerrit Rinckes, from Berlikum, who obtained the citizenship of Amsterdam on 1 March 1586 (ibid., p. 51). Rijckelsma, in partnership with Cornelis van Tongerloo, who was later to found a glass manufacture in Amsterdam, dried marshes in the Zijpe, and went to Venice in 1605 to sink wells for salt and water.  He established a manufacture of movable mills for grinding grain in the former Karthuizerklooster, some of which he sold to the young Christiaen IV of Denmark, who wished to use them to feed his troops during a military campaign (Van Eeghen, ibid. and M. de Roever in Exh. Cat. Amsterdam: Venetien van het Noorden, 1992, p. 168.) He was also important in cloth manufacture.  Rijckelsma gave the painter and etcher Hans Rem (of R 27756 of Montias2) a commission to make prints of the stranding of the Spanish fleet in 1601. Rem received 100 f. for one version of the print, 150 f. for another, from the States General, which had issued an octroi for their publication (Van Eeghen, op. cit. p. 54).  The widower Gerrit Rijckelsma lived in Amsterdam till about 1616 when he left to carry out various enterprises, including some for the Prince of Hesse (Van Eeghen, op.c cit. p. 53). Victor Rijckelsma (of R 29950), the son of Gerrit Rijckelsma and Jannetje Verschuijl, baptized on 23 March 1589, became a predikant and co-rector of the Latin School in Haarlem (1617-1620), from which he was removed, along with Rector Theodor Schrevelius for his Remonstrant sympathies (Van Eeghen, op. cit. pp. 53 and 62). His uncles Jan Verschuijl (of R 29937 of Montias2) and Thomas Marinus (of R 29940 of Montias2) helped Victor secure the fellowship (beurse) which allowed him to study theology (ibid. p. 62).
Intro Text: Opten 16 april 1608 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Jannetge Verschuyl. Postscript: Total f 1918: 4: 4. Deductions: Salaris, f 96: 8:--; voor copeij: f 2:25:--; voor oplegging: f 12:--:--; voor de tafel ende oproepen: f 1:--:--. Rest zuiiver: f 1806:11: 4.

Biographical Notes: On 18 December 1614, the masters of the Orphan Chamber appointed Jacob Jansz. Lantarenmacker, the children's uncle, as guardian over and curator of the estate of the children of Captain Heyndrick Jansz. de Lange (WK 5073/513, fol. 148). In addition to Jacob Jansz., Captain Hendrick Jansz. de Lange may have been the brother of Michiel Jansz. de Lange (of R 21699 of Montias2),  born in Bergen in 1578, husband of Grietge Woutersdr. Verhee, who invested 900 f. in the first subscription for V.O.C. shares (Van Dillen, Het oudste aandeelhoudersregister, p. 186). On 13 October 1633, Trujntje Claes, widow of Hendrick Jansz. de Lange, was betrothed to Willem Cornelisz. Bruijn (DTB 441/263). It should be noted that an earlier sale had taken place on 6 June 1608 of the goods left by Hendrick Jansz. de Lange, which consisted only of clothing. The proceeds of the sale, 186 f. 14 st., were paid to Dirck Jacobsz. Heyn (see the INTRO above)  and Anne Jans, the godmother.
Intro Text: Op ten 28e october 1609 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren  vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Cap[itey]n Hendrick Jansz. de Lange. Postscript: Dese penningen syn aen Dirck Jacobsz. Heijn de pete moen betaelt.

Additional Names: and his wife Sack van Loo
Residence: Op de O.Z. Voorburgwal int Ryff Woeck in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: The deceased was a schoolmaster. On the painter Pauwels de Vries, see NOTES to  R 28936 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Opten 27 january 1609 syn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Joost van Looten schoolmeester ende Sack van Loo syn huysvrouw. Postscript: Is onder de handt van Pauwels de Vries ende Daniel Rogge by de cedel gebleken dat de penningen van de vercoft goederen syn betaelt den 26en april 1609.

Biographical Notes: The late owner of the goods sold may be Elbert Diercs Metselaer who was betrothed to Neel Claes on 26 May 1598 (DTB 663/75). Jan Harmensz. cuyper, to whom the proceeds of the sale were paid, was overman of the guild of kolenmeters on 18 September 1613 (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven R.G.P. 78(1933), p. 63).
Intro Text: Op ten 27 february 1609 zyn ter ordonnantie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Elb[ert?] de Metselaer. Postscript: De penningen ... betaelt aen Jan Harmensz. cuyper den 12 september 1609.

Biographical Notes: The owner of the goods sold at this sale is probably the merchant and insurer Jacques  Rombouts (I)  who was married to Anna de Wilde, even though the date of death reported by one of Jacques Rombouts's descendants was reported to be 1612 and not 10 December 1608 (see below), which is consistent with the date of this sale. (On the apparently erroneous date of death of Jacques Rombouts I,  see Nederlandsche Leeuw, 42(1924), col. 211). Jacques Rombouts I was cited as an assuradeur in a document of 12 June 1596 (Winkelman, Bronnen voor de geschiedenis van het Oostzeehandel, R.G.P., 178(1981), p. 76). He must not be confused with his son  Jacques Jacquesz. Rombouts or with Jacob Jacobsz. Rombouts (1581-1626), the son of Rombout Jacobsz. I (1550-1629). It was perhaps the latter, whose name was given as Jacob Rombouts,  who assisted the painter and future schout Jan Tengnagel upon his betrothal to Meijnsgen Simonsdr., the daughter of Symon Jansz. Pynas on 19 November 1611 (Oud Holland 1(1883), p. 197). Jacob (or Jacques) Jacobsz. Rombouts, who bought lots in the Haarlem lottery in 1606, is  probably identical with Jacob Jacobsz. Rombouts, cited above. It was apparently Jacob Jacobsz. Rombouts who was buried on 12 October 1626 (DTB 1054/27). The widow of Jacques Rombouts and his son (probably Jacques Rombouts III), living on the Singel, paid a tax of 300 f. in 1631 (Kohier, fol. 13, p. 4).   There is little doubt, in any case, that Jacques Rombouts I  and Hans Rombouts, who were both born in Antwerp, were the sons of Willem Rombouts and Catharina Regers (Nederlandsche Leeuw 42(1924), col. 211-213).  On 26 March 1596, the merchant Jacques Rombouts and his wife Anna de Wilde had their child Catrijna baptized in the presence of Tanneken Mens (or Moens) (DTB 38/90). Tanneken Moens was the mother of Bartel Philipsz. of R 27378 of Montias2.  On 12 November 1599, Jacques Rombouts, koopman, (I?), and his wife Tanneken Rombouts (identical with Anna de Wilde ?)  had their son Geeliaemen baptized in the presence of Cathalijna Rombouts (DTB 3/209). Jacques Roemboeutsen (Rombouts) was buried on 10 December 1608 (DTB 1053/92). Cathalina Rombouts, the sister of Jacques (I) and Hans Rombouts, was married, first, to Pieter Walraven and, second, to Adriaen Vierendeel.  Hans Rombouts (of INVNO 200), the brother of Jacques Rombouts I, who received the proceeds of this sale, bought works of art in it (R 30032). The children of Jacques Rombouts I were Catharina (baptism cited above, died in 1661), who married Dirck van Wissel[t] (of R 20620); Maerten; Willem (probably the same as Geeliaemen, baptized in 1599); Jacob (or Jacques ?) already cited, who married Gertruyd Arminius;  and Hans, cannunick in Utrecht, who died a bachelor (on the Rombouts genealogy, see Nederlandsche Leeuw, op. cit.)
Intro Text: Op den 24 marty 1609 zyn ter ordonnacie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Jacques Rombouts. Postscript: De penningen ... betaelt aen Hans Rombouts.

Additional Names: wife of Hendrick Jacobsz. Appelman
Biographical Notes: Henrick Appelman, living on the Nieuwendijck, paid a tax of 4 f. in 1585 (Van Dillen, Amsterdam, p. 147).
Intro Text: Op ten 16 aprilis 1609 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Neel Cornelis huysvrou van Hendrick Jacobsz. Appelman.

Biographical Notes: Annetje Gilberts, the widow of Anthony del Cham, was declared insolvent and her inventory taken on the order of the commissaries of the Insoventboedelkamer on 7 September 1646 (DBK 5072/353). She may have been the widow of the owner of the goods in this sale or of his  son or other close relative.  For the inventory sale of Pauwels Bisschop, art dealer, who received the proceeds of the sale, see INVNO 575 of 1620.
Intro Text: Op ten 3e junij 1609 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Anthony del Cam. Postscript: Dese penningen syn betaelt aen Pauwels Bisschop als by reckening ...

Biographical Notes: Jochem Dircksz. was a merchant who freighted one ship between 1590 and 1602 (IJzerman, Economisch-Historisch Jaarboek, vo. 31 (1617), p. 269). On 3 September 1609, Jan Cornelisz., former goldsmith (of R 28594) and Cornelis Pietersz. Can (brother of Pieter Pietersz. Can of R 21378 of Montias2) were named guardians of the estate of Jochem Dirxsz. (WK 5073/513, fol. 133). Jochem Dircksz. may have been the brother of Claes Dircksz. Schepel, cited in R 30126 of Montias2, who bought lots in this sale. Note that Jochem Dircksz. of this inventory cannot be identical with Jochem Dircksz. Muijsenest of R 33258 of Montias2 since the latter bought a lot in 1637.
Intro Text: Op ten 17e october 1609 syn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Jochem Dircksz.

Residence: Op de Gasthuys Meulen steech in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: The owner of these goods, Barber Jacobs, must not be confused with the well-known uitdraagster (the mother of Pieter Lastman),  who bore the same name. The latter died in 1624 (see INVNO 821 of 19 April 1625).
Intro Text: Den 11e decembris 1609 zyn vercoft ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren de goederen achtergelaten by Barber Jacobs.

Biographical Notes: The late owner of the goods at this auction, Neel Volckertsdr., was the wife of N.N. Bouwen. They were the parents of Jannetgen Bouwens, born in 1557 and buried on 21 April 1633, who married Jan Claesz. Cloeck in Amsterdam on 10 January 1599 (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 398).
Intro Text: Den 5e mary 1610 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Neel Volckertsdr.

Biographical Notes: The painter Gillis van Conincxloo was born in Antwerp in 1544. He married Maeyken Robroeck in Antwerp and, after her death, Geertgen van Eeden in 1603. He lived in Middelburg from the beginning of 1585 to 1587, then spent 8 years in Frankenthal. In the middle of 1595, he settled in Amsterdam, of which he became a citizen in 1597. He died in 1606. He was an ardent Calvinist (Briels, Zuidnederlandse immigratie, pp. 221-222). In the year of his death, 1606, he bought lots in the Haarlem lottery for 12 st. voor Helena jongh in jaren, rijckt sij een goet lot, sij sal wel bewaren (Helena was his daughter) (20/37 F 138). N. de Roever suggested, on the basis of the similarity in titles of certain lots,  that several paintings and water colors in the sales held at the request of Hans van Conincxloo (INVNO 749), [anonymous] (INVNO 750), and Pieter Isaacksz. (INVNO 751) belonged to the estate of Gillis van Conincxloo (      Oud Holland 3(1885), pp. 40-44). In some cases, indicated in the NOTES for these works of art in Montias2, I have indicated that the identity was at least plausible. In the case of the sale held at the request of Pieter Isaacksz., in which there is a single coincidence of titles, the identity seems improbable to me.
Intro Text: Op ten eersten Marty 1607 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Gillis van Conincksloo op ses weecken dagh.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Regents of Orphan Chamber
Intro Text: 25 may 1619 ten versoecke van de Regenten van de Weeshuys vercocht.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Grietge Thymons, widow of Floris Willemsz.
Residence: Op de Brestraet by de Nieuwe Waech
Biographical Notes: On 19 March 1616, Floris Willemsz., widower of Liesbet Danckerts, was betrothed to Grietge Thiemons, widow of Jacob Slager (3 years), living on the Zeedijck (DTB 420/112). Floris Willemsz. was a schipper, living in the Vrouwensteech.  The goods sold probably belonged to Floris Willemsz., but the introduction does not make this clear.
Intro Text: Op 15 martij 1625 zyn ten versoecke van Grietge Thymons weduwe van Floris Willemsz. vercoft dese naervolgende goederen.

Residence: In de Lauriersstraet in de Wolsack in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Isaack Sindorp, the son of Jacob Sindorp, was a buyer at the auction of his father's goods (R 30243 of Montias2).  On 14 February 1621, Isaack Sindorp and his wife Trijn Frerix had their son Abraham baptized in the N.K. in the presence of Betje Teunis (DTB 40/116). On 8 May 1634, the honorable Catrina van Sindorp, widow of the late Isaack van Sindorp, assisted by her brother-in-law and guardian Hans Gerritsz., on one side, and the honorable Jacob Venturin, silk spinner, on the other, signed a contract of apprenticeship for Isaack, the son of Catrina and Isaack van Sindorp (see R 30243). Jacob Venturyn, silk spinner, living on the Keysersgracht, was said to be 32 in a deposition dated 23 February  1639. He was married to Jannetie van de Rogier (NA 1021, Not. S. van der Piet).
Intro Text: Op den 3e january 1623 zyn vercoft de nagelaten goederen van Jacob Sindorp te betalen de beloofde cooppenningen in gerede gelde doch zullen de gene de borgen hebben gestelt ofte stellen sullen  genieten ses weecken dach.

Additional Names: widow of Hendrick Bouwer
Residence: Op de O.Z. Voorburchwal by de Liesdelsluijs
Biographical Notes: Hendrick Bouwer, born in 1547, married Catharina ten Berch on 25 November 1569. She was buried in the O.K. on 29 October 1624. She was the daughter of Marten ten Berch and Metgen Hansdr. Kind and the sister of Brechte ten Berch cited in the TEXT of R 184. Hendrick Brouwer was buried in the O.K. on 29 October 1624.   His nephew Melchior Bouwer, the son of Hillebrand Brouwer, became secretary of Amsterdam (1611-1626) (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 413). He was a buyer at auction (R 27856 of Montias2). Catharina ten Berch was a regent of the Leprozenhuis.
Intro Text: Op den 12 april 1625 zyn vercocht de naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Catarina van den Berch weduwe van Hendrick Bouwer.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Gerrit and Jan Jacobsz. Coeckebacker
Biographical Notes: Gerrit and Jan Jacobsz. Coeckebacker, at whose request the goods were sold, are presumed to be the sons of Jacob Jansz. Coeckebacker (who died in 1595) and of  Aecht Jandsdr. Benningh. They were probably also the brothers of Claes Jacobsz. Coeckebacker (of R 28510 of Montias2), who was a member of the Raed of Amsterdam but was dismissed in 1623 (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 214). Jan Jacobsz. Bennink Couckebacker (probably of R 30281)  invested 6000 f. in the first subscription for V.O.C. shares (Van Dillen, Het oudste aandeelhoudersregister, p. 126). Tryn Gerrits was probably a relative of the Coeckebackers.
Intro Text: Op huyden den 10e May [1625] zyn ten versoecke van Gerrit ende Jan Jacobsz. Coeckebacker als curateurs over de boel van Tryn Gerrits vercoft de naervolgende goederen.

Residence: Op de Princegraft over 't hoff van Bohemen
Biographical Notes: Cornelis Boom I  of the present inventory cannot be identical with Cornelis Boom II, the son of Abraham Boom, who lived from 1601 to 1651 and became pensionaris of Amsterdam.  He is probably identical with the carpenter of that name who married Geertgen Ariaens (a buyer at auction of R 30284 of Montias2) on 29 January 1615.  At that time he was 24 years old and living on the Spiegelstraet. He  may have been a son or grandson of Cornelis Pietersz. Boom, lijndraaier and scheepmacker, who was married to Griet Jacobs Codde (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 132). The Hof van Bohemen where Cornelis Boom and Geertgen Ariaens had been living  was indeed located on the Princengracht.
Intro Text: Opden 16e junij 1625 zoo syn ten versoecke van de erffgenamen van Cornelis Boom vercocht de naervolgende goederen.

Residence: Op de Oude Heeregraft bij de Heijsteegh in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Rogier Meuwels was an occasional buyer at auction. He bought fairly expensive paintings (such as the one by Frans Francken II of R 20491), which are not included in the present inventory. From the high percentage of the value of art works he owned at his death to the total of his meuble goederen, it may be inferred that he was perhaps at least an occasional art dealer.  His name is usually followed by tot Casper Onckelboer, which may mean that he was living in the house of Onckelboer (or possibly that Onckelboer was his surety). The day after this auction, November 7, 1625, the heirs of Rogier Meuwels, named Warnaer Albertsz. and Pieter Segersz., silversmith (the brother of the painter Pieter Lastman) to handle the succession (GAA, NA 351B, film 6406). Jasper or Casper Onckelboers, from Antwerp, was 26 years old on 8 October 1605 when he was betrothed to Sara de Vett (DTB 411/596). On 25 June 1638, Abraham Anthonisz., the famous Remonstrant, turned over to the Orphan Chamber the accounts for the assets inherited by the children of Jasper Honckelboers (WK 5073/1193). On 19 May 1636, Hans Meuwesz., 48, and Claes Janz. Meuwesz., 73, living in Amsterdam, declared at the request of Seger Pietersz., goldsmith, that they had signed and approved an act of succession as heirs of Rogier Meuwesz. ( NA 597)  His son Hans (cited above and in the NOTES to R 20491 in Montias2) was a silk spinner (zydereder). He died before 2 April 1637 when his death inventory was taken (NA 714, Not. P. Carels). Hans, judging by his books and by the portraits of preachers in his inventory, was very probably Reformed.
Intro Text: Op den 6e novembris 1625 zyn vercocht dese goederen bij Rogier Meuwels [naergelaten ?]

Residence: Op de Nieuwen Dijck in de Oliphant binnenhuys
Biographical Notes: Marij Pieters has not been identified. The Oliphant on the Nieuwen Dijck was also known as De Witte Oliphant.
Intro Text: Op 13 january 1626 zyn vercocht aende naervolgende personen de goederen hierna gestelt achtergelaten bij Marij Pieters.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of heirs of Jannetge Jacobs
Residence: Op de Rawaense Kaij bij de Jan Roon Poorts Tooren in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Den 7e april 1626 zyn ten versoecke vande erffgenamen van Jannetge Jacobs vercocht dese naervolgende goederen

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Louijs Ponje as father of children under age of Dirckgen Wouters
Biographical Notes: On 4 December 1627, Louys Pongie, from Doornik, innkeeper, widower of Dirckje Clevits (Kevits?), was betrothed to Stijntje Jans, from Bommel, widow (5 1/2 years) of Gerrit Jansz. Coerts (DTB 432/486). Louis Pongie (or Ponie) was an innkeeper (see the NOTES to R 24996 of Montias2). On 13(?) October 1633, Thomas Maes, 28, made a deposition at the request of Stijntje Jans, wife of Louis Ponje, about events that occurred in the inn de Vergulde Pauw (which was probably Ponje's inn) (NA 372, fol. 155, Not. W. Cluyt). Thomas Maes, the son of Harmen Tomasz., at one point (perhaps shortly after the last deposition) was in Recife da Pernambuco where he served Isack de Rosiere, an employee of the W.I.C. (NA 695A, omslag 73, fol. 420vo, Not. J. Warnaerts). Louis Pongie  was buried on 10 April 1637 (DTB 1130/60). Dirckje Clevits (Kevits?) is presumably identical with Dirckje Wouters, to whom the goods sold had belonged.
Intro Text: Op den 9e october 1627 zyn ten versoecke van Louij Ponje als vader van twee onmondige kinderen van Dirckgen Wouters vercocht dese naervolgende goederen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Adriaen de Kempenaer and Rogier Jansz.
Residence: ten huyse van Daniel Jansz. van Beuningen in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Adriaen de Kempenaer, at whose request the goods in this sale were sold, may be identical with Adriaen, son of Danckert de Kempenaer of R 25250 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Op en 2en february 1628 zijn ten versoeck van Adriaen de Kempenaer ende Rogier Jansz. vercocht dese naervolgende goederen te betalen etc.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Roeloff Warnaertsz., uncle and guardian of the children of Hendrick Warnaertsz.
Biographical Notes: The late Hendrick Warnaertsz. may be the tinsmith (tinnegieter) who stood surety for 1200 f. for Jacob Rutgersz. bierbeschoyer, on 10 February 1610 (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven, R.G.P., 69(1929), p. 677.) Roeloff Warnaertsz., the guardian of the children, was most probably the brother of the late Hendrick Warnaertsz.
Intro Text: Op den 2e augustus 1628 soo syn ten versoecke van Roeloff Warnaertsz. als oom ende voogd van de nagelaten kinderen van Hendrick Warnaertsz. vercocht etc...

Additional Names: and his wife Trijntge Pieters
Biographical Notes: On 3 October 1615, Jan Maes, from Zevender, wine distributor, 33 years old, living on the Verwerssingel (for 28 years), no living parents, was betrothed to Trijntie Pieters, 28, from Rinsmageest,  living on the Zeedijck, assisted by her acquaintance  Maritgen Gerrits (DTB 419/238). In January (?) 1628, Pieter Hermansz., wine dealer (cited in the TEXT of R 391), sold a house on the Zeedijck to Jan Maes, wine dealer, for 2,300 f. (WK 5073/913). On 16 January 1636, Dirck Maes, as the uncle of Dirck, 14, Pieter, 13, Gerrit, 12, Coren(?) and Jannetje, twins, 11, Gierten, 10, Grietgen, 7, Jannetgen, 6, the children of Jan Maes, wine dealer, whose mother was Trijntgen Pieters, brought some assets to the Orphan Chamber on the children's behalf (WK 5073/7089). The wine dealer should not be confused with Jan Maes, married to Anna van der Meer who died before 1 March 1652 when his widow signed a marriage contract with the tobacco dealer Paulus van Heemskerck (INVNO 1173). It is not clear which of the two, if not a third individual with this name, living on the Rockin, paid a tax of 30 f. in 1631 (Kohier, fol. 251, p. 57).
Intro Text: Den 6en february sijn vercocht de naergelate goederen van Jan Maes ende Trijntge Pieters.
Den 8 martij 1635 zijn de naergelaten goederen van Styntgen Livens vercocht.

Residence: Op de O.Z. Achterburchwal in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: The procuror Hendrick van Marcken was married to Maritgen Everts de Swart. He was an attorney before the court (de Vierschaer) of Amsterdam. He was portrayed as a shooter in the company of Reynst Pietersz. in a group portrait by Dirck Barentsz. in 1585 (Oud Holland 15(1897), p. 136). He was the father of Frans van Marcken of R 23546 of Montias2, sheriff of Amstelveen in 1635; of Maritgen van Marcken, married to Andries Mombers; of Diewertgen van Marcken, married to Pieter Cornelisz.; and of Aeltgen van Marcken, married to Barent Gerritsz. Bernardyns, who died before 11 May 1629, when she appeared before the Orphan Chamber as a widow with children (WK 5073/789). Aeltgen van Marcken apparently remarried with Jan Garbrantsz., ship's carpenter, before 9 January 1636, when she was scheduled to appear before the Commissary for Small Affairs (commissaris voor cleijne saecken) (NA 991, fol. 1, Not. J. Bosch).  On 29 July 1632, Anna Claes, assisted by her guardian Hendrick Claesz. van Marcken, appeared before the Orphan Chamber on behalf of her children with her late husband, a shoemaker (WK 5073/789). Hendrick van Marcken was portrayed, possibly by Cornelis Ketel or by Dirck Barendsz., approximately in 1609, in the Korporaalschap of Reynst Pietersz. and vaandrig Claes Claesz. Kruijs (Blankert, Amsterdams Historisch Museum, p. 404). In 1602, Reijnier Paeuw invested 100 f. for Hendrick van Marckel in the first subscription for V.O.C. shares (Van Dillen, Het oudste aandeelhoudersregister, p. 251). Hendrick van Marcken was a buyer of porceleijn at an Orphan Chamber sale of 16 October 1626 (WK 5073/952). Hendrick van Marcken must have died in late 1634 or early 1635 when his family came to an agreement on the settlement of the estate. which had apparently had more assets than debts and was to be turned over to his creditors. The agreement was  signed on 11 February 1635 by the widow Maritgen Everts de Swart; by Frederick Harmensz. Dickstein, her brother-in-law; by her nephew and guardian Jan Pauw; by her son Frans van Marcken; by Andries Mombers, married to Maritgen van Marcken; by Pieter Cornelisz., married to Dieuwertgen van Marcken; and by Aeltge van Marcken, widow of Barent Gerritsz. (Bernardyn) (NA 991, film 1220, fol.25, Not. Jan Bosch). On 14 March 1636, Maritge de Swart, widow of Hendrick van Marcken, named Hugo van Groenewegen to defend her against Frans van Marcken, Schout of Amstelveen (NA 991, fol.26, Not. J. Bosch).
Intro Text: Op den 13e april 1635 zijn de naergelaten goederen vercoft van Procureur Hendrick van Marcken.

Residence: In de Kalverstraet bij de Heijligesteeg in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 16en decembris zijn vercocht dese naervolgende goedern achtergelaten bij Lysbeth Meuwes.

Additional Names: and his wife Stijn Jans
Intro Text: Op den 8 Martij anno 1625 zyn vercocht dese naervolgende goederen achtergelaten bij Pieter Cornelisen ende Stijn Jans zijn huysvrou.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Hans van Conincksloo (II)
Biographical Notes: From the identity of two of the  works of art in this inventory with items in Gillis van Conincxloo's death inventory of 19 January 1607, N. de Roever implied that the paintings in this sale, sold at the request of Hans van Conincxloo II, were part of Gillis van Conincxloo's estate (most of which was sold in the sale of 1 March 1607 (INVNO 733)). This is highly uncertain and rather improbable.  Hans van Coninxloo II, the son of Hans van Coninxloo I who died about 1595, married Magdalena Ruts (or Rudts) in 1588. After Magdalena's death, he remarried with  Clara Wouters from Antwerp, 37 years old, in 1599 in Amsterdam. He became a poorter of Amsterdam in 1605. He spent the last two years of his life in Embden where he died shortly before June 1620. His son Hans van Coninxloo III was also an art dealer. For more details, see the NOTES to  R 29348 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Ten selven dage ten versoecke van Hans van Conincksloo zyn vercocht de naervolgende goederen, ende de teckeningen by Jacques van der Wet tot David Born.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of [....] [perhaps belonging to the estate of Gillis van Conincxloo]
Intro Text: Op den 5en marty 1607 zyn ten versoeck van [left blank] vercoft de naervolgende goederen

Additional Names: goods sold at the request of Pieter Isaacx
Biographical Notes: On the painter Pieter Isaacksz., at whose request the goods were sold, see R 21175. He was married to Susanna Crayborn. His four daughters were named Cathalyn, Helena, Margriet and Mary. He was active in Amsterdam from 1590 to 1607 and lived the rest of his life in Denmark where he died in 1625. N. de Roever suggested in his article on the Conincxloo's in Oud  Holland (3(1885), p. 43) that at least some of the lots in this sale were part of the estate of Gillis van Conincxloo, the main sale of whose works had taken place on 19 January 1607.
Intro Text: Opten 3 marty 1607 zyn ten versoeck van Pieter Isaacx vercoft de naervolgende goederen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Cornelis van der Voort
Biographical Notes: On Cornelis van der Voort, see the TEXT to R 464 and the NOTES to R 20793 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Opten 5e marty 1607 zyn ten versoeck van Cornelis van der Voort vercoft de naervolgende goederen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Jan Basse
Biographical Notes: On Jan Basse, see the notes to R 7637 in Montias2. After his death in 1637, an enormous auction sale of his possessions took place.
Intro Text: Dese navolgende goederen zyn van Jan Basse [crossed out: Hans van Conincksloo] vercoft den sesten marty 1607.

Additional Names: goods belonging to Govert Govertsz., Pieter Segersz., and Crispijn
Biographical Notes: Govert Govertsz., a buyer at the auction of Gillis van Coninxloo (R 30494), was the knecht of the latter, which probably meant that he was a painter working for him. Pieter Segersz. was the father of Pieter Lastman. He had formerly been bode of the Orphan Chamber but had been removed from this function, qua Roman Catholic, after the alteration in 1578. On Crispiaen Colijn, see the text of R 596 in Montias1.
Intro Text: Ten selve dag [6e marty] syn vercoft de navolgende goederen toecomende Govert Govertsz., Pieter Segersz., ende Crispijn (Colijn).

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Hans Conincxloo (II)
Occupation: Retail merchant |a Art dealer; Artist |a Painter
Biographical Notes: On Hans van Coninxloo II, see the TEXT of  R 652 of Montias1 and NOTES to  R 9348 of Montias2.
Intro Text: De navolgende zyn van Hans Conincxloo

Residence: Op de Camper Steyger in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Abraham Cornelisz. Bestevaer, who was probably the late Cornelis Bestevaer's son, was betrothed to Grietje Jans on 21 March 1635 (DTB 443/258). Pretentje Cornelis Bestevaer, who may have been his daughter, was betrothed to  Roeloff Adamsz. Heck on 27 February 1638. She was the widow of Laurens Jansz. (DTB 448/115).  Willem Jansz. Uijl, cited in the INTRO, was the brother of the painter Jan Jansz. Uijl.
Intro Text: Op den xxe april 1609 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Cornelis Cornelisz. Bestevaer. Postscript: Gerrit Jacobsz. heeft vertoont van de betalinge van dese ordonnancie hem gegeven door Willem Jansz. Uijl, Gerrit Claesz. Leyenaer ende Jan Jacobsz. Wrocht den 1 february 1608.

Biographical Notes: A kousemacker (hose-maker) named Jacques de Heer may be the owner of the goods sold in this sale. With his wife Jakemijn de Heer he had his daughter baptized in the O.K. on 18 May 1585 in the presence of Maeijken Hessels (DTB 1/257). He may have remarried after the death of Jakemijn, if the following baptism does not refer to another individual. On 2 March 1604, Jacques Heer and Hilletje Hendricx had their daughter Annetge baptized in the N.K. (DTB 39/32). The son of the owner, to whom the proceeds of the sale were remitted, was named Heer Jacobsz. Jacob Heer (or Hero), who invested in the painting and art-dealing business of Hendrick van Uylenburgh of R 24428, may have been the son of Heer Jacobsz.  Uylenburgh acknowledged a debt to him (as well as to Rembrandt and a number of other individuals including some renowned painters) on 20 January 1640 (Strauss, Rembrandt Documents, p. 185). Jacob de Heer, who may be this same investor, was a wine dealer. He was betrothed, as widower of Aeltje Bogaerts, to Maria, the daughter of Nicolaes Ruts (1630-1711), on 20 June 1659 (DTB 480/54). After his death, she remarried with a plumber (loodgieter) named Gerrit Jansz.  Hoefmans on 4 November 1672 (Jaarboek Amstelodamum 26(1939), p. 68 and DTB 498/261). It is improbable, on balance, that Jacob Heer and Jacob de Heer are identical. The location of the house of the owner, In't Hemelrijck, would be seem to be in the fifth wijk, on the N.Z., not far from the Coningsgracht (see Kohier, p.90).
Intro Text: Ten selven dage [12 aprilis 1607] syn ter ordonnencie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Jacob Heer. Postscript: de suyvere penningen ... betaelt ... aen Heer Jacobsz.

Additional Names: and his wife (Elsje Michiels)
Biographical Notes: Part of the estate of the late Jan Colyn was sold at auction and part was assessed, apparently for distribution to the children. Jan Colijn, born in Antwerp on 21 November 1548 died in Amsterdam on 18 May 1603. He was a glovemaker and retailer, but he also produced a Spanish-Dutch dictionary in 1576, which was later reprinted. He married Elsje  Michiels (1557-1603) on 31 January 1580 (Jaarboek C.B.G. 14(1960), p. 64). In 1594, the ship Den Engel that he had freighted was damaged in a storm (Winkelman, Bronnen voor de geschiedenis van het Oostzeehandel R.G.P. 178(1981), pp. 13-14). Jan Colijn was a buyer at Orphan Chamber auction in 1601 (R 38541 of Montias2).   Jan Colijn and Elsje Michiels were the parents of 10 children. On 29 January 1608, Michiel (of R 22124) was already married, Claes was 28 years old,  Niesgen was 22, Jan 17, Heyndrick (of R 26959), Emanuel (of R 24926) 13, and  Lysbeth 8. Niesgen (Nieske) married Cornelis Benninck Jansz., widower of Aefje Cornelis Boshamer (Bolhamer?), on 5 December 1613.  Elisabeth, baptized on 30 August 1 1599, married Amelis Vortkamp in Amersfoort on 20 August 1625. Jan Colijn II, cited in the NOTES to R 26959 of Montias2, died in the East Indies. Nicolaes is cited in the NOTES to R 22124 of Montias2 (Jaarboek C.B.G. 14(1960) p. 68 and passim).  In 1608, the children inherited part of a house on the Warmoesstraet, called de Meerman. On Jan Colyn II, see also the NOTES to R 26959. The children also inherited property  from their uncles Heyndrick (I)  and Pieter Michielsz. and from their great uncle Rombout Jacobsz. (de oude)  (of R 31491), the brother-in-law of Jan Colijn  (J.G. Kam, Waar was dat huis in de Warmoesstraat?, p. 34/13).
Intro Text: Op den iiii may 1607 zyn ter ordonnantie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Jan Colyn en syn huysvrou. Postscript: Den 25sten augustj is geconsenteert dat Claes Colyn dese suyvere overschietende penningen te mogen ontfangen . Van de reste dese penningen heeft Gerrit Jacobsz. vertont quitans ondertekent by Emanuel Colyn. Present: Jan Pietersz. Rijael and Harmen van der Poll (Orphan Chamber masters).

Biographical Notes: On 18 March 1607, Willem Arentsz. (Aertsz.),  wine dealer, passed his testament. He named as his universal heir Arent Willemsz., his son from his first marriage, and his children by his present wife Giert Jans (Anna, Jan, and Hessel). He named as executors Jasper Caltschuyr and Pieter Dircxsz. Breevelt, wine dealers (NA 5B, fol. 144vo, Not. Pilorius, Extracten). On Breevelt or Brevliet, see below. On 15 May 1607, the inventory of Griet Jans, widow of Willem Arentsz., was taken, several of the art works in which could be matched with art works in the present sale. However, neither the portrait of Willem Arentsz., nor the two portraits of Arent Willemsz.,  his son by his first marriage, in the probate inventory,  appear to have been sold in the present sale. Ian van Noort, living in Utrecht, owed 45 f. to the estate (NA 36, film 50, Not. Lamberti). The late Willem Aertsz. may also  be the individual of that name who invested 900 f. in the first subscription for V.O.C. shares in 1602 (Van Dillen, Het oudste aandeelhoudersregister, p. 164). On 9 June 1615, Pieter Dircksz. Brevliet was appointed by the masters of the Orphan Chamber in place of Caspar Calschuer, vermits sijn impotentie, as guardian over the children of Willem Arentsz., wine merchant, together with Mr. Adriaen Muller, advocaet (WK 5073/513, fol. 152). Pieter Dircksz. Brevliet, wine dealer, was the brother-in-law of the printmaker  Jan Hermansz. Muller, who in turn was the brother of the attorney Adriaen Muller. (On Pieter Brevliet, see INVNO 818 (R 722 of Montias1)). Part of the proceeds of the present sale were paid to Dirck Jacobsz. Heijn, who was also a wine dealer. He was the guardian of the children of the wine dealer Marten Spil (see the NOTES to R 31708 of Montias2). On 29 April 1625, the Orphan Chamber named Cornelis Dirxsz. Cool as guardian over the children of Willem Aertsz. wine merchant (WK 5073/513, fol. 33). On Cornelis Dirxsz. Cool, see the NOTES to R 32237 of Montias2.    The son Arent Willemsz., who was a buyer at auction (R 31315 of Montias2), was also a wine dealer. He  was embroiled in a dispute with the wine dealer Isaack van Gherven on 25 May 1612 (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven R.G.P. 78(1933), p. 8).
Intro Text: Opten 16e january 1607 zyn ter ordonnantie van de weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Willem Aertsz. wijncooper. Postscript: Is verthoont hier van quitans daer boven de 237 f. 4 st. 12 pen. by de soon Arent Willemsz. Hy heeft betaelt Dirck Jacobsz. Heyn een gulden 5 st. 10 pen. in dato 17 november 1608.

Biographical Notes: Isaack Verbeeck (I), merchant, born in Antwerp, was the son of Aert Verbeeck, likewise from Antwerp. Isaack was first noted in Amsterdam in 1600 (Gelderblom, Zuid-Nederlandse kooplieden, p. 316). He invested 1000 f. in the first subscription for V.O.C. shares in 1602. Aert Verbeeck and his family lived for some time in Bremen after leaving Antwerp (Van Dillen, Het oudste aandeelhoudersregister, pp. 229 and 238). Isaack Verbeecq's inventory, in addition to the items listed in Montias2, included a lute, sold for 16 f., a vioolon for f 5: 5:--. and a viool for f 2: 6:--. It also included  a stone for rubbing colors and sacks and boxes containing ashes and colors, which suggests he   may have been an amateur artist. Note also that Isaack Verbeeck collected naturalia and East Indian exotic objects (some of which are listed in the inventory). Isaack Verbeeck was the brother of Abraham Aertsz. Verbeeck (cited in the NOTES to R 36982), of Jacques Verbeeck (of R 31364), of Susanna Verbeeck (who married David Joosten), of Tanneken Verbeeck (married to Adam Bessel de oude, the father of Adam Bessel de jonge of R 35041 of Montias2),  of Margerite Verbeeck (married to Cornelis de Meyer of R 31367 of Montias2) and, in view of the following deposition, of Annetge Verbeeck.  On 12 August 1634, Maximiliaen van Geel, 69, testified at the request of Annetge Verbeeck, and of Marten Gerritsz., married to Susannetgen Verbeeck, concerning their claims on the inheritance from Adriaentge Blocx, widow of Adriaen Verbeeck (NA 694B, film 4980, Not. J. Warnaerts). The connection of the Verbeeck family with Maximiliaen van Geel emerges from the NOTES to R 31364, Maximiliaen van Geel was the son of Hans van Geel I and the brother of Catharina Jans van Geel who married Jacques Verbeeck in 1602. Susanna Verbeeck may have remarried with Marten Gerritsz. Isaack Verbeeck II may have been the son of Isaack Verbeeck I. In any case, he was the father and guardian of Joost Verbeeck, whom he apprenticed to Cristoffel Crist for 4 1/2 years (NA 478, fol. 149).
Intro Text: Opten 27e february 1608 zyn ter ordonnantie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Isaack Verbeecq. Postscript: De suyvere penningen ... betaelt aen Cornelis de Meyer de jonge. Expenses: Salaris, 139 f. 10 st.; tot hier toe [...] dagen en 3 persoonen, f. 18; voor de tafel, f. 1:16:--; oproepen, 6 st.

Biographical Notes: Jan Jacobsz. Lons, born in 1567, was found drowned by Arent Bouwers Spijker (cited in the TEXT of R 594) in the N.Z. Achterburchwal on 16 March 1608. He was the son of Jacob Jansz. Lons or Lonsvaerder (freighter to London), port master in 1578, who died of a wound he suffered on 13 November 1581. His mother was Wijburch Claes Gaeff, the daughter of Claes Claesz. Gaeff (cited in the NOTES to R 22127 of Montias2). She remarried Jan Karstensz., who was indeed the stepfather of the children.  Jan Jacobsz. married Neeltge Croon of INVNO 553 in December 1600 (Elias, Vroedschap pp. 153-4). Among the goods left by Jan Jacobsz. Lons were various items of tinsmith equipment.
Intro Text: Op den 25 april [1608] zyn ter ordonnantie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Jan Jacobsz. Lons. Postscript: Betaelt aen Jan Karstensz. de kinderen stiefbestevader (signs Jan Karstensz.)

Biographical Notes: The religion of the late Aecht Jacobs is inferred from the presence of a Lutheran Bible in the inventory.
Intro Text: Opten 23en decembris 1605 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Aecht Jacobs. Posscript: De suyvere penningen... betaelt aen Aussuerus Blocklandt.

Additional Names: and his wife Anne Claes
Biographical Notes: On 10 January 1606, Gerrit Cornelis Coppesz. (?) was named guardian over the son of Jan Braems, wine merchant,  and Anna Claesdr. (WK 5073/513, fol. 125). Pieter Brames (or Braems) who bought several lots at the sale may have been the son or brother of Jan Brames. He was a wine seller who delivered wine to the city and paid a tax of 25 f. in 1585 (Van Dillen, Amsterdam, p. 20). On Pieter Brames, see also R 31430 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Opten 9en february 1606 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Jan Brames ende Anne Claes syn huysvrou. Postcript: de penningen ... betaelt aen Gerrit Cornelis Cobbesz. als byde quitancie blyckt.

Residence: Op de hoeck van de Kapelsteech opt Water in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: The soap boiler Bartholomeus Florisz. was the son of Floris Gerritsz. and of Cornelisgen Alberts and the brother of Jacob Floris of R 31446 of Montias2.  His sister Neeltjen Floris married the engraver Claes Jansz. Visscher of R 22512 of Montias2. He  freighted 3 ships between 1591 and 1602 (IJzerman, Economisch-historisch Jaarboek 17(1931), p. 269. On 6 March 1602, Barthelemeus Florissen, merchant in Amsterdam, freighted a ship for himself and for his company, de rato.  On 22 March 1603, he freighted a ship in partnership with Marten Corsen. (Winkelman, Bronnen voor de geschiedenis van het Oostzeehandel  R.G.P. 184(1983), pp. 67 and 120).
Intro Text: Opten 18en aprilis 1606 zijn ter ordonnantie van de heeren weesmeesteren ende onder versoeck van inventaris vercoft de naevolgende goederen achtergelaten by Bartholomeus Florisz. seepsijder.

Additional Names: widow of Lambert Jansz. steenhower
Biographical Notes: Lambert Jansz., the late husband of Tanneken Lamberts, was a stone sculptor or carver.
Intro Text: Ten selven dage [6 marty 1603] ende ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren syn vercoft de naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Tanneken Louris weduwe van Lambert Jansz. steenhower.

Additional Names: and his wife Anne van der Bergh
Biographical Notes: In a deposition dated 1 July 1593, Nicolas Bierstet and Pieter Pouille declared that Jacques Motte had arrived in Amsterdam about 10 days earlier but that he had left town again without satisfying his creditors (Winkelman, Bronnen voor de geschiedenis van het Oostzeehandel R.G.P. 178(1981), p. 330.) Between 1595 and 1599,  he was noted as a maeckelaer van de wissel, that is, a broker in transactions concerning letters of credit (ibid. pp. 186 and 194). He was 30 years old and engaged in that occupation when he made a declaration concerning the exchange rate in trade with Dantzig at the request of Cornelis Pietersz. Hooft (Winkelman, op.cit. 178(181), p. 386).  He was already married in 1592, when his wife was mentioned in connection with some goods belonging to her and her husband which had been sequestered for non-payment of debts (ibid. p. 329). On 18 January 1600, Jaques Motte and Anna Mote had their son Salomon baptized in the N.K. in the presence of Salomon le Merre (DTB 38/781). On 2 April 1603, Isaack van Berghen, the uncle of the children of Jacques Motte and Anna van Berghen, was appointed guardian over these children,  together with Passchier Huer (of R 26991 of Montias2).  On 22 September 1611, David Motte, also an uncle of the children, replaced Isaack van Berghen as guardian (WK 5073/513). Four days after the present sale, on 12 April 1603, some goods, including jewelry, were sold at the request of Paschier Huer (on whom see the NOTES to R 20353 of Montias2). Some of the jewelry was bought by Isaack van den Bergh. It is probable that these goods also belonged to Jacques Motte and Anna van der Bergh. Jacques Motte may be identical with the maeckelaer Moote cited in 1601 (Thys Arch. 112A). Pierre (Pieter) Mote, at whose request an Orphan Chamber sale was held on 16 July 1609, was most probably a close relative of Jacques Motte.
Intro Text: Opten 8en aprilis 1603 syn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Jacques Motte ende Anne van der Bergh zyn huysvrouw.

Additional Names: and his wife Mary Thomasdr.
Intro Text: Opten 24en aprilis 1603 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren meesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Dirck Jacobsz. ende Mary Thomasdr.

Additional Names: widow of Jacob Romboutsz.
Biographical Notes: Errem Jans was buried on 3 September 1602 (DTB 1052/210). Jacob Rombouts, who died before 1602, is not mentioned in the tax book of 1585 (Van Dillen, Amsterdam in 1585). It is possible but by no means certain that he was the father of Rombout Jacobsz. I (1550-1629), the father of Pieter Jacobsz. Indische Raven I of INVNO 666. He may also have been the brother of Willem Rombouts, married to Catharina Reygers, who was the father of Hans Rombouts of INVNO 200.
Intro Text: Op den 3e may anno 1603 zyn ter ordonnantie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Erm Jans weduwe van wijlen Jacob Romboutsz.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Sibbel Everts, widow of Dirck Thymensz.
Biographical Notes: Dirck Tijmensz. Cortenhoeff was a brewer on the Rockin in't Duyfgen, behind the old Weeshuis. He was buried on 20 September 1595. His widow Sibille Evertsdr. Brenart was the daughter of Evert Reynertsz. Brenart and of Remerich Claesdr. Dirck Tijmensz. was captain of the militia in 1578 and Regent of the Oude Mannen- en Vrouwenhuis in 1589 (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 204). He paid a tax of 20 f. in 1585, living on the Rockin. He had acquired the poorterschap of Amsterdam in 1589 (Van Dillen, Amsterdam, p. 162.)
Intro Text: Op den lesten january 1598 ten versoucke van Sibbel Everts de weduwe van Dirck Thymensz. int Duyffken syn vercoft de naervolgende goederen.

Residence: In de St. Jansstraet in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: The late Neel Visch was an uitdraagster. She was the sister of Garbrant Visch, whose daughter Mary Garbrants was also apparently an uitdraagster (R 31527).
Intro Text: Op den 25e may 1603 syn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren deser stede vercoft de naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Neel Visch in haer leven uijtdraegster.

Biographical Notes: The late Neel Gerritsdr., alias Neel Ruslandt, was an uitdraagster who probably lived in 't Ruslandt. Her husband's name, as appears from the inventory, was Herman Thysz. An individual named Herman Thijsz., living on the Ooster Achterburchwal, paid a tax of 2 f. in 1585 (Van Dillen, Amsterdam, p. 117.) Neel Gerritsdr., alias Ruslandt, had also been a buyer at auction (R 37962).
Intro Text: Op den 26en ende 27en september anno 1602 syn ter ordonnantie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Neel Gerritsdr. alias Neel Ruslandt uijtdragster.
Op den lesten decembris anno 1602 zyn ter ordonnantie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft het naervolgende goed achtergelaten by Lambert Pietersz.  Swartenhont seylmacker ende zyn huysvrou.
Op den 1e octobris zyn ten versoeck van de erffgenamen van Nes int Aegge vercocht de goederen achtergelaten by Nes int Aegge.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Mary Otmoedich
Biographical Notes: Mary Ootmoedich, at whose request the goods were sold, was probably an uitdraagster (see R 24982 of Montias2).
Intro Text: Op den 17en november anno 97 syn ten versoecke van Mary Ootmoedich vercoft de volgende goederen

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Joost Hermansz.
Biographical Notes: Joost Hermansz., at whose request the goods were sold, may be the baker of that name who paid a tax of 1 f. in 1585. He lived on the Achterburchwal at the corner of the Gasthuissteech (Van Dillen, Amsterdam in 1585, p. 175).
Intro Text: Op den 18en february 1598 zyn ten versoecke van Joost Hermansz. vercoft ... op zes weecken dach.
Op den 20e february 1598 syn ten bevele van mijne heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen naegelate by Dirck Willemsz. Sparreboom.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Jan Bara
Biographical Notes: Anne Moerenturffs is probably identical with Tanneken Moerenturf, the mother of Valerius, Felix, Govert, and Alexander van der Hoeve (of R 20019, 31605, 22969, and 20896 of Montias2 resp.) (Tanneken van Moerenturf was married to Govert van der Hoeve (or Hove)). The fact that Felix van der Hoeve bought art  at the present sale supports the presumption of the family relation. Jan Bara may be the engraver Johan Barra, the brother of the physician Jacobus Barra, who married Margarit Tulkschaep in 1621 (Oud Holland, 3(1885), p. 60). For a deposition of Dr. Jacobus Barra, see R 39404 of Montias2. The Moerenturff family was from Antwerp. Catharina Moerentorff, the widow of the engraver Theodore Galle, may also have been a relative of Anne Moerenturff (for her death inventory, see Duverger, Antwerpse inventarisse 4(1989), pp. 18-23).
Intro Text: Den 5 marty 1598 syn ten versoucke van Jan Bara vercoft de navolgende goederen achtergelaten by Anne Moerenturffs tot behoef van haer kinderen op zes weken.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Pieter Ovrentsz. (?), alias Pieter Oom.
Intro Text: Op den xxvi marty syn ten versoecke van Pieter Ovrentsz. (?) alias Pieter Oom in den huyse van den Taeffel van Leeningh binnen dese stede vercoft de naevolgende goederen op zes weecken.

Residence: Op de O.Z. Burchwal by de Nysels brugge in Amsterdam.
Biographical Notes: Remburch Fransdr. was the daughter of Frans van Campen Jacobsz. and of Trijn Hillebrants den Otter (buried in August 1556). Remburch was buried in the N.K. on 5 April 1595. She was married to Gerrit Heuszenz., grain dealer op 't Water in den Otter. They were the parents of Hillebrant Gerritsz. den Otter who married Giertge Ysbrants Hem (see the NOTES to R 28963 of Montias2 and Elias, Vroedschap van Amsterdam, p. 87).
Intro Text: Den 27e april 1598 zyn vercocht op de Oudesyde Burchwal by de Nysels brugge de naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Reymbrich Fransdr. ende dat ten behoeven van haer erffgenamen op zes weecken dagh.

Biographical Notes: Huybrecht Gillisz. (I) was a goldsmith. He may have been the father or the uncle of Huybrecht Gillisz. (II), likewise goldsmith, the brother of Catlyn Gillis, the husband of Gerrit Velthuysen, goldsmith (WK 5073/789, 27 March 1631).
Intro Text: Op den 1e augustij anno 1598 zyn ter ordonnantie van de heeren weesmeesteren deser stede vercoft de naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Hubrecht Gillisz. goutsmit.

Additional Names: goods sold at the request of Hans van Hanswyck
Residence: Int Nayersse in de Warmoesstraet in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Jacques van Hanswyck I,  originally from Antwerp, paid a tax of 4 gulden in 1585, living on the St. Annenstraet in Amsterdam  (Van Dillen, Amsterdam, p. 26.). He was a shareholder in the expedition of Jacob Cornelisz. van Neck to the East Indies in 1598 (C. Romburch et al. Beredeneerd Register op de Werken der Linschoten-Vereeniging, p. 271). Since Jacques van Hanswyck had died by the date of this inventory, it must have been his nephew  Jacques van Hanswyck de jonge (the son of Hans van Hanswyjck)  who invested 7500 f. in the first subscription to V.O.C. shares. Hans and Jacques van Hanswyck (II) had an account at the Wisselbank of 1 folio in 1612 and 2 folios in 1615 (Van Dillen, Het oudste aandeelhoudersregister, p. 170. Van Dillen confutes the father and the son.) This inventory was followed by two smaller inventories, both drawn up at the request of Hans van Hanswyck: the first of the goods of Leijntge van Hanswyck (total, 260 f., including 4 bortges bought by Jan Jansz. Beusemacker for 1 f.), the second of the goods belonging to Anneke van Hanswyck (total 196 f. 14 st., no works of art). Leijntge and Anneke were presumably sisters of Jacques I  and Hans van Hanswyck. The death inventory of Jacob van Hanswijck II, dated 27 January 1639, contained, along with many other paintings (without attributions), two portraits of Hans van Hanswijck and of Erm Claes, who were presumably his uncle and aunt. The inventory was made at the request of Hercules Roch, Jacob Roch and Hendrick Lens (NA 840, film 567, Not. Hoogenboom). On 15 November 1617, Carlo van Heldewier, Isaacq Coymans, and Adriaen van Nieulandt made a deposition at the request of Daniel van Gele (Geel) (of R 31393? of Montias2) concerning two paintings by Henrick van Steenwijck, presently in London, being two paintings (on copper) in perspective, one by day and one by night, which Daniel van Geel had bought from the Antwerp art dealer Anthony Goetkint. The transaction had been effected in the house of Jacques van Hanswyck (II) (Bredius, Künstler-inventare, p.167n.) Anthony Goetkint was active in the Antwerp and Paris markets. In 1630, the painters Adriaen van Stalbemt and Jacques Jordaens testified at his request before an Antwerp notary  that he, Goetkint, had gone to France with his stock of paintings before the prohibition to carry on correspondence with France had been issued (Duverger, Antwerpse kunstinventarissen 4(1989), p.14.) Goetkint's sister Sara was married to the painter Abraham Janssens (ibid. p. 135).
Intro Text: Den vierden, 5en, 6en february 1599 syn ten versoucke van Mr. Hans van Hanswyck vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Jacques van Hanswyck syn broeder en syn [zal. ?] huysvrou.

Residence: Op 't Rokin in Arnhem in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 26e aprilis 1600 zyn ten versoecke van Claes Cornelisz. van Arnhem vercoft de naervolgende goederen op zes weecken.

Additional Names: late wife of Gerrit Thomasz. Rooseboom
Residence: Achterburchwal omtrent de Heyberch in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Gerrit Thomasz. Rooseboom (or Roseboom), was born in 1568 and buried in Amsterdam on 6 May 1644. In 1597, he was clerk of the Secretary of Amsterdam, in 1601 he became Secretary. He lived on the Singel. He married Barbara Jansdr., born in Brussels and living in Leiden, on 12 April 1597. After her death, he remarried with Jacomijntge Lam in 1602. A daughter from this second marriage, named Emerentia, married Jacomo Pauw (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 202.)
