Intro Text: Den 7en juny 1600 syn ter ordonnantie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Barbara Jans in haer leven huysvrou van Gerrit Thomasz. Rooseboom.

Residence: By de Cleuveniersdoelen aen de Osse in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Gerrit Evertsz. was master of the fabrica of the city, which may mean that he was an architect.
Intro Text: Den 13en february syn ter ordonnantie van de heeren weesmeesteren dese stede vercoft die naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Gerrit Evertsz. in zyn leven fabryckmeester desen stede Amsterdam.

Additional Names: and his wife Maria Koeymans (Coeymans)
Residence: In de Fortuijn in de Warmoesstraet in Amsterdam.
Biographical Notes: Hans van Gheel (or Geel) I  was born in Antwerp (Gelderblom, Zuid-Nederlandse kooplieden, p. 301). He seems to have been the brother of Daniel van Gheel I who fled in Antwerp in or about 1585 to settle in Amsterdam (see the NOTES to R 31393 of Montias2).   He was  an important merchant (dealing in cloth, cannons and other goods),  who did business with the Near East and Italy. He was married to Maria Koeymans (Coymans or Coeymans), who was also from Antwerp. She was the daughter of Jeronimus Coymans I and Constantia Spinelli.  Maria Koeymans (or Coeymans) was the sister of Jasper Coeymans I of R 31693 of Montias2, who bought lots at the present auction.  On 17 November 1598, Hans van Geel and Maria Coymans had their daughter Maria baptized in the N.K. in the presence of Balthasar Symons and Clara Schurmans (DTB 38/367). The family name of Balthasar Symons was probably Appelman. His daughter Aeltge married Geurt Dircksz. van Beuningen, the father of Dirck Geurtsz. of R 21904. Clara Schurmans was the wife of Hans van Geel's son Maximiliaen. In their testament of 15 September 1599, Hans and Maria left 500 f. to the poor of the Nederlandsche-Duitsch Kerck and 200 f. to the Waalsche community. He paid a tax of 30 f. in 1585, at which time he lived on the East side of the Kerckstraet (Van Dillen, Amsterdam, p. 25). Hans van Geel I's daughter Catharina married Jacques Verbeeck of INVNO 544. After the death of Hans van Geel I, an inventory of his possessions owned in common with Maria Coeymans was taken on 27 March 1600 (NAA 20E/38, not. Salomon Henrix). On 16 January 1618, the children and heirs of Hans van Geel put up for sale the house de Fortuyn or Sandloper in the Warmoesstraet. The neighbors were the heirs of Jacob Gerritsz. Romeyn on the South side. The buyer for f. 4610 was the silk dealer Jacob (de) Bye, the sureties Alexander van der Hoeve (of R 20986) and Laurens Charles (of R 20464). On 7 May, Daniel and Jan van Geel (II), for themselves and as empowered by Leonard Sweerts, husband of Constantia van Geel transferred the deed of the house (kwitscheldte) to Jacob de Bye (Kam, Waar dat huis in de Warmoessraat?). In 1631, the widow of Jacques de Bye, living in the Warmoesstraet, paid a tax of 15 f. (Kohier fol. 172, p. 40).  One son of Hans van Geel,  Jan or Hans van Geel II, of R 37007, just cited, born in 1589, became director of the W.I. Company in 1636. He was associated in a firm with his brother  Daniel van van Gheel (II). He married Elisabeth Lampsins on 5 September 1623 (Elias, Vroedschap, pp. 975-6). On 16 April 1628, Jean van Geel and Elisabeth Lampsins had their son Daniel baptized in the N.K. (DTB 40/447).
Intro Text: Den 15e february ende 16e, 17e, 19e, 1601 zyn vercoft de naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Hans van Gheel ende Maria Koeymans in de Fortuijn in de Warmoesstraet.

Additional Names: and his wife Claesie Jacobs
Residence: Op de Cingel buyten de Gasthuijs ... poort in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Den 9en marty 1601 zyn ter ordonnantie van de heeren meesteren vercoft de naevolgende goederen achtergelaten by Capiteyn Harmen Michielsz. ende Claesie Jacobs. ... zes weecken.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Mary Andries
Residence: In St. Jansstraet tot Mary Andries in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Mary Andries was one of the buyers at the Hans van Gheel sale, which had taken place two months earlier (R 37979 of Montias2). According to Hilde van Wijngaarden, she was an uitdraagster (notes to Scriptie). For another sale held at her request, see INVNO 2007.
Intro Text: Ten selven dage [3 April 1601] opt versouck van Mary Andries vercoft op zes weecken etc..

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Jan Poppen
Residence: Opt Zeedijck in de Gulden Steur in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Jan Poppen, who indeed lived in de Gulden Steur in the Warmoesstraet in 1601, was born in the Land of Steur (in Holstein) c. 1545. He was buried in Amsterdam on 7 August 1616. In 1579, he was said to be a merchant. In 1594, he was one of the founders of the Compagnie van Verre (which sent ships to India). In 1602, he was one of the first directors of the V.O.C. He laid the basis of the fortune of Jacob Poppen (INVNO 292). He married 1) Baert Jansdr. and 2) Lijsbeth Pieters, born in 1544,  a diaconesse of the Nederlandse Hervoormde Gemeente (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 286). He invested 12,000 f. in the first subscription for shares in the V.O.C. (Van Dillen, Het oudste aandeelhoudersregister, p. 108). He freighted 3 ships between 1591 and 1602 (IJzerman, Economisch-historisch Jaarboek 17(1931), p. 271). He was the uncle of Michiel Poppe(n) of R 7674.
Intro Text: Op den 5e april 1601 zyn ten versoecke van Jan Poppen vercoft 't naervolgende goed op zes weecken dach.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Rutgert Jansz. van Dorssen
Biographical Notes: The individual at whose request the goods in this sale were auctioned may be identical with Rutgert Jansz., whose widow Femmetge Theunis was the sister-in-law of the painter Barent Teunis (R 842 of Montias2).
Intro Text: Den 12en Aprilis anno 1601 zyn ten versoecke van Rutgert Jansz. van Dorssen vercoft 't naervolgende goet op zes weecken dagh.

Additional Names: widow of brewer
Intro Text: Den 17e aprilis anno 1601 syn ten versoeck van Benichtgen Bruynen weduwe van den brouwer vercoft de naervolgende goederen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Willem Willemsz.
Biographical Notes: Willem Willemsz., at whose request the goods were sold, may have been the father of Baartje Willems, who was betrothed to Niclaes Rauwart Jacobszoon on 16 July 1604. She was said to be living op 't Water, which would be consistent with the address of the sale above (Damsluijs) (DTB 665/357). Willem Willemsz., who took on the name of Van Beynsdorp, was a soap boiler in den Hamer. He was the most prominent zeepsieder in Amsterdam in his time. He paid a tax of 20 f. in 1585. He died in 1626. (Van Dillen, Amsterdam, p. 120).
Intro Text: Ten selven dagh [7e augusti anno 1601] opt versoeck van Willem Willemsz. vercocht 't naervolgende goed.

Additional Names: and his wife Anna Claes
Residence: Achterburchwal by de Heypoort (?) in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 2 December 1590, Elbert Jacobsz. and Anne Claes had their son baptized in the N.K. (DTB 38/170). On 3 October 1592, they baptized Ytge (DTB 38/263). On 13 September 1594, Elbert Jacobs schipper and Anne Claes had their son Jacob baptized in the N.K. (DTB 38/264). Elbert Jacobsz. was the skipper of a boat.
Intro Text: Den 16e augusty anno 1601 ter ordonnantie van de heeren weesmeesteren zyn vercocht 't naevolgende goet op zes weecken dach achtergelaten by Elbert Jacobsz. ende Anna Claes in twee ontbeg. (?)

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Frans Claesz.
Residence: Op de Oude Singel by de Gasthuyspoort in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Frans Claesz. may possibly be the son of the painter Claes Eewoutsz. of R 29021 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Op den 23en augusti syn ten versoeck van Frans Claesz. vercoft 't naevolgende goet.

Residence: In de Stad Napels op de O.Z. Achterburchwal in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 25en en 26en octobris 1601 ten ter odronnantie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Jonghe Jan Pot ende [...] (left blank) syn huysvrouw ten behoeve van haere achtergelaten kinderen.

Additional Names: and his wife Mary Claesdr.
Residence: Aen de oude Cingel in de oude Tobias by Nieuwe Haarlemmmersluijs in Amsterdam.
Biographical Notes: Cornelis Jacobsz. Zeeuw was probably the brother of Jacob Jacobsz. Zeeuw who married Lijsbeth Gerritsdr. Southolm in 1601 (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 312) as well as of Jan Jacobsz. Zeeuw (of R 31937 of Montias2).
Intro Text: Op den xe, xiie december anno 1601 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de naevolgende goederen achtergelaten by Cornelis Jacobsz. Zeeuw ende Mary Claesdr. zyn huysvrouw.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Claes Henrixsz.
Biographical Notes: The seller may be the dyer Claes Hendricksz. of R 7667 of Montias2 who was said to be 40 years old in 1620.
Intro Text: Den 15e december anno 1601 ten versoecke van Claes Henrixsz. vercoft 't gene volcht.

Residence: Aen de ouwe Cingel opt hoeckge van de Nes legewech in Amsterdam.
Biographical Notes: On 1 November 1601, the Orphan Chamber named as guardians over Jannetge, the daughter left by Mr. Thomas van Elder, goutsmeerder (goldsmith melting gold?),  whose mother was Hilletge van de Voort, Pieter Segers and as his co-guardians Hendrick Verstegen and Hans van Ceulen.  Thomas van Elder had apparently remarried with Hester Singemans, who was said to be his widow. As creditors of Thomas van Elder were named Gerrit van de Voort, for himself and on behalf of Adam van Steene, the uncle by marriage of the child, Pieter van Dilsen, as her granduncle  on the father's side, Hans van Keulen, Huybert Otsen Willelaers, and Elder's widow Hester Singemans, assisted by her brother Pontiaen Singemans (WK 5073/513, fol. 103vo.) Pieter Zegersz. was the former bode of the Weeskamer, discharged qua Roman Catholic in 1578. He was married to Barbara Jacobs and was the father of the painters Pieter and Claes Lastman (cf. R 31152.) On 23 March 1604, Dirck Jacobsz. Hem, goldsmith, was named guardian over the children of Thomas van Elder, goutsmeerder (WK 5073/513, fol. 117vo.)
Intro Text: Den 24e en 25e january anno 1602 zyn ter ordonnantie van myne herren weesmeesteren opt versoeck van Pieter Zegers ende als geordonneerde curateur van den boel van Mr. Thomas van Elder vercoft de naevolgende goederen achtergelaten by den selven Mr. Thomas op zes weecken dach. herr

Biographical Notes: On 12 June 1626, Heyndrick Coenen, the neve by marriage of Anna, 1 1/2 years old, the daughter left by Jan Harmansz. Spagnaert, shoemaker, appeared on her behalf before the Orphan Chamber (WK 5073/789).
Intro Text: Op den 11 marty 1625 zijn vercocht de naergelaten goederen van Jan Harmensen Spangniaert schoenmacker

Additional Names: goods sold at the request of Henrickgen Adriaens
Intro Text: Ten selven dach [3e marty 1602] opt versoecke van Henrickgen Adriaens vercoft.

Residence: Opt hoeck vande Liesdel in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 13 aprilis anno 1602 zyn ter ordonnantie van my heeren weesmeesteren vercoft 't naervolgende goed ... achtergelaten by Dieuwer Pieters.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Daniel Bloemaert
Biographical Notes: The merchant Daniel Bloemaert, born in Antwerp, lived in de 3 valcken on the Fluwele (O.Z.) Voorburchwal. He was also a buyer at auction. For additional information, see the NOTES to R 28410 in Montias2.
Intro Text: Op den 11 marty anno 1602 syn ten versoecke van Daniel Bloemaert vercoft 't naervolgende goed.

Biographical Notes: On Pouwels and Jasper Jansz., see the NOTES to R 31974 of Montias2
Intro Text: Op den 13e augusty 1602 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Pouwels Jansz. ten behoeve van zyn erffgenamen.

Additional Names: and his wife Geertje Pieters
Biographical Notes: Roeland Dircxsz., the guardian of the children of Jan Pietersz. and Geertje Pieters, was a goldsmith.
Intro Text: Den 20e Augustj anno 1602 zyn ter ordonnancie van myn heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Jan Pietersz. ende Geertje Pieters syn huysvrouw. Postscript: De suyvere penningen ... betaelt aen Roelant Dirxsz. goutsmit oom van 't kint die deselve renten heeft genomen volgende de weesmeesters kennisse.
Op den 22e augusty syn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Machtelt Cornelisdr.

Additional Names: wife of Reijnier Harckes
Residence: Op de Heeregracht bij de Nieuwe Hey Brug in Amsterdam.
Biographical Notes: On 12 May 1612, Reynier Harckes, from Loppersum in Groenewegen, kistemacker (coffin maker, joiner),  was betrothed to Griet Jans, widow of Pieter Thijsz. (2 years) (DTB 667/19). Reynier Harckes survived his wife (he bought at the sale).
Intro Text: Den 13e octobris anno 1618 zyn vercocht de goederen achtergelaten by Griet Jans de huysvrou van Reijnier Harckes.

Residence: In de Haarlemmerstraet bij de Nieuwe Hall in Amsterdam
Intro Text: opten 10e november 1618 zyn vercocht de goederen achtergelaten by Elsgen Jans.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Neel Gerrits
Biographical Notes: Neel Gerrits may be identical with the uitdraagster Neel Gerrits Ruslandt (see R 37962 of Montias2).
Intro Text: Opten 5en february 1619 zijn ten versoecke van Neel Gerrits vercocht dese naervolgende goederen.

Residence: ten huyse van Jan Dircksz. in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: The late Jacob Huych Thomasz. was named concierge in 1587. After his death in 1617, his son Thomas Jacobsz. Haringh took over his function. The concierge handled executoriale verkopingen, the sale of goods at the order of judicial authorities by reason of bankruptcy or other causes (I. van Eeghen, Jaarboek Amstelodamum, 61(1969), p. 74). Most of his goods were sold on 10 August 1617 (INVNO 889), but one valuable painting and some jewelry were sold in the present sale (One juwel met deamanten ingeset fetched 629 f.)
Intro Text: Opten 11e february zyn dese naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Jacob Huijgen conchierge vercoft.

Residence: Op de Heijlige Wech naest de verwerij van de Roos in Amsterdam.
Biographical Notes: Eghbert Jansz. was skipper of a boat (probably a barge) sailing to Rotterdam.
Intro Text: Op den 6en aprilis 1619 zyn vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Eghbert Jansz. schipper op Rotterdam.

Biographical Notes: The late owner of the goods sold, Tanneken Praeckmans, was a midwife.
Intro Text: Opten 15en aprilis 1619 zyn vercocht de goederen [crossed out: achtergelaten] van Tanneken Praeckmans vroemoeder.

Residence: Naest de brouwerije vant Lam in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 18e april anno 1619 zijn vercocht de naegelaten goederen van Catryna Garbrants

Residence: In de St. Jacobstraet in Amsterdam.
Intro Text: Op den 30 octobris 1619 zijn vercocht de naervolgende goederen van Jan Cornelisz.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Abraham van de Moer
Intro Text: [Op den 7e april 1620 zyn] ten versoecke van Abraham van de Moer vercocht dese naervolgende goederen.

Additional Names: and his wife Weintgen van Neck
Residence: Op de Keysersgracht over Groenlandtse Spijckers in Amsterdam.
Biographical Notes: Jacob Claesz. van Hoorn was a wine dealer in the Keysersgracht in Swol. He was the son of Claes Gerbrantsz. Schilt, tar dealer in the Teertuinen, and of  Trijn Jansdr. van Hoorn. He married Weijntgen van Neck on 5 August 1607. Weijntje van Neck, the daughter of Jacob van Neck, tar dealer, bought lots in the Haarlem lottery of 1606, at which time she lived on the old fortification near the Roodenpoort (GAA, 75/2 F 590). In addition to the present inventory, a list of assets and possessions of Jacob Claesz. van Hoorn and Weyntge van Neck was taken on 19 December 1624. Grietgen van Neck (Weyntge's sister) was said to be the aunt of the children, and Dirck van Neck and Zeger Pietersz. goldsmith  their neven (probably cousins). The household goods were not specified in this list inasmuch as they would be sold as soon as possible (als de selve eersten dachs zal vercoft werde ende 't gelde gemaeck) (WK 5073/968).    A daughter of Jacob Claesz.  and Weijntgen, named Lucretia van Hoorn, married the Remonstrant Mr. Johannes Wttenbogaert on 10 June 1642. Weijntgen's sister Margarieta (Grietge) was married to Jan Claesz. van Hoorn. He was said to be 53 years old in a deposition of 13 March 1619 (NA 200, film 111, Not. J.F. Bruyning).  Another brother was Jacob Claesz. Codde (alias Kod) of INVNO 646  (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 449). On 19 February 1625, Pieter Jansz. van Horen and Dirck Jochemsz. van Neck were named by the Orphan Chamber as guardians over the five children left by Jacob Claesz. and Weyntge van Neck. On 29 March 1627, Zeger Pietersz., goldsmith was named as an additional guardian (WK 5073/513, fol. 28vo.) On a procuration passed by Seger Pietersz., 56, and Dirck van Neck, 46, on behalf of the children of Jacob Claesz. van Hoorn, see the NOTES to R 32330.  Jacob Claesz. and his family were Roman Catholic. Another woman named Weyntgen van Neck was the daughter of Jan Jansz. van Neck, cloth dealer, and of Gerritgen Jans. She was said to be 8 years old in an Orphan Chamber act of 2 December 1622 (WK 5089/789).
Intro Text: Op den 20 Marty 1625 zyn vercocht dese naervolgende goederen achtergelaten bij Jacob Claesen van Hoorn ende Weijntgen van Neck ende sullen de vrunden ofte voochden vande weeskinderen de penningen selffs doen innen ende de schaden tot haere peryckel nemen, waerover zyluyden niet meer als een per cento voor salaris sullen geven. Postscript: salaris vyff percento (despite above INTRO).

Additional Names: widow of Huybrecht Hobbe
Residence: Op de Cingel by de Blauwe Burchwal in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 1 December 1607, Huijbrecht Hobbe, from Rotterdam, schrijver (bookkeeper on a ship), 32, living in Rotterdam, was betrothed to Griet Jans (Goutsbloem), from Gouda, 24, assisted by Jan Cornelisz. Goutsbloem, her father and [...] her mother (DTB 666/103). Cornelis Jansz. Goutsbloem, to whom the proceeds of the sale were to be paid, was the brother of Griet Jans. He was a merchant born about 1585 (NA 695A, film 4981, Not. J. Warnaerts).   On 19 June 1625, Cornelis Jansz. Goutsbloem appeared before the Orphan Chamber as uncle and guardian of Gerrit, 16, and Claertgen, 12, the children of Grietgen Jans, whose late father was Huybrecht Hobbe, skipper (WK 5073/789). Claertgen Arents Hobbe (whose first name was identical with that of Huijbrecht Hobbe's daughter) was probably the sister of the late Huijbrecht Hobbe. She married Sijmen Sijmenss of INVNO 146 of 2 February 1629 (who may have been Roman Catholic). Cornelis Jansz. Goutsbloem, the brother of Griet Jans, was a buyer at the sale of Gerrit Jacobsz. Bruijn, who lived in the Goutsbloem. The sale occurred on 11 December 1624 (INVNO 658, R 26740). Note that, contrary to the announcement in the INTRO of this inventory, the auctioneer of the sale collected 5 percent (not 1 percent) of the proceeds as his salary.
Intro Text: Op den 22e marty 1625 zyn vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Griet Jans weduwe van Huybrecht Hobbe, welverstande dat Cornelis Jansz. Goutsbloem haer procederende broeder de penningen van de voors. goederen selfs zal doen innen ende ontfangen, zonder dat de secretarissen ofte Gerrit Jacobsz. daer vooren vast zullen staen, te welcken regard zulcks tsamen maer 1 percento over salaris genieten.

Residence: Op de Oudezyts Voorburchwal by de St. Jans brugh in Amsterdam.
Intro Text: Op den 1en april 1625 zyn vercocht de naergelaten goederen van Neeltge Pieters. Postscript: Dese penningen heeft de man ontfangen ende daer eenige schulden afbetaelt.

Additional Names: and his wife Joosge Jans
Biographical Notes: Marten Jansz., the owner of the goods sold, was a baker.
Intro Text: Op den 2en april anno 1625 zyn vercocht de naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Marten Jansz. backer en Joosge Jans zyn huysvrou.

Additional Names: and his wife Grietgen van Dronckelaer
Biographical Notes: Sebastiaen Egbertsz., alias Sebastianus Egberti, was a professor of anatomy at the Atheneum Illustre in Amsterdam. He was a member of the Raed of Amsterdam from 1602 to 1618 and burgomaster in 1606 and 1608. He invested 900 f. in the first subscription for V.O.C. shares (Van Dillen, Het oudste aandeelhoudersregister, p. 200).  He was removed from the Raed, due to his Remonstrant sympathies, by Prins Maurits on 3 November 1618. He was born in 1563 and buried on 16 April 1621. He married 1) on 20 July 1596 Agnieta Jacobs Benningh (born in 1561) and 2) on 13 August 1606 Margriete (alias Grietge) van Dronckelaer (1583-25 November 1624), daughter of Pelgrom Cornelisz. van Dronckelaer and Reymerich Jaspers Appelman (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 258). On 26 March 1625, Bartelemeus Reael was named guardian over the children left by Sebastiaen Egbertsz. by the Guardian Chamber (WK 5073/513, fol. 32). Sebastiaen Egbertsz. left an estate of 206,000 f. (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 258).
Intro Text: Op den 3en april 1625 zyn vercocht dese naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Burgermeester Doctor Sebastiaen Egbertsen ende Grietge van Dronckelaer zyn huysvrouw.

Residence: Op de Oudezyts Burchwal over de Bierkay in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: The late Pieter Dircksen van Brevliet was a wine merchant who lived on the O.Z. Voorburchwal, near the Bierkay. He was the brother-in-law of the engraver Jan Muller. On 14 January 1619, Jan Muller, engraver (plaetsnijder).  Adriaen Muller, licentiate in law, secretary of the city of Emmerick, Pieter Dircksz. Breevliet, as husband and guardian of Lysbeth Harmans, Hillegont Harmans, assisted by Jan Valcxsz. (of R 21679), her chosen guardian in view of the absence of her husband Adriaen Hendricksz. Boot, and Maritgen Harmans, assisted by Mr. Jan Pietersz. Sem, her chosen guardian (the brother of Syvert Pietersz. Sem of R 27934), all children and heirs of Harmen Jansz. Muller, engraver of figures (figuersnijder).  declared that they had all received their portions of the inheritance. Maritge Harmans was to keep the house De Gulde Passer in the Warmoesstraet, but would have to pay the debts of the estate and give Hillegont Harmans, Johan (Jan Muller), Mr. Adriaen, and Pieter Dircksz. (Brevliet) 400 f. each. The witnesses, both journeymen engravers (plaetsnijdersgesellen), were Abraham Hendricksz. Doeckman and Hendrick (Lourensz.) Roghman (of R 21939), who were most probably apprentices of Harmen or Jan Muller (Not. L. Lamberti, cited in N. de Roever, Jan Harmensz. Muller,     Oud Holland, 3(1888), p. 270). The post-mortem inventory of Pieter Dircksz. Brevliet, wine dealer, was taken on 31 January 1625. It contained a portrait of Harmen Jansz. Muller (NA 590, film 4664). In his testament dated 11 August 1624, Jan Muller left to Dirck Pietersz., son of Pieter Dircksz. (Brevliet), his brother-in-law, all the books on art that might be useful for his studies (    Oud Holland 27(1909), p. 131).  On 2 March 1634, Claertgen Pieters, daughter of Lysbeth Mullers, 24, and  Dirck (Pietersz.)  van Brevliet (the son of Pieter Dircksz. van Brevliet), at present outside the country, children of Hillegont Millers made a declaration concerning the estate of Adriaen Muller, which was heavily fraught with debts. The honorable Cornelis Dircksz. Cool (on whom see the NOTES to R 32237 of Montias2), as husband and gurardian of their aunt Maritgen Mullers, received one fifth of the house De Vergulde Passer on the Warmoesstraet (NA 595, fol. 482/3, Not. Lamberti). Note that Notary Lamberti was related by marriage to Cornelis Cool and, through him, with the Muller family (NOTES to R 32337 of Montias2).
Intro Text: Op den 4e april anno 1625 zyn vercocht de nagelatene goederen van Pieter Dircksen van Brevliet wijncoper.

Additional Names: and his wife Catalyntje de Bock
Residence: Op den Dam op de hoeck van de Beurstraet in Amsterdam.
Biographical Notes: Samuel Coenraets was a dealer in leather goods. On 13 March 1616, Samuel Coenraets, leercoper (leather merchant), registered a notarial complaint (insinuatie) against Roelof Jansz. (of INVNO 377), shoemaker, a headman of the shoemakers guild, concerning certain fines that Coenraets was supposed to pay to the guild to be admitted into it (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven R.G.P., 78(1933),  p. 147). The coopmanschappen in the inventory consisted of raw leather and leather goods, such as jerkins and muffs. Some of the leather was bought by out-of-town dealers. Samuel Coenradsen, from Middelburgh, tailor, 30 years old, was betrothed to Neeltje Goverts, from Antwerp, 32, assisted by her nichte Susanna Joris, on 3 March 1607 (DTB 666/160.) As widower of Susanna Goverts, he was again betrothed to Cathalijntje de Bock, assisted by her mother Anneken Bozyns, on 11 March 1608 (DTB 666/117). After his death, on 18 March 1626, Symon van der Boeckhorst, the uncle of his children (of R 32252),  and Coenradt Jaspersz., the neve (probably cousin)  of these children, were named by the Orphan Chamber as guardians over them (WK 5073/513, fol. 42).
Intro Text: Op den 15en april 1625 zijn vercocht dese naervolgende goederen als coopmanschappen etc.. achtergelaten by Samuel Coenraets ende Catalyntje de Bock zyn huysvrouw.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of the widow of Hendrick van Wyningen
Residence: Ten huyse van Gerrit Jacobsz. in Amsterdam
Intro Text: uts [18 april 1625] zijn ten versoeck van de weduwe van Hendrick van Wyningen vercocht dese naervolgende goederen.

Residence: Op de Brestraet over de Zuydekerck in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Barbara Jacobs and Pieter Zegersz. were the parents of the painters Pieter and Claes Lastman who bought lots at this auction (Claes bought only household goods). Pieter Zegersz. had been named bode of the Orphan Chamber in 1572 but was removed after the Alteratie qua Roman Catholic. She became a sworn uitdraagster at least as early as 1591 and continued in the trade until her death. For details on the genealogy of Barbara Jacobs and Pieter Lastman, see the article by Dudok van Heel cited under Publication above and the NOTES to R 27873 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Op den 19e april 1625 zyn vercocht dese naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Barbara Jacobs eertyts gesworen uytdrachster dese stede.

Additional Names: widow of Michiel Ghysbertsz. Hoppesack
Residence: In de Nieuwe Hoochstraet in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 17 September 1596, Michiel Gijsbrechtsz. Hoppesack, 23 years old, living in the Warmoesstraet, assisted by his father Gysbert Michielsz., was betrothed to Lysbet Jans Veen, assisted by her father Jan Veen and her mother Machteltgen Cornelis (DTB 408/69). For further details on the family, see the notes to R 21592 in Montias2.
Intro Text: Op den 28e april anno 1625 zyn vercocht de naegelate goederen van Lysbethge Venen weduwe van Michiel Ghysbertsz. Hoppesack.

Residence: Op de Gelderse Kay by de Hooftbrugh in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 14 February 1609, Jan Hesen, from Nuijs, 30 years old, living in Keulen, was betrothed to Janneken Sybrants, widow of Nanning Heijnrixsz. Kloeck, living on the Oude Schans, assisted by her neve Schout Willem van der Does and her nichte Lysbeth Bertsdr. (DTB 414/3). On Nanning Kloeck, see R 29575 of Montias2. On Schout Willem van der Does, see R 29672 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Op den 29e april anno 1625 zyn vercocht de naergelate goederen van Jan Hesen, ende hebben de weduwe ende Willem Hesen de broeder geconsenteert dat Engel Jansz. uyt de penningen ontfangen so veel hem van huyshuyre is competerende.

Additional Names: wife of Secretaris Melchior Bouwer
Residence: Op de Keysersgracht by de Westermarckt in Amsterdam.
Biographical Notes: Trijntge Lucasdr. Rotgans was the daughter of Lucas Jacobsz. Rotgans and Weyntge van Hagen. She was betrothed to Melchior Bouwer on 11 April 1609 (DTB 414/33). He became Secretaris of Amsterdam in 1611, a post which he retained until his death in 1626. His goods were sold on 26 April 1627 (INVNO 935).  One of their daughters, named Maria, married Isaac van Gerwen (INVNO 237). Melchior's sister Maria married Syvert Pietersz. Sem of INVNO 402 in 1582. On Trijntje's father, Lucas Jacobsz. Rotgans de oude, commissioner of minor matters (Commies van kleijne sacken),  see R 24924 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Op den 10 maij anno 1625 zyn vercocht dese naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Trijntge Lucasdr. huysvrou van Secretaris Melchior Bouwer.

Residence: Op de Brestraet aende Sluijs in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On Cornelis van der Voort, see TEXT of R 463.
Intro Text: Op den 13e may anno 1625 zyn vercocht dese naervolgende schilderyen achtergelaten bij Mr. Cornelis van der Voort in zijn leven schilder.

Biographical Notes: Pieter van der Voort was very probably the  son of the painter Cornelis van der Voort and of his first wife Truytie Willems.  He lived in the Brestraet bij 't Lazarus of Leprozenhuis in the house of Rochus Witsen. His death  inventory was taken on 29 December 1624. From the subjects of unfinished paintings, we can infer that he painted portraits and still lifes (N. de Roever, Drie Amsterdamsche schilders, Oud Holland 3(1885), pp. 204-207). He should not be confused with Pieter Pietersz. van der Voort, cammenmacker, the brother of Cornelis van der Voort, born c. 1556, who married Susanna Vinckboons before 1603 (Briels, Vlaamse schilders, p. 400).
Intro Text: Op den 17e maij [crossed out: april] anno 1625 zyn ten versoeck van de erffgenamen van Pieter van der Voort vercocht dese naervolgende teeckeningen.

Additional Names: and his wife. Goods sold at request of Andries Overhagen.
Biographical Notes: On 25 April 1606, Antoine Marinus, pasteybacker (pastry baker), from Vlissingen, was betrothed to Josijntge van den Bremde, from Antwerp, 30 years old (DTB 411/736). Josijntge may have been a sister of the painter Daniel van den Bremde. In an Orphan Chamber document dated 3 July 1620, a rentebrief issued by Anthoni Mariniss, pasteybacker, for 62 f. was cited. It accrued to Meyndert the son of Egbert Claesz. Coninck (WK 5073/789).  Anthoni Marinisz. was probably a close relative of Andries Overhagen, who was married to Anna Marines, the daughter of Josijntje Marines (see R 32697 of Montias2).  Andries Overhagen (of R 32697) was a buyer of several lots at the auction of Cornelis van der Voort (INVNO 825). He paid a tax of 10 f. voor de erffenis in 1631, at which time he lived on the Appelmarckt (Kohier, fol. 261, p. 60). On 31 December 1617, Anthony Marinisz. and Josijne van den Bremde had a child baptized in the O.K. in the presence of Abraham de Decker, Guillam Michielsz., and Catlijntje van Doesburgh (DTB 5/236). Abraham de Decker (of R 33003) bought lots at this sale. He was then said to be a relative (vrund) of the deceased. Catlijntje (Catharina) van Doesburgh was apparently the widow of Govert Jacobsz. (ex Bastiaensz), hides dealer (huydecooper),  with whom she had five children (WK 5073/789 of 16 December 1627) (See also R 34728 of Montias2).
Intro Text: Op den 13 junij soo syn ten versoecke van Andries Overhagen de naervolgende goederen. [10 folios further, some goods were assessed with the following introduction] Op den 12e junij soo syn uijtten sterfhuyse van zal. Anthoni Marinisz. ende zyn huysvrouw geschat voor Andries Overhagen de naervolgende goederen. The total (2634 f. 11 st. 8 pen.) appears to include the goods sold at auction.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Daniel du Gardyn and Daniel Sohijer
Residence: Op de Ooster marckt in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Hester de Wary has not been identified. If her name, as seems likely, was de Wery, she was probably related to Daniel (de) Wery of R 29386 of Montias2.  The custodian of her estate, Daniel du Gardijn, was a witness at the baptism of Nicolaas, son of the painter Nicolaas Elias (Pickenoy) on 2 February 1633 (Oud Holland, 3(1885), p. 142). He was a merchant-investor in the Buitenvelderste polder (see the NOTES to R 26643 of Montias2). He was a regent of the Waalsweeshuis in 1637. He married Marguerite Balestel in 1597 and Marie Reynst in 1626 (Jaarboek C.B.G. 19(1965), p. 164).   The other custodian, Daniel Sohier, at whose request the inventory was drawn up,  was related to Nicolaas Sohier of INVNO 232. He was a merchant, first noted in Amsterdam in 1620 (Gelderblom, Zuid-Nederlandse kooplieden p. 314).
Intro Text: [op den viii junij 1625 zyn vercocht ten versoecke van] Daniel du Gardyn ende Daniel Sohijer als cur[ateur]s over de boel van Hester de Wary weduwe.

Additional Names: wife of Stants Jacobsz.
Biographical Notes: On 16 May 1609, Stans Jacobsz., widower of Cornelisje Jans, living in the Gravenstraet, was betrothed to Jannetje Thomas, widow of Claes Tomasz., living in the Haringpackerijen (as in the above address), assisted by her mother Mary Pieters (DTB 666/177). On 14 September 1628, Stants Jacobsz., from Amsterdam, widower of Jannetje Thomas Sillinghs,  living in the Keisersgracht, was betrothed to Tietje Pieters, 43, from Amsterdam (DTB 671/85).
Intro Text: Op den 11e july anno 1625 zyn vercocht de naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Jannetgen Thomas huysvrou van Stants Jacobsz.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of widow of Hans van Dorp
Residence: Op de Cingel over de Appelmarct in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: The notary Willem Cluyt paid a tax of 80 f. for the widow of Hans van Dorp, living on the Cingel, in 1631 (Kohier, fol. 62vo., p. 15.)
Intro Text: Op den 21 marti 1626 zyn ten versoecke van de weduwe van Hans van Dorp vercocht dese naervolgende goederen. [The sale does not include the jewelry which were sold at the house of Jan Dircksen (van Beuningen) on 28 March 1626.]

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Marrj Hendrickx
Biographical Notes: Marrij Hendricx, at whose request the goods were sold, may be identical with the woman of that name who had some goods sold in 1611. One or the other or both may have been uitdraagsters (Hilde van Wijngaarden, notes to scriptie.)
Intro Text: Den 12e marty 1630 zijn ten versoecke van Marrj Hendrickx vercocht dese naervolgende goederen te betalen etc..

Additional Names: paintings, prints etc.. sold by Pieter Jacobsz. Indische Raven
Biographical Notes: On 12 March 1637, Daniel Mijtens, who was acting as agent for Thomas Howard, Earl of Arundel, reported to the earl's secretary that the auction or outcry of Jan Basse in Amsterdam had begun. He opined, however, that, although there was a large number of prints and drawings in the sale, there were verie fewe pictures, not for my Lordes turne (cited by Jaap van der Veen in Burlington Magazine, March 2004). This is the only contemporary comment on an Amsterdam sale that has come to light. Jan Basse de Oude, from Rijssel (Lille), 43 years old, assisted by Guiljam Basse (I), his father, was betrothed on 19 May 1611 to Cornelia Kief, 24, assisted by her mother Anna van Liesveld. He lived on the O.Z. Voorburgwal, she on the Koningstraet (betrothal in the Church) (Oud Holland, 3(1885), p. 60.) On 25 December 1616, Jean Basse and Cornelia Kif  had their son Henrij baptized in the Walloon Church in the presence of Diricq Kif and Jenne Derondeau, femme de Guillaume Basse le jeune (DTB 130/39).  On Guillaum Basse and Jeanne Derondeau (or Arondeau), see R 31003 of Montias2. On 4 August 1624, Jan Basse and Cornelia Kif had their daughter Cornelia baptized in the same church in the presence of Guillame Basse and Catherine Kif, femme d'Israel Jerbier (DTB 130/39). On Israel Jerbier, a buyer at WK auction, see R 23616.  The seller of the goods, Pieter Jacobsz. Indische Raven (II), is presumed to be the son of Pieter Jacobsz. Indische Raven de oude (I),  who died shortly before January 1626 (R 31326 of Montias2). In 1634, Jan Basse lived on the Uytrechtsche Steyger, next to the cakebaker Marcus Jansz. (NA 771, act dated 12 December 1634).  In the introduction to the inventory taken of the goods of Jan Basse on 6 January 1637 by Notary Pieter Barcman, it was noted that Pieter Indische Raven, guardian of Willem Basse, son of Jan Basse, had requested the inventory, along with Hendrikje Basse, daughter of the late Jan Basse de jonge. The inventory was also made op 't aengeven of Willem Basse and Jannetge Andries, the widow of the foresaid Jan Basse de jonge (Bredius, Künstler-inventare, vol. 1, p. 129.) According to the accounting delivered by Pieter Indische Raven to the Orphan Chamber on 22 June 1640, some of the assets left by Jan Basse I were given to Guilliam Basse, the uncle of Henrickge, the daughter left by Jan Basse II, and some to Janneke Andries, the widow of Jan Basse II (WK 5073/789, fol. 244. For other details, see the NOTES to R 7637 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Den 9e marty 1637 zijn de naergelaten rariteijten, steengewassen, silver ende goudse medaelen, printen ende teeckeningen, schilderyen etc.. van za. Jan Basse door Pieter Jacobsz. Indische Raven vercocht ende dat op conditien soo [iemandt] in dese vendities iet komt te kopen gehouden sal te stellen suffisant borghen dan genieten den tijt van ses weecken ende geen borgh stellende gehouden sal zijn contant te betaelen. [The household goods, not including any art objects, were sold on 1 April 1637 and brought only 153 f. 1 st. They were also sold by Pieter Jacobsz. Indische Raven.]

Residence: In de kleyne Keysersstraet op de hoeck van de Dwarssloot in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 17e April 1620 zyn vercocht de naergelate goederen van Neeltge Lucas.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Annetge van der Vinck
Residence: Op den Oudezyts Voorburchwall tusschen de St. Jans brug ende de Varcksluijs in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 21e april 1620 zyn ten versoecke van Annetge van der Vinck vercocht dese naervolgende goederen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of the widow of Cornelis Bartheltsen
Biographical Notes: The owner of the goods sold may be the candlemaker or fats collector Cornelis Bartholomeusz. who signed a petition along with 28 others men and women working in the trade on 18 July 1618 (NA 377, fol. 278, film 6409). He may also be the individual named Cornelis Bartelsz. who was godfather of Machtelt, daughter of Adam Reijger of R 20841 of Montias2, when she was baptized on 12 April 1594. Either may be identical with the surgeon Mr. Cornelis Bartelsz., who was said to be 40 years old, when he appeared in a deposition with Geraert Verstegen, 40, and declared at the request of Hans van der Bruggen that the latter was free of the plague (NA 381, film 6413, notaries Jacob and Nicolaes Jacobsz.).
Intro Text: uts [op den 4 junij anno 1620] zijn ten versoecke van de weduwe van Cornelis Bartheltsen vercocht [left blank]

Additional Names: and Annetge Harmans
Residence: Aende Blauw Brugh achter de pikeur stal in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Many frames were sold in the sale, including 30 for 4 st. a piece. From this it may tentatily be deduced that Arent Jansz. was a framemaker.  Among the buyers of frames were Marten Elbertsz. Oom in't Moriaensstraet, Willem Claes kistemacker (coffin maker, joiner) on Uijlenburch in de Bataviers dwarsstraet, Harmen Dommer ebbenhoutwercker (ebony woodworker) in de Gasthuysmolensteech, Cornelis Theunisz. kistemacker, Symon Hendricksz. kistemacker, Jan Willemsz. Bos in de Molsteech. Harmen Dommer was the frameworker portrayed by Rembrandt in 1640 (Strauss, Rembrandt Documents, p. 318.) On an important document, dated 18 November 1625, concerning the ebony workers of Amsterdam, including Harmen Dommer and Jan Willemsz. Bos, see Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven R.G.P. 78(1933), pp. 584-5.
Intro Text: Den 14e august 1636 zijn de naergelaten goederen van Arent Jansz. ende Annetge Harmans vercocht

Additional Names: and Lysbeth Pieroots. Goods sold at request of Adriaen Braems.
Residence: Int Sinte Claes straet in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Adriaen Braems, of R 25313 of Montias2,  at whose request the goods in this sale were sold sale,  helped to administer the Orphan Chamber (see Borgtochten, WK 5073/903). He paid a tax of 15 f. in 1631, when he lived on the Warmoesstraet.
Intro Text: Den 28e january 1637 sijn de naergelaten goederen van Benijamin Jacobsz. ende Lysbeth Pieroots door Adriaen Braems vercocht.

Biographical Notes: Michiel Jacobsz. Brouwer may have been the brother of Jan Jacobsz. Brouwer of R 30089 and of Hendrick Jacobsz. Brouwer, cited in the NOTES to R 26595.
Intro Text: Op den 12e decembris 1624 zijn vercocht dese naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Michiel Jacobsz. Brouwer.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Abraham Anthonisz.
Residence: ten huyse van Gerrit Jacobsz. in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On Abraham Anthonisz., see the notes to R  20033 in Montias2.
Intro Text: Op den 7e January 1625 zyn ten versoecke van Abraham Anthonisz. vercocht dese naervolgende goederen.

Residence: Op de oude zyts Voorburghwal inde Schrijvende Hand in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 24 March 1617, a post-mortem inventory of the goods of Pieter Claesz., schoolmaster, and of his wife (Sara Gerrits) was taken. The goods owned in common (?) were evaluated at 958 f. 1 st., the wife's clothing at 395 f. 10 st. The works of art that were listed separately were evaluated at 13 f. However, they were also said to be 5 small paintings in the binnecamer and 10 small and large paintings in the groote camer that were not evaluated. The painters Pieter Stalpaert and Jan Rieuwerts estimated that the works of art, all in all, were worth 140 f., not including, apparently, those that had been appraised separately (NA 647, film 4957). Sara Gerrits remarried with Cornelis de Meijer of Antwerp, droochschilder (cloth finisher), widower of Sabina van Wimpe, on 18 October 1625 (DTB 430/280). Cornelis de Meyer was a buyer at WK auction (R 31367). He became insolvent in 1646 (DBK 5072/352, fol. 6 and foll.) In an act of 8 August 1634, the house of Pieter Claesz., schoolmaster, on the Buijtendijckstraet, was cited (NA 728, film 5159, fol. 356).
Intro Text: Op den 27e martij 1620 zyn vercocht de naergelaten goederen van Pieter Claesz. in zijn leven schoolmeester.

Additional Names: goods allotted to the heirs of Gerrit Reynst
Residence: Ten huyse van Gerrit Jacobsz. in Amsterdam.
Biographical Notes: The sale probably comprised only a part of the goods left by Gerrit Reynst I  who died in Jakarta on 7 December 1615, where he was governor general of the Netherlandish Indies. He was married to Margaretha Nicquet, the daughter of Jan Nicquet and Margerita Bosmans (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 373.) He was a wealthy merchant. His son Gerrit Reynst II was married to Anna Schuijt, daughter of Albert Schuijt (of R 28923 of Montias2) and of Constantia de Haze. He was a famous collector of naturalia.
Intro Text: Ten selven dage [10 martij 1617] syn dese naervolgende goederen toecomende de erffgenamen van Gerrit Reynst zal. vercocht.

Residence: Aen de Amstel byt backhuys int Melckman
Intro Text: Op den 25 july 1610 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Lysbeth Gysberts.
no introduction

Biographical Notes: The paintings in this sale were sold at the request of various individuals, whose names are indicated in the lot headings of the inventory in Montias2 (wherever they are known).
Intro Text: no introduction: Some of the paintings were sold in de Verwerijen, some in de vier Trijtons.

Additional Names: and his wife Mary Jacobs
Biographical Notes: The owner of the goods was Cornelis Willemsz. de Goijer, cloth dealer, who transferred a fourth part of a house on the Nieuwen Dijck to Jan Gerritsz., also lakenkoper, on 2 February 1585. In 1585, living on the Nieuwen Dijck, he paid a tax of 6 f. (Van Dillen, Amsterdam, p. 128).  He invested 600 f. in the first subscription for V.O.C. shares (Van Dillen, Het oudste aandeelhoudersregister, p. 194). It was presumably his daughter Teuntje Cornelis de Goijer who married Lambert Gerritsz. Ruijl (at first painter, later merchant) of INVNO 596.  Gysbert de Goijer, who signed the receipt for the net proceeds of the auction, was probably Gysbert Jacobsz. de Goijer, born in 1562, living in the Warmoesstraet, who married Nelletgen van Heussen on 9 February 1603 (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 129.)
Intro Text: O ten 27 augustus 1605 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Cornelis de Goijer ende Mary Jacobs zyn huysvrou op 6 weken dach. Postscript: Quitantie (voor de suyvere penningen) gegeven by Gysbert de Goyer.

Biographical Notes: The late Zacharias Claesz. was a merchant who freighted 5 ships between 1598 and 1605 (IJzerman, Econonisch-historisch jaarboek 17(1931), p.268 and Winkelman, Bronnen voor de geschiedenis van het Oostzeehandel  R.G.P., 184(1983), p. 600.) His brother Lambert Claesz. freighted one ship in 1598 (IJzerman, ibid., p. 252). On 23 May 1603, Zacharias Claesz., 29 years old, living op 't Water, assisted by his father Claes Lambertsz., was betrothed to Jannetke van Stompwijck, 18, living on the N.Z. Achterburchwal, assisted by her father Pieter van Stompwijck and her petemoeij Marijtgen van Stompwijck (DTB 665/82). When Jannetke van Stompwijck remarried in January 1606, she had been 9 months a widow. The death of Zacharias Claesz. can therefore be placed in early 1605. On 2 April 1608, the Orphan Chamber appointed Lambert Claesz., the brother of Zacharias, as guardian over his orphan child (WK 5073/513, fol. 129vo.) It was presumably after the death of Lambert Claesz. that, on 22 October 1626, Lambert Gerritsz. Gent and Niclaes Wandelman were named guardians over the son of Zacharias Claesz. (WK 5073/513, fol. 48). Niclaes Wandelman (of R 30408) was the son of Mary van Stompwyck, who was undoubtedly a close relative of Zacharias's wife Jannetje van Stompwyck.
Intro Text: Opten 3 november 1605 zyn ter ordonnantie van den heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Zacharias Claesz. Postscript: De suivere penningen betaelt aen Lambert Claesz.

Residence: Op het Princen hoff in Amsterdam.
Biographical Notes: The goods sold belonged to a Carthusian monk.
Intro Text: Op den 25e january anno 1603 zyn ter ordonnantie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Johannes de Carthuyser monick plagh te werden. Postscript: Among the expenses that reduced the suivere pennningen due to the heirs of the deceased were: salaris, f 26: 6: 8; omroepen, f -: 2:--; taeffel, f -:12:-- Geertgen, f 1: 1: 1; extract, f 1: 2: 8.

Additional Names: goods sold to his brother-in-law Adriaen Maen
Biographical Notes: Adriaen Banck began his business career by working as the servant (dienaer) of Hans Vrancx (of R 20713) who, on 24 April 1638, ordered him to appear before the directors of the V.O.C. in the chamber of Amsterdam to transfer to Pieter and Jacob Valck, merchants, an action with the face value of 500 pounds Vlaems (NA 1556, fol. 69, Not. Cappoen). On 12 November 1638, Vrancx had him transfer  a sum of 500 pounds Vlaems capital to Jan van Bassen. The latter cannot of course be identical with the art dealer and painter Jan van Basse I of INVNO 832  who had died in 1637, nor with his son Jan van Basse II who died before January 1637. Adriaen Banck bought a painting of Susanna from Rembrandt about 1647. He was  the executor of the testament of Eva Ruwardus, the widow of the predicant Eleaser Swalmius. He was married to Swalmius's daughter Hilletje. He was a dealer in canvas (canvashandelaer). On 16 October 1661, Francois Beaumont was said to owe  the boedel of  Adriaen Banck 10,550 f. as part (in mindering) from the promised purchase price on a house on the Heeregracht on the West side (DBK 5072/514(old)).   On Eva Ruwardus and Eleaser Swalmius, see the TEXT of INVNO 352 (R 269). Adriaen Maen was his brother-in-law.
Intro Text: Op huijden den xxxi augustus xvi ende sestich compareerde voor mij Mr. Pieter van Toll notaris d'E. Adriaen Banck, coopman alhier, ter eenre, ende d'E. Adriaen Maen, coopman te Schiedam, ter andere zyde, bekenende hij Banck vercoft ende in handen van den voornoemt Maen overgegeven te hebben... schilderijen, huijsraet ende anders alles ten prijs de selfde hyer onder gespecificeert staen, van welcken coopmanschappen hy vercoper verclaerde wt handen van den cooper te vollen vernoegt ende voldaen te sijn.

Residence: Op de Bisschuyt marct in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Mr. Claes (alias Nicolas Petri), from Deventer, was a writer on book keeping and philosophy in 't Gulden Claverblat on the O.Z. Voorburgwal. He was also a zeevartkundig (his inventory comprised some astronomical instruments including an astrolabe.) He paid a tax of 6 f. in 1585 (Van Dillen, Amsterdam, p. 71). His goods were sold separetely, and brought f. 477:16:--. Among the buyers of these books were Barent Adriaensz. of R 3608 and Jan Evertsz. (Cloppenburch) of R 29002 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Ten selven dage [3 april 1603] syn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft 't naervolgende goet achtergelaten by Mr. Claes Pietersz. in zyn leven schoolmeester.

Purpose: Death inventory drawn up at request of Willem and Hendrick Schrijver and Johan Boreel
Biographical Notes: The inventory of Willem Scriverius (the above-named Schrijver), dated 26 October 1661, cited in Bredius, Künstler-inventare, vol. 1, p. 216, apparently contained a number of the paintings listed in the present inventory. Note that Jan Heijndrixsz. Soop (Floris's father) was the son of the dairy merchant  Heijndrick Pietersz. Schrijver. Already in 1612, according to an act dated 5 August, Jan Hendricx  Soop was managing the glass house of the city on Kloverniersburgwal  (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven 78(1933), p. 11). In 1614, he contributed lamps, apparently for a chandelier, included in the gift of the States General to the Sultan of Constantinople (Oud Holland 1(1883), p. 183).  Jan Hendricx Soop was a Remonstrant. According to Wagenaar (Amsterdam, vol.3, p.499), Carel Leendarsz. and Jan Willemsz. Bogaert, who were vroom Calvinists (hardline) objected to the naming of Jan Hendricx Soop as captain of the Nieuwe Wendelen of the Amsterdam militia.  There were portraits of Daniel, Mary, and Pieter Mathijsz. Schrijver in the present inventory (R 8552, R 8565, and R 8568 of Montias2). Pieter Mathijsz. Schrijver was a former alderman of Amsterdam and a Remonstrant, as was the (entire ?) family Schrijver. Jeronimus Ranst, cited in the INTRO,  was named guardian over the children of Gommer Spranger of R 31375 on 25 November 1640 (WK 5073/789). For an inventory of goods he obtained in compensation for a debt, see INVNO 1334.  Floris Soop, who lived from 1604 to 1657, was a director of the Amsterdam Schouwburg from 1638 to 1640. He was said to be a poet as well as a glass manufacturer (Jaarboek Amstelodamum 72(1981), p. 41). His portrait, as standard bearer, was painted by Rembrandt, perhaps in 1654 (see R 8663 of Montias2).
Intro Text: Inventaris ... van wijlen Floris Soop soo ende sulcx die bij hem nagelaten ende in zijn sterffhuys bevonden zijn. Gemaeckt op't versoecke ende overstaen vande herren Willem ende Hendrick Schrijver, mitsgaders de heer Johan Boreel, ambassadeur van wegens deser staet aende croon Franckrijck, ende de heer Jeronimus Ranst, als vanden Ed. Gerechte deser stede  ...  geobtineert hebbende appoinctement van authorisatie verlent op seker request aende gemelte gerecht gepresenteert ende overgelevert, in dato den darden deser maend maij xvi zevenenfijftich [in presentie van] Hendrick Tieboel ende Willem vande Poel [als ...] getuijgen.

Additional Names: widow of Reynier Jelensz.
Residence: Buyten 't Waterpoortge inde stadt werff in Amsterdam.
Intro Text: Op den 10e may anno 1603 noch ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren mede vercoft by Moortgen Henricx in de Pool weduwe van Reynier Jelensz.
Op den xiiii marty anno 1598 ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren deser stede syn vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Trijn Jansdr. ten behoeve van haere erffgenamen.

Additional Names: and his wife Mary Jansdr. Goods sold at request of Herman Ysbrantsz.
Biographical Notes: Pieter Cornelisz. metselaer (mason), in de Vijfhoeck in the St. Jacobsstraet, paid a tax of 8 f. in 1585. Herman IJsbrantsz., the guardian of his children, at whose request the inventory was drawn up, paid a tax of 12 f. He was a grain merchant, living near the Calverstraet. He used the last name Hem. He was a Regent of St. Pieters Gasthuis from 1602 to 1605. He was married to Maritge Hendricksdr. Loeff. He was a Schout of the city in 1575 (Van Dillen, Amsterdam in 1585, pp. 96 and 157; Elias, Vroedschap, p. 7). Herman Ysbrantsz. was the father of Ysbrant Hermansz. Hem of R 28963 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Op den xvi april 1598 zyn ten versoucke van Herman Ysbrants ende hem als voocht van de nagelaten kinderen van Pieter Cornelisz. metselaer ende Mary Jansdr. zyn huysvrou vercoft de naervolgende goederen op 6 wecken.

Additional Names: and Hans Dirxsz.
Occupation: Manufacturer |a Textiles, leather; Merchant (largescale) |a Leather, hides
Residence: In de Stad van Essen op de Zeedyck in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Hans Dircxsz., leather tanner  in de Swarte Bock op 't Water, paid a tax of 6 f. in 1585 (Van Dillen, Amsterdam, p. 121). On 6 September 1590, Hans Dijrricksz., leerkoper (dealer in leather), and Brecht Willems had their son Abram baptized in the O.K. in the presence of Maijken van Harcke (DTB 2/64).
Intro Text: Den 3 february 1599 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de nagelaten goederen van Brechtgen Luls ende Hans Dirxsz. ten behoeven van haer kinderen als volcht.

Additional Names: and Bayken van de Hout
Residence: Op St. Margriete Pat in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 12 april 1600 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Jaspar Windricx ende Bayken van de Hout.

Residence: In de Wijdesteech over 't vergulde aepken in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op de 3 may anno 1600 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de navolgende goederen achtergelaten by Mary Pieters.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Anna Willems alias Voetbooch
Residence: Buyten St. Claestooren poort van Bantem in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Anna Willems, alias Voetbooch, was presumably an uitdraagster.
Intro Text: Ten voors. daghe [29 augustus 1600] syn opt versoeck van Anna Willems alias Voetbooch vercoft de navolgenden goederen op 6 weken.

Biographical Notes: The late Jacob Elbertsz. was the former servant of the Orphan Chamber.
Intro Text: Op den 12e january 1601 zyn ter versoecke van de Regenten van 't weeshuys deser stede vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Jacob Elbertsz. eertyts knecht van 't weeshuijs.
Ten selven dagh [den 1e august anno 1601] zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Aeff Michiels weduwe op zes weecken.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Nicolaes Accotie
Intro Text: Op den 14 (?) september 1601 zyn ten versoecke van Nicolaes Accotie vercoft de naervoldgende goederen 6 wecken.

Additional Names: wife of Ellert van Diemen
Biographical Notes: Jonge Ellert van Diemen, the son of Ellert Hermansz. van Diemen, who was buried on 28 August 1577, and Aertgen Jaspersdr. Appelman, was married to Trijn Cornelisdr. who was buried on 7 July 1601 (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 330). According to Elias, he was a flagbearer for a company of Schutters, but the evidence for this comes from the delivery of stormhoeden to Allard van Diemen in 1573, who may well be the elder Van Diemen (     Oud Holland, 4(1885), p. 291).
Intro Text: Ten voors. dage [14 February 1602] ter ordonnancie als vooren [van de heeren weesmeesteren] zyn vercoft 't navolgende goet achtergelaten by Trijn Cornelis huysvrou van Ellert van Diemen

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Anne Symonsdr.
Residence: Tegenover 't meters huysgen op de Colck in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Den 23 marty anno 1602 zyn ten versoecke van Anne Symonsdr. vercoft 't naervolgende goed, zes wecken.

Additional Names: and his wife
Residence: Tegenover Henrick Arentsz. lijnban in Amsterdam.
Biographical Notes: The late Andries de Swart Ruyter was a captain. Hendrick Arentsz., who seems to have owned a lijnbaan, may be identical with the buyer of that name (R 32589 of Montias2)  who was said to be living on the Campersteyder in the Dom van Munster. Commandeur Pieter Claesz. de Swarte Ruyter whose ships carried whale sperm was probably related to Andries de Swart(e) Ruyter (M. Simon Thomas, Onze IJslandsvaarders in de 17de en 18de eeuw, Amsterdam, 1935, p. 69).
Intro Text: Op den 3e april anno voors [1602] zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft t navolgende goet achtergelaten by Cap[iteij]n Andries de Swart Ruyter ende syn huysvrou.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Maritgen van Horrick
Biographical Notes: Maritge van Horrick may have been the mother of the following individual. On 10 February 1590, Cornelis van Horick, from Mechelen, spaansleerbereider, 20 years old, living on the O.Z. Achterburchwal, assisted by his father Cornelis van Horick and his mother Mayken Pieters, was betrothed to Anneken de Meyer, from Mechelen, assisted by her father Gillis de Meyer (DTB 405/253). Cornelis de Horick (de jonge ?), in any case, was a buyer at the auction held at her request.
Intro Text: Ten selven dage [10 april 1602] syn ten versoeck van Maritgen van Horrick vercoft

Additional Names: and his wife
Residence: O.Z. Achterburgwal by 't gasthuys in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: There were two individuals of the same name, Francois de Raet I and II,  possibly father and son, who may have owned the goods in this inventory. Francois de Raet I was married to Geertruy Albrechts; Francois de Raet II was married, first, to Francijne Bollens and, second, to Geertruy Laurens. On 11 May 1589, Franssoes de Raet, merchant, and his wife Fransyne Bolles had their daughter Sara (I)  baptized in the O.K.  (DTB 2/14). On 11 May 1589, Francois de Raet, widower of Francijne Bolles, was betrothed to Geertruy Laurens, widow of Willem Eeuwen (DTB 762A/63). The owners of the present inventary may have been Francois de Raet I and Geertruy Laurens. They both had sons named Daniel. It is inferred that Francis de Raet I was the older, perhaps the father, of Francois de Raet II, because Daniel, the son of Francois de Raet I, born in Sandwich, England, was betrothed as early as 14 July 1601 when the other Daniel, the son of Francis de Raet II,  baptized on 7 September 1586, was only 15 years old (DTB 1/289). In July 1601,   Daniel de Raet of Sandwich, assisted by his mother Gertruyd Albrechts, widow of Francis de Raet,  was married to Susanneken Carpentier (Van Dillen, Het oudste aandeelhoudersregister, p. 148). Thus  Francois de Raet I died before July 1601. Given the date of the sale, the owner of the goods was probably  Francois de Raet II.   It was probably Francoijs de Raet I who paid a tax of 20 f. in 1585 (Van Dillen, Amsterdam, p. 169) and also freighted ships from 1591 to 1600 (IJzerman, Economisch-historisch Jaarboek 17(1931), p. 271). The following acts presumably refer to Francis de Raet II. On 2 May 1591, Pieter, son of Francois de Raet and of Francijne Bolles, was baptized, also in the O.K. (DTB 2/89). On 5 December 1593, Sara (II), same parents, was baptized in the O.K. in the presence of Abygel van Harthoeck (DTB 2/205). On 15 July 1595, Francois de Raet, widower of Francijn Bolles, was betrothed to Geertruyt Laurens, widow of Willem Eeuwen (DTB 762A/63). Francoys de Raedt III who wooed Lysbeth van Valckenborch without success (she eventually married the poet Jacob Cats) may have been the son of Francois de Raet I or II (Oud Holland 7(1889), p. 174.)
Intro Text: Op den 11-12 aprilis anno 1602 vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Francoys de Raedt ende zyn huysvrou te betalen op 6 wecken dach.

Residence: In de geesten poortgen achter 't [...] velt in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: One of the only instances where the owner of goods sold has been denoted as a street worker.
Intro Text: Den 26e aprilis 1602 zyn vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Jan Wibbesz. arbeyder aende straet.

Residence: In de Romeyns armsteech in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Den 30e may 1602 ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren syn vercoft 't naevolgende goet achtergelaten by Gerrit Hendrixsz.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Salomon de Schilder
Residence: ten huyse van Jan Dircxsz. [van Beuningen] in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Salomon de Schilder is likely to be identical with Salomon Pietersz. (of R 875 of Montias1), who lived in the Rockin in De schildershant and also had paintings sold on several occasions at the house of Jan Dircksz. (van Beuningen).
Intro Text: [op den 15e august 1620] ten versoucke van Salomon de Schilder.
Op den 12e november 1620 zijn vercocht de naergelate goederen van Annetge Prijs.

Residence: In de Nieuwe Lelystraet in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op de 1e marty anno 1621 zyn vercocht de naegelate goederen van Giert Jochems.

Residence: Tegen over 't Utrechtse Veer door de Geelvinck steech aende Schans in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: The late Grietgen Augustyns is likely to be identical with Margriete Augustyns, the wife of the merchant Bartholomeus Claesz., who was still living in Amsterdam in 1608. Their son Hugo Bartholomeusz. van der Mast was living in Amsterdam in 't gulden Schepel when he married Swaentgen Boelens, daughter of Dirck Hendricksz. on 2 September 1603. He later settled in Delft (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 592). It is probably this same Bartholomeus Claesz. who paid a tax of 10 f. in 1585, at which time he lived op 't Water on the Brugsstege (Van Dillen, Amsterdam, p. 103).
Intro Text: Op den 3e martij 1621 zyn vercocht de goederen achtergelaten by Grietgen Augustyns.

Residence: Op de Prince gracht by de Elandts straet in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: The only goldsmith by the name of Jan Claesz. that could be identified is the individual in R 21352 of Montias2. His last name was Kroeck or Croock. The present estate sale is surprisingly meager: it contains none of the expensive paintings that Jan Claesz. goutsmit had bought at auction earlier.  On 14 April 1585, Jan Claesz., goutsmit, and Eechgen Everts had their daughter baptized in the O.K. (DTB 1/204).  The goldsmith Jan Claesz. living on the South side of the Kerckhoff, paid a tax of 3 f. in 1585 (Van Dillen, Amsterdam, p. 45). Jan Claesz. Croock was one of the headmen of the goldsmiths' guild in 1602 (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven R.G.P., 69(1929), p. 607).  He may also be identical with Jan Claesz. in't Wapen van Sutfen who invested 900 f. in the first subscription for V.O.C. shares (Van Dillen, Het oudste aandeelhoudersregister, p. 208). On two occasions in 1594, he delivered silver or gilded objects to the city (Oud Holland 24(1906), pp. 56-7).
Intro Text: Op den eersten april 1621 zijn vercocht de naegelate goederen van Jan Claesz. Crock in sijn leven goutsmith.

Biographical Notes: The name of the late owner of the goods sold is normally written Karel Kare, Carre, or Carree. On 13 June 1596, Carel Carree, from Antwerp, 25 years old, living on the Betanienstraet for the last 8 years, was betrothed to Barentgen Jansdr., from Zwolle, 28. He signs with an elaborate mark (he fully signs notarial documents) (DTB 408/37). On 6 July 1606, Carel and his wife had their son Jan baptized in the presence of Aeltge Cornelis in the N.K. (DTB 39/2). On 7 September 1611, Carel Caree, stone sculptor, acknowledged receiving the sume of 539 f. from Margrite Halfmere for sculpture work and carpentry (NA 38, film 52).  On 7 February 1617, Carel Care, steenhouwer (stone carver), and Octaeff Laurens entered into an agreement for making posts for hearths  (schoorstenen). Carel Care was to advance 200 f. for the enterprise without demanding interest on his investment. Octaeff Laurens was to get 15 stuivers a day while working on these posts. The profits over and above labor costs were to be shared half and half (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven, 78(1933), p. 228). On 5 December 1618, Meynert Jansz., tax master for bulk wares (grove waren) summoned a number of stone dealers and sculptors, including Carel Caree, to declare his stock of stones. He responded that he would come to the impostmaster to make his declaration (NA 381, fol. 542).   On 25 March 1621, Trijntgen Louwers, widow of Carel Carree, steenhower, assisted by Lenaert Thonisz., schipper, her chosen guardian, presented the four children (Annetge, married to the sculptor Pieter Emanuels,  Passchijntge, 19, Jan, 17, and Sara, 15) of her husband, whose mother was Barentge Jans, before the Orphan Chamber. The children were entitled to 2365 f. for their mother's inheritance (WK 5073/789, fol. 169).  On 15 January 1627, the children and heirs of Karel Carre, steenhouwer, sold a house on the Koningsgracht named de Rot Steen, contiguous on the north side with the house of the children of bourgomaster Jacob Poppen. The house was sold to Pieter Emanuel, steenhouwer (the husband of Annetge,  the eldest daughter of Carel Cre) for 3840 f. The sureties (borgen) were Hendrick Fredericksz., beer distributor (bierbeschoijer), of R 25295 of Montias2, and Gerrit Woutersz. mason. Another house on the Koningsgracht was sold to Jan Jansz. steenhouwer, one of the buyers at the Cre sale, for 2950 f. Still another house aen den Vesten was sold to Jan Carel, steenhouwer, perhaps the son of Carel Cre baptized in 1606, for 1120 f. (WK 5073/913). Pieter Emanuel seems to have remarried with Passchijntge Carels, the younger sister of his first wife Sara. On 20 August 1632, Pieter de Keyser, stadsbeeldhouwer, had a notary notify in an insinuatie directed at Passchjntgen Carels, widow of Pieter Emanuelsz., steenhouwer, asking payment for some sculpture (a preeckstoel etc..), which he, de Keyser, had undertaken on a half and half basis with her late husband, for Dominicus van Uffelen in Hamburg. He was owed 1169 f., minus 202 f. she had already paid him (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven R.G.P. 78(1933), pp. 810-811.) In 1631, Sara Caree, who was 15 years old in 1621, was the widow of Lubbert Gerritsz. blue dyer by 1631 (WK 5073/789, fol. 169).
Intro Text: Op den 4e april 1621 zyn vercocht dese naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Karel Cre beelthouwer.

Additional Names: paintings sold at request of Marten Hendricksz. Spiegel
Residence: Op de Fluwele Bruchwal in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 1 September 1612, Marten Hendricksz. Spiegel, 24 years old, living op 't Water, assisted by his father Hendrick Jansz. Spiegel, was betrothed to Nelletien Jan Korvers, 25, assisted by her father Jan Korver and her mother Nelletgen Bassen (DTB 416/256).  On 9 November 1616, Marten Spiegel took out a mortgage on a mill for making woolen cloth for 24 gulden a year (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven R.G.P., 78(1933),  p. 188.) He had probably died by 1631, when his children paid a tax of 30 f., at which time they lived on the West side of the Heeregracht (Kohier, fol. 85vo., p. 20.)
Intro Text: Op den 13 may 1621 zyn ten versoecke van Marten Hendricksz. Spiegel vercoft de naervolgende schilderijen.

Additional Names: widow of Jan Dircxsz. (Hoochsaet)
Residence: In de Oude Haarlemerstraet in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Jan Dircxsz. Hoochsaet was the son of Dirck Cornelisz., sailmaker. He was living in the St. Oloffs capelsteech when he paid a tax of 1 f. in 1585 (Van Dillen, Amsterdam, p. 63). He became a citizen of Amsterdam in 1597.  On 5 February 1600, Jan Dierics Hoochsaet, from Nieuwenierop (Nierop), compass maker, 23, living by the Haarlemmersluys, assisted by his father Dirck Pietersz., was betrothed to Femmetje Jans, assisted by her mother Neeltge Willems (DTB 665/62). Dirck Pietersz. van Nierop was a teacher of the Waterland Anabaptist community. Femmetje Jans was the daughter of the cloth dealer Jan Jansz. and of Neeltgen Willems. She was the sister of Aefje Jans, married to Lucas Jacobsz. (Wijnman, Uit de kring van Rembrandt en Vondel, p.22).  Isaack Warnersz., one of the two guardians of the children of Femmetgen Jansdr. and Jan Dircxsz., was the ironmonger Isaack Warnersz. Kisgens of R 20063. Claes Jacobsz., the other guardian cited in the INTRO, was the uncle of the children of Jan Dircksz. and Femmetje Jans (ibid. p.22). He may possibly have been the compass maker and flag-maker Claes Jacobsz. van Vollenhoven, noted in Amsterdam in 1583, 1586 and 1609 (Sybrich ter Kuile, Amsterdamse kompasmakers ca 1580-ca 1850, Amsterdam, 1999, p. 74). On 20 January 1638, Jan Gerritsz., tailor, 26, Annetge Jans, wife of Jan Gerritsz., Mietetje Jans, 21, and Grietje Egberts, widow of Jan Jansz. de Wolff, declared at the request of Stijntje Coornharts, stepmother of the producent (Compas), that, at the time when Annetje Jans was maid servant in the house of Dirck Jansz. Compas, Stijntje Coornhart had taken lemons and locked them up, had broken a mirror belonging to Dirck Jansz. Compas, and so forth. (NA 1276, act 67).  Trijntje Jans, (Hoochsaet),  the daughter of the late Jan Dircxsz., bought much of the silver, which was sold at fixed prices in the present sale. On 23 January 1627, Trijn Jans married the skipper Pieter Claess Croon. She was 20 and he was 28 (Wijnman, ibid.) She remarried with Hendrick Claesz. Rooleuw in 1637 (with whom she got on so badly that the couple was eventually granted a judicial separation) and, finally, with the surgeon Jan Schildt in 1673  (ibid., pp. and 35). Hendrick Claesz. Rooleuw was the brother of the notary Evert Claesz. Rooleeuw.    In 1657 Trijntje Jans Hoochsaet was portrayed by Rembrandt. Jan Dirkcsz. was the brother of Pieter Dircksz. (Hoogsaet), the father of Jan Pietersz. Neckevelt of R 23594. Another brother, named Reyer Dircksz. van Nierop, sailor, was married to Metgen Andries, the daughter of Andries Claesz. Schaepherder. A sister of Metgen, named Grietje Andries, married the calligrapher Lieven van Coppenol. Wijnman conjectures that Coppenol gave Rembrandt a commission to etch his portrait in 1658  after he saw the portrait of Trijn Jans Hoogsaet painted the previous year (On these family relations, see H.F. Wijnman, (op.cit. pp. 21-2 and 32-3). The compass maker  Dirck Jansz. Compas was presumably the son of Jan Dircx Compas. On 5 September 1635, Sr. Nicolaes Block insinuated Dirck Jan Compas, claiming that all the latter's movable goods would have to be sold to satisfy his creditors (Na 1410, Not. Cornelis Touw).  On 9 September 1636, the stone dealer Hendrick Thomasz., lying sick in bed, declared that he had guaranteed an alderman's obligation, whereby Dirck Jansz. Compas had bound himself for the sale of goods  that Thomasz. had sold to Jacob Bueno on the Vlooyenburg. Jacob Bueno was the Portuguese Jewish doctor in medicine portrayed by Rembrandt (NA 1418, Not. C. Touw, act 8).  For the  family name of Femmetje Jans, which was apparently Branderis, and for other information on the Hoochsaet family, see the NOTES to R 23594 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Op den 15e september 1621 zyn ten versoecke van Isaack Warnersz. ende Claes Jacobsz. (als voogden van de nagelate kinderen van Femmetgen Jansdr. weduwe van Jan Dircxsz. compasmaker) vercoft de navolgende goederen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Claes Cornelissen
Residence: Ten huyse van Jan Dircksz. (van Beuningen)
Intro Text: [den 16 septembris] ten versoecke van Claes Cornelissen zyn vercocht.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Pieter Claesz. den Drager
Intro Text: Ten versoecke van Pieter Claesz. den Drager vercocht dese naervolgende goederen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Jannetge Flamengs
Residence: Int Gebet Sonder Endt in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Ten voors. dage [4e january 1623] zyn ten versoucke van Jannetge Flamengs vercoft de naevolgende goederen te betalen etc... [6 wecken]

Residence: Op de Prinsegracht by de Ree Brugh in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Anthony Hagenoij was the son of Hendrick van Hagenoij, prosecuting attorney (procureur), in Leiden, married to Catharina van Heusden, who was assassinated in the street on the night of 1 February 1593. The assassination was witnessed by Cornelis Willemsz. Zuytbroeck, who was Rembrandt's uncle. Anthonij, who became an attorney and, for a short time, a notary in Amsterdam, had a sister named Ann (Nederlandsche Leeuw 65(1948), col. 158).
Intro Text: Op den 7 december 1624 zyn vercocht dese naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Avocaet Anthonij Hagenoij te betalen etc...[6 wecken]
Op den 30 november 1624 zyn vercocht dese naevolgende goederen achtergelaten by Jan Ewoutsen, te betalen etc.. [6 wecken]

Residence: Op de Bier Kaij op de Hoeck van de St. Annestraet in Amsterdam.
Biographical Notes: The buyer of lot 00011 was Rogier Rogiersz. de man, who was the husband of the late Dirckge Cornelisdr. On 19 September 1624, Mr. Rogier Rogiersz., chirurgijn (surgeon), and his wife Dirckjen Cornelis, had their daughter Jannetje baptized in the presence of Cornelis Roosen and Rogier Bernaert (DTB 6/93). For more information on Rogier Rogiersz. Bernaert and his son of the same name, see R 36276 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Op den laetsten december 1624 zijn vercocht dese naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Dirckge Cornelisdr., te betalen etc.. [6 wecken]

Additional Names: and his wife Maritgen Vincken
Residence: Op de Keulse Kay by de Nieuwe Wech in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: The merchandise owned by Arent van Liesvelt, consisting of barrels and wijnverlater gereetschap was sold on 3 January 1625. The buyers were Bruijn Meyndertsz., Hendrick Wybrantsz., Hendrick Doncker, Hans Marijn, Evert Carelsz., Harmen Visscher, Bouwen Bouwensz., Dirck Haack, Albert Jansz. Grootvorst, Cornelis Barentsz., Gerrit Claesen, Daem Hectorsz., Michiel Lubbertsz., Koenraet van Dul(leken ?), Willem Benedictus, Augustyn Jonckes, Maerten Dircksz. and Dirck Remmesen. None was a buyer at auction in preserved records. The proceeds of the auction were to be paid to the coopers' guild to settle the debts of Arent van Liesvelt.
Intro Text: Op den 2en januarij 1625 zyn vercocht dese naevolgende goederen achtergelaten bij Arent van Liesvelt ende Maritgen Vincken zijn huijvrou, te betalen etc.. [6 wecken]

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Christoffel van Sichem de jonge
Biographical Notes: On 23 March 1613, Christoffer van Sichem de jonge, from Basel, figuursnyder, 31 years old, living in the Monkelbaanstoorn, assisted by his father Christoffer van Zichem, was betrothed to Anneken Lunden, from Antwerp, 31, living on the Rokkin, assisted by her mother Janneken Lunden and her uncle Daniel Sautyn (Oud Holland, 2(1884), p. 206.) He later remarried with Anna Glimmer and, after her death, with Marritie Joosten (ibid.) See also R 20995 of Montias2. Maritge Joosten cited in the TEXT of R 789 of Montias1 may be identical with the third wife of Christoffel van Sichem.
Intro Text: Op den 14 januarij anno 1625 zyn ten versoecke van Christoffel van Sichem de jonge vercocht dese naervolgende goederen te betalen uts.. [6 wecken]

Biographical Notes: The works of art owned by Pieter Jansz. van Loo may have been sold separately. The present  sale contained some silver and a few jewels, including a diamond, which was sold to Sara IJsacx (of R 27195 of Montias2) for 11 f. 5 st. Pieter Jansz van Loo lived op de Dam (on the N.Z.) in 1606 when he bought lots in the Haarlem lottery for 7 f. (GAA 119/22 F 882). This address corresponds to the one he gave when he seems to have been underbidder for three lots in 1609 (including R 29436, where he gave his address as  in de 3 Vijseltgens op den Dam, where auction sales were frequently held). . On 6 May 1613, Pieter Jansz. van Loo was said to be impost meester van de bieren (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven R.G.P. 78(1933), p.48; in 1630, he was said to be impost meester van de wijnen (ibid. p. 709). In 1631, Pieter Jansz. van Loo, living on the Keizersgracht, paid a tax of 20 f. (Kohier fol. 90, p. 22). Abraham Jansz. van Loo was presumably the brother of Pieter Jansz. On 10 July 1635, Abraham Jansz. van Loo, the uncle, and Reynier Ranson, the uncle by marriage, of Sara van Loo (presumably Pieter Jansz.'s sister) brought assets  to the Orphan Chamber for Hester, 14, and Lysbeth, 10, inherited from their grandaunt Lisbeth Ridders (WK 5073/789).   On 8 October 1635,  Harmen Jacobsz. van Doornick, who had been appointed guardian and administrator over the person of Claes van Loo, the orphan child left by Pieter Jansz. van Loo, who had lived on the Bloemgracht, named Hendrick Teunisz., as husband and guardian of Mary Jans, the sister and co-heir of Pieter Jansz. van Loo, to collect rents due to the estate. Claes and Mary Jans divided the estate in equal halves (NA 772, Not. Verhey). On 18 October 1635, the Orphan Chamber received the sum of 968 f. from the estate of Pieter Jansz. van Loo, lyndrayer (linen worker), whose late mother was Ytge Gerrits [G...t]. Pieter Jansz. was apparently not married (WK 5073/789). Pieter van der Loo of INVNO 1310, a diamond cutter and jeweler,  was another individual. Finally, there was a broker named Pieter de Loo who was said to be 36 years old in an act dated 14 October 1637 (NA 522, film 4861). He may be identical with the spices merchant  Pieter van Loo who was said to be 21 years old when he was betrothed to Aeffgen van der Waart,  on 1 February 1625. He was assisted by his aunt Maijken de Vries. Both of the betrothed were living in Leiden (DTB 763/136).
Intro Text: Den 26en maij 1635 zyn de naergelaten goederen van Pieter Jansz. van Loo vercocht.

Additional Names: and his wife Barber Pieters
Residence: Op de Nieuwendijck naest de Oude Pauw in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 2 June 1601, Pieter Arentsz. Sandelyn, kuyper, 26, living on the N.Z. Achterburchwal, assisted by his sister Aechgien Arents and his nichte Janneken Harkey, was betrothed to Barber Pieters, 23, living on the Nieuwen Dijck, assisted by Jan Pietersz. Tolck and Cornelis Pietersz., her brothers, and Claes Jansz. Copma (?), her uncle (DTB 665/165). On 29 March 1616, Jacob Jacobsz. Seeuw (cited in R 23774 of Montias2)  and Cornelis Pietersz. Tolck were named guardians over the goods of Maritge Joosten impotent WK 5073/513, fol. 155vo. The third wife of Christopher van Sichem, named Marritge Joosten, may be identical withe impotent woman cited in this last document (see R 787 of Montias1).
Intro Text: Op den 9e november anno 1618 zijn vercocht de goederen achtergelaten by Pieter Arentsz. ende Barber Pieters zyn huijsvrou.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Salomon Pietersz.
Biographical Notes: Salomon Pietersz. had goods sold on at least four other occasions (R 850, 874, 875,  and R 878). He may have been a dealer in paintings (see R 875).
Intro Text: uts [4 april 1620] zyn ten versoecke van Salomon Pietersz. vercocht etc..

Residence: Op de O.Z. Voorburchwal by de St. Jans straet in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Vincent Jacobsz. Coster, alias Sente Peylder, born about 1553, was an official wine gauger, for collecting excise on wine, and a servant of the Stadexcijshuis. He was perhaps also a wine merchant (    Oud Holland 6(1888), p. 105). He was the nephew of the burgomaster Dr. Marten Jansz. Coster.   He lived in the Niesel in the Witte Calckoen. He owned a lunatic asylum (doolhof) outside the city. He was known as a friend of the arts. His portrait was painted by Jacques de Geyn in 1591 and by  Jacob Matham in 1602. His testament was witnessed by the painter Cornelis Ketel in 1608, the year of his death. He was married to Grietge Stoffelsdr., who was buried on 24 July 1624.
