She apparently kept her late husband's household goods until her death. On 18 April 1619, a distribution by lots (caveling) took place of the possessions of Vincent Jacobsz. Coster. Jan Gasmae(?). horticulturist,  on one side; Jan Centen (probably of INVNO 280); Daniel van Genegen (of R 20520 of Montias2) as husband and guardian of Aeltgen Centen; and Gerrit Adriaensz. Merm as husband and guardian of Susanna Centen, all children and heirs of Vincent Jacobsz. Coster for themselves and in the place of Grietgen Stoffels, widow of the late Vincent Jacobus Coster, drew lots for the division of the estate. Claes Hendricksz. and Willem Jansz. horticulturist were arbiters in this division. Various sums were exchanged to make the lots equitable. Claes Hendricksz. (probably of INVNO 1195) and Willem Jansz. horticulturist acted as arbiters. Various compensatory sums were paid to make the lots equitable (NA 200, film 111). It is not clear whether this division did not go through or whether the goods in the present sale consisted of what remained after the division. In any case,  Cent Jacobsz.'s goods were sold at the request of his heirs, including Jacob Jansz. Koster, one of the buyers at the sale, who may have one of the children of Jan Vincentsz. Koster of INVNO 280 and INVNO 2800, thus a grandchild of Cent Jacobsz. On 15 June 1633, the honorable Gerrit Adriaensz. Merm named his wife Susanna Cent Jacobs Costers to indemnify Bartolt Philipsz. (of R 27378), Adriaen Cornelisz. Brederode (the father of Bredero of R 28859), Claes Hendricx Stopper (of R 20012, all of Montias2), and Hendrick Brughmans for the guarantee they had given him when he had purchased the farm on the tax on wine (NA 991, fol. 31, Not. J. Bosch).
Intro Text: Op den 11e marti anno 1627 zyn ten versoecke van de erffgenamen van Cent Jacobsz. Peiler vercocht dese naervolgende goederen te betalen etc...[6 wecken]

Additional Names: wife of Jacob Jacobsz. Ondermarck
Biographical Notes: On 18 September 1627, Jacob Jacobsz. Ondermarck, widower of Magdalena Jans, living the Haarlemmerstraet, was betrothed to Katharina Samuels, assisted by her father Samuel Bastiaensz. and her mother Jannetje Delsert (DTB 432/366). Jacob Ondermarck was a buyer at his wife's auction (R 36425 of Montias2).
Intro Text: Op den ii julij 1627 zyn vercoft de nagelaten goederen van Magdalentgen Jans huysvrou was van Jacob Jacobsz. Ondermarck te betalen etc.. [6 wecken]

Biographical Notes: Jacob Huych Thomasz. was appointed concierge of Amsterdam in 1587. He died in 1617 and was followed in his post by his son Thomas Jacobsz. Haringh, who was born in 1586 or 1587. The concierge was responsible for holding executoriale auctions of bankrupt individuals, while the bode of the Orphan Chamber supervised all other auctions approved by the Town Hall (I. van Eeghen, Het Amsterdamse Sint Lucasgilde in de 17de eeuw, Jaarboek Amstelodamum, 61(1969), pp. 73-4). A supplementary sale of his goods was held on 11 February 1618 (INVNO 808).
Intro Text: Op den thiende Augusty anno 1617 zyn ten versoeck van den erfgenamen van za. Jacob Huych Thomasz. in syn leven conchierge deser stede vercocht 't navolgende.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of the widow and children of Davit du Gardyn
Biographical Notes: On 2 February 1605, Maria Bertoudts was betrothed to Gerrit Gerritsz. barbier onder Captain David du Gardyn (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 322).
Intro Text: Op den 19en octobris anno 1617 zyn ten verzoecke van de nagelaten weduwe ende kinderen van Davit du Gardyn in zyn leven capiteyn vercocht dese navolgende goederen.

Additional Names: godmother of Hendrick Claesz.
Residence: Op de O.Z. Burchwal achter de Oude Kerck in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 9en january anno 1618 zyn vercocht de goederen naergelaten by Neel Dircx de petemoij van Hendrick Claesz.

Residence: Op de wortel mart in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Willem Jansz. was a baker.
Intro Text: Op den 25e january anno 1618 zijn vercocht de goederen naergelaten by Willem Jansz. backer naergelaten hebbende twee kinderen genaemt Marijtgen ende Jan Willemsz.

Additional Names: goods left by the widow of Mr. Sybrant
Biographical Notes: Mr. Sybrant, barbier, paid a tax of 2 f. in 1585 (Van Dillen, Amsterdam, p. 29).
Intro Text: Den 19 marty 1618 zyn vercocht de goederen achtergelaten by de weduwe van Mr. Sybrant.

Additional Names: late wife of Ysbrant Lambertsz.
Residence: In de Vogelsteech dwarstraet in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 31 October 1609, Ysbrant Lambertsz., sailmaker, 25 years old, living in the Nes, assisted by his neve Jochum Hendricksz. [...], was betrothed to Aeltgen Heijnricx, 22, living in the St. Janshoff, assisted by her bestemoeder Griet Joosten and her [...] Jacob Hansz. (DTB 414/182). Ysbrant Lamberts remarried with Geesje Heijckes in December 1626 (DTB 431/496).
Intro Text: Op dese 24e marty anno 1618 zijn vercocht de goederen achtergelaten by Aeltgen Hendricx huijsvrouw van Ysbrant Lambertsz. naegelaten hebbende een kint genaemt Hendrick Ysbrantsz.

Additional Names: widow of Lucas Reijnaert
Residence: In de Bloet straet in een slopgen in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 26e martij anno 1618 zijn vercocht de goederen achtergelaten by Heijltgen Lucas weduwe van Lucas Reijnaert naegelaten hebbende 6 kinderen.

Additional Names: wife of Lubbert Jansen
Residence: In de Warmoesstraet in de Craen in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: The house called de Kraen in the Warmoesstraet was occupied by prominent individuals in the 16th century (Elias, Vroedschap, pp. 128, 181, 226.) On 11 November 1589, Lubbert Jansz., droochscheerder  (cloth finisher), living on the O.Z. Voorburgwal, 25 years old, assisted by his mother Anne Hendricksdr., was betrothed to Rycklant Noye, from Hardewyck, assisted by her brother Gerart Noyen (DTB 405/213).  On 10 December 1601, Lubbert Janssen, cloth dealer (lakenkoper), and his wife Ricklant Noeijen had their son baptized in the O.K. in the presence of Michiel Noijen (DTB 4/6). According to a notarial act of 4 May 1618, a dispute had arisen between Lubbert Janssen, assisted by his brother Hendrick Janssen, on one side, and Cornelis Pietersz., tinsmith (of R 36553 of Montias2), as husband and guardian of Grietgen Lubberts, and Franchoijs de Buijs (hose merchant), as husband and guardian of Aeltgen Lubberts, assisted by Jan Noije (of R 36562 of Montias2), the uncle and guardian of the children of the afore-said Lubbert Jansz., on the other, concerning the testament of Lubbert Janssen and his late wife Rycklant Noijen and the goods left by Rycklant Noijen. In 1617, it  had been decided to submit the dispute to Dominicus van Heemskerck, a member of the Amsterdam Vroedschap, and Floris Claessen Cloeck (of R 29575), as arbiters. After prolonged deliberation, the arbiters had decided that the testament of Lubbert Jansz. would be null and void and that 48 f. would be paid to Cornelis Pietersz., the brother-of-law of Lubbert Jansz., for the pension (montkosten) of the two children who had apparently been apprenticed to him (NA 200, film 111, Not. J.F. Bruyning). After the death of his wife, probably shortly before the date of this inventory, Lubbert Jansz. attempted to sell de Kraen at auction on 29 January 1619 but it did not sell (held up at 5,400 f.) (J.G. Kam, Waar was dat huis in de Warmoesstraat? 1968, p. 34/14.) On 6 December 1622, the Orphan Chamber appointed Cornelis Pietersz., tinsmith, and Arnoldus van der Vorst (or Voort ? of R 37013)  as guardians over the children of Lubbert Jansz. and Rijckland Nooyen (WK 5073/513, fol. 8). Lubbert Jansz. remarried with Maijke Wouters on 1 May 1626 (DTB 765/5).
Intro Text: Op den 12e meij [1618] zijn vercocht de goederen naergelaten by Rijckelant Noije huysvrouw van Lubbert Jansen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Aert Lambertsz.
Residence: Ten huyse van Jan Dircxsz. in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: The goods in this sale were sold at the request of Aert Lambertsz., who is tentatively identified as  Aert Lambertsz. Cock, the half brother of Philips Lenertsz. of R 29712 and of INVNO 1228  and the uncle of Michael van den Broeck of R 32429 (of Montias2).  On 6 July 1616, he sold a house called de wilde man to Gerrit Roseboom, secretary of the city (of R 36187 of Montias2; see also the NOTES to R 29712).
Intro Text: Op den 29e january 1618 zijn ten versoecke van Aert Lambertsz. vercocht dese naervolgende goederen.

Residence: Op de Cingel by de Gasthuys in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 6 juny 1614 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Franchyntge Claesdr. Postscript: Weesmeesteren ordonneren Gerrit Jacobsz. Harinck de suyvere penningen van dese vercopinge gecomen te tellen aen Wouter Cornelisz. den outsten soon omme daer de schulden te betalen ... acte den 27 augusty 1614.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Ambrosius Laurensz.
Biographical Notes: Ambrosius Laurensz., born in Antwerp, was a merchant and a cloth dyer. He was related to (perhaps the brother of) Pieter Laurensz. (Spiegel) of R 7612 of Montias2 (Gelderblom, Zuid-Nederlandse kooplieden, p. 306). He was married to Gerbrich  Hendricx. He died before 17 September 1625 when his wife made an appearance before the Orphan Chamber (WK 5073/789, fol. 100).  The expenses that were deducted from the net proceeds were  remitted to Elisabeth Verplancken on behalf of the unnamed daughter of Ambrosius Laurens. The expenses of the sale  were: 15 f. 15 st. for the auctioneer's salary; 8 st. for the table and for the announcement (omroepen); 17 f. 19 st. tot wiens versoeck (items that were bought, presumably, by the daughter of Ambrosius Laurensz.); and 16 st. for a copy of the sale. Laurens Verplancken, whose pre-nuptial contract with Hester Provoost follows, may have been the son or grandson of Ambrosius Laurensz. On 8 December 1643, Laurens Verplancken, accompanied by Jan Jansz. Wassenaer, his stepfather, Reynier Verplancken, his brother,  Abraham Verplancken (cited in the NOTES to R 32330), Jan Reyniersz., Jasper Loduwycx van der Plasse (probably the brother of Cornelis Loduwycx van der Plasse of R 28224) and Melchior Barentsz. Veres, his uncles, signed a pre-nuptial contract with Hester Provoost, assisted by Jacques Provoost, Jacques de la Haije, and Jean le Gillon, her brothers-in-law (NA 988, act 42, Not. J. Bosch). On 22 January 1621, Melchior Barentsz. and Bartelemes Symonsz. were named as guardians over the children of the late Pieter Barentsz., house carpenter (WK 5073/513). Melchior Barentsz. Veres (Veris, Feris) was almost certainly related to the (amateur?) painter Barend Jansz. Veris, cited in the TEXT of 905 of Montias1.
Intro Text: Op den 22e july 1608 syn ten versoecke van Ambrosius Laurensz. vercoft de naervolgende goederen op 6 wecken dach. Postscript: Den 25sten augustij sijn dese booven geschieten penninghe betaelt aen Eleijsabet Verplancken door last van de dochter van Ambroses Lauwerens.

Additional Names: widow of Cornelis Herwayer
Residence: Op de Cingel over de Gelderse Caye in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 23 June 1622, Aper Harrewaijer (signs Herwayer, as in this INTRO) was betrothed to Anna Borth. He was assisted by his cousin and guardian Jacob Simonsz. Aper Harrewaijer was 22 years old at the time. He cannot be identical with Aper Claesz., the guardian of the children of Cornelis Herwayer, since he would only have been 14 at the time this sale took place. Aper Claesz., however, may have been his  uncle. (DTB 424/161). The late Cornelis Herwayer, in turn, may have been the father of Aper Harrewaijer. Note that, on 20 March 1614, Aper Claesz. was named guardian over Meynsgen, the daughter of the late Cornelis Baers (WK 5073/513, fol. 142). On 6 February 1588, Aper Claesz., binnenlantsvarer (bargeman on inland waters), 29 years old, assisted by his father Claes Hansz., was betrothed to Pietertge Jans, 27 (DTB 662/103). On 23 March 1610, Aper Claesz., widower of Pietertge Jans, was betrothed to Trijntje Claes, widow of Anthonie Verbruggen (DTB 414/261).
Intro Text: Op ten 27 octobris 1612 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Ael Huygens weduwe [crossed out: huysvrou] van Cornelis Herwayer. Postscript: Dese penningen zyn betaelt als blyct int leste van de ceedel by Gerrit Jacobsz. vertoont aen Aper Claesz. ende Jacob Symonsz. voochden van de kinderen, den 25 january 1613. Actum den 15 november.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Samuel Godijn
Biographical Notes: The brothers Samuel and Daniel Godijn were both of South Netherlandich origin. Samuel was born in Antwerp. Their parents are tentatively identified as Jean Godin and Barbe Vivien (see also the TEXT of R 1018).  They were both first noted in Amsterdam in 1602 when they invested 3000 f. in the first subscription for V.O.C. shares (Van Dillen, Het oudste aandeelhoudersregister, p. 96).  In 1623 and 1624, Samuel Godijn, who was primarily a wool merchant, was one of the directors of the W.I.C. (Johannes de Laet, History of the W.I.C.)  He paid a tax of 400 f. in 1631, at which time he lived on the East side of the Keysersgracht (Kohier, fol. 187, p. 43). Johanna Godin, daughter of Samuel Godijn and Anna Anselmo Anthonijsdr.,  was married to Jacob Trip, a member of the famous Dordrecht family of cannon and ammunition dealers, on 14 February 1634 (Elias. Vroedschap, pp. 548-9.) Another daughter named Cecilia married Hendrick Trip (Jacob's brother) on 31 March 1633. After her death, he remarried with Ann Anselmo (R 24909 of Montias2). Samuel Godijn's inventory was taken after his death on 29 November 1633 (NA 694B, cited by W. Fock in Oud Holland, 112(1998), note 179.) On 31 October 1633, the honorable Joris van Hengel (cited in the NOTES to R 25443 of Montias2) and Jan Leschevin (probably of R 29988 of Montias2), merchants, declared that they had seen the notice written by Gonsalvo Romitti (of INVNO 302), who, besides themselves, had arbitrated the differences between the honorable Samuel and Daniel Godin, on one side, and the honorable Jacques Schot (or Scott) (cited in the NOTES to R 29995 of Montias2), who married the widow of Charles Godin (Rachel le Carlier) on 17 August 1615,  on the other. The arbiters confirmed that Samuel and Daniel Godin, according to a testament (?) of 1607, were to give to each of the heirs of Charles Godin  200 pounds Vl. (NA 694B, film 4980, Not. J. Warnaerts). Rachel Godin (married to David van Baerle of INVNO 118) was the daughter of Charles Godin and of Rachel le Carlier. Charles Godin seems to have been the brother of Jean Godin, the putative father of Samuel and Daniel Godin. Charles Godin was a merchant based in Frankfort (for details, see Elias, Vroedschap van Amsterdam, pp. 562 and 579). On 14 September 1627, Daniel Godijn notified Abraham Luls that he had sold him 50 bolts of cotton lijnwaet at the price of 10 f. 10 st. per bolt, which had not been paid for. Luls wished to avail himself of Godijn's promise that he would take the merchandise back if desired (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven R.P.G. 78(1933), p. 633). For further details on the Godijn family, see the TEXT of R 1018.  One of the items sold in the present sale, not included in INVNO 902, was a Bible in 8 parts (no doubt illuminated), which was bought for 150 f. by Hans Walschart.
Intro Text: Op ten 30 octobris 1613 zyn ten versoecke van Samuel Godijn vercoft dese naervolgende goederen. Postscript: By quitantie van Samuel in dato 10 marty 1614 vertoont betaelt te sijn.

Residence: Op de N.Z. Achterburchwal in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 16e junij 1627 zyn vercoft de goederen achtergelaten bij Anna Marcus.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Cornelis and Jan Witsen
Biographical Notes: On Cornelis and Jan Witsen, see the TEXT of INVNO 294.
Intro Text: Op den 28e decembris 1627 zyn ten versoecke van Cornelis ende Jan Witsen vercocht de naervolgende goederen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Ambrosius Jansz. wine dealer
Residence: Ten huyse van Gerrit Jacobsz. in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 22 December 1612, Ambrosius Jansz., from Haarlem, wine dealer, 21, living op den Dam, was betrothed to Gertruyd Pieters, assisted by her mother Josyntge Claes (DTB 416/339). On 20 September 1628, Ambrosius Jansz., wine dealer, brought 325 f. to the Orphan Chamber on behalf of the children of the wine dealer Pieter van Balen of R 27417,  who was buried on 6 April 1621 (see the NOTES to R 27417 of Montias2 and WK 5073/789). On 30 November 1630, the widow of Ambrosius Jansz., who was carrying on her late husband's trade on the Rockin, was insinuated along with many other wine dealers (NA 910).  The widow of Ambrosius Jansz. was betrothed to the jeweler and goldsmith Hans Jansz. (of R 21745) on 5 April 1631 (DTB 437/145). She claimed that she had been a widow 41 months at the time of remarriage, but this may have been a slight exaggeration. In any case, Ambrosius Jansz. must have died not long after his presentation before the Orphan Chamber.
Intro Text: Den 29e decembris 1627 ten versoecke van Ambrosius Jansz. wijncooper

Biographical Notes: The late Andries Huijsman was a retail seller of hats. Note that the father of Andries Huysman (of R 28955 of Montias2), was named Harmen Huysman, who was born about 1560. The owner of the present inventory may have been his grandson.
Intro Text: Op den 3en april 1628 zyn vercocht de goederen achtergelaten bij Andries Huijsman in zyn leven hoedecramer te betalen uts.

Residence: Inde Biscopstraet by de Zuydekerck in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Cathalintgen Bultsingh was the sister of Hester Bultsingh (I) (of R 36735 of Montias2)  who was married to Fransoijs Reijniersz.  For these and  other members of Bultsingh (alias Bulsinck)  family, see the NOTES to R 36735 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Den 5e may 1628 ... achtergelaten by Cathalyntgen Bultsingh

Additional Names: wife of Elias Eliasz.
Residence: Op de Heerengraft by de Woffstraet in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 21 January 1622, Elias Eliaess, goldsmith, 22 years old, assisted by his father Elias Claesz., living in the Minnebroerssteegh, was betrothed to Willemptje Jans, 28, assisted by her mother Floryntje Geumes, living on the Rusland (        Oud Holland, 3(1885), p. 142.) On 29 August 1623, Elias Claesz. was a witness at the baptism of Sara, the daughter of the painter Nicolaes Elias Pickenoy. Elias Claesz. was the father of both Elias Eliasz. and Claes Eliasz. (the painter Nicolaes Eliasz. Pickenoy of R 8367 of Montias2 (see also      Oud Holland, 4(1886), p.82).
Intro Text: Den 5 february 1628 zyn de goederen vercoft achtergelaten by Willempje Jans huysvrouw van Elias Eliasz.

Biographical Notes: The owner of the goods sold in this sale has not been identified. He is unlikely to Jan Martsz., cloth dealer, in view of the small proceeds of the sale (507 f.) and of the address (the cloth merchant lived on the Nieuwen Dijck). The stone merchant Jan Martsz. is excluded from consideration as the owner of this inventory because he was still alive in 1631 (Maandblad Amstelodamum 53(1966), p. 1).
Intro Text: Op den 11en september 1621 zijn vercoft de nagelaten goederen van Jan Martsz.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Harmen Albertsen
Residence: Op te Deventer Houtmarckt in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: An individual by the name of Herman Albertsz. was dean of the huistimmerluiden- and kistemackersgilde in 1625 (see the deposition of 18 February 1626 in Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven, R.G.P. 78(1933), pp. 592-3.) His house, situated on the Deventer lumber market, next to Bartolomeus van Gennep of R 27481, is cited in the NOTES to that record. He may have been the brother of Lenardt Albertsz., stone merchant, who lived in that proximity (Kohier, fol. 217vo, p. 50).
Intro Text: Op den 3en september anno 1622 zijn ten versoecke van Harmen Albertsen vercocht dese naervolgende goederen.

Residence: Op de Nieuwen Dijck in 't Postpaert in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: The house het Postpaert on the Nieuwendijk across the Sint Jacobstraat still exists today (see the photograph in J.G. Kam, Restauratie van 'het Postpaert' aan de Nieuwendijk (nr. 113, Maandblad Amstelodamum, 66(1979), p. 17). The house had been bought in 1611 by the bookbinder Barent van Erpenbeeck, at which time the sign de Witte Engel hung in front. It is probable that Jan Jansen Postpaert was renting the house at the time of his death (J.G. Kam, Waar was dat huis in de Warmoesstraat, p. 18).
Intro Text: Op den 6en decembris 1624 [sijn vercoft de goederen ...] achtergelaten by Jan Jansz. Postpaart.

Residence: Op de Niezyts Voorburchwal by de Narensteech in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 10e marty anno 1622 zyn vercocht dese naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Ancke Hanses.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of [left blank] Kistemacker
Intro Text: Opten 18en october 1625, ten versoecke van [left blank] Kistemacker

Residence: Achter de brouwerije van de Eenhooren in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: The late owner of the goods may be identical with a frequent buyer at auction in 1624 and 1625 named Giertge Willems. The brewery den Eenhoorn, owned by Jacob Dircksz. Brouwer in 1624, was located in the Haarlemmerstraet near the Eenhoornsluijs.
Intro Text: Op den 26 martij anno 1626 zyn vercocht dese naervolgende goederen achtergelaten bij Giertge Willems.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Saertge van Bergem
Intro Text: Den 9en april 1626 zijn ten versoecke van Saertge van Bergem vercocht dese naervolgende goederen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Mr. Pieter Jacobsz.
Residence: Op de hoeck van de Dirck van Assen steech in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 23en april 1626 zijn ten versoecke van Mr. Pieter Jacobsz. verkoft de naervolgende goederen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Jochem Blau
Residence: Op Welenburch int Witte Hart in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 17en junij 1627 zijn ten versoecke van Jochem Blau vercocht de navolgende goederen

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Dirck Claesz.
Intro Text: 29 july 1626 zijn ten versoecke van Dirck Claesz. vercoft dese naervolgende goederen.

Additional Names: and his wife Jacobge Jacobs
Biographical Notes: The owner of the goods sold in this sale is probably identical with the dyer Hendrick Claesz.  Claes Hendricksz. (of R 7667 of Montias2) who bought most of the works of art in the sale, was the son of the dyer Hendrick Claesz. On the company of dyers formed by Hendrick Claesz. and his brother Willem Hendricksz., which operated from 1631 to 1633, see the NOTES to R 29847 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Den 20e april 1635 zijn de naervolgende goederen van Hendrick Claesz. ende Jacobge Jacobs vercocht.

Residence: In de St. Angnietiestraet in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Den 26e julij 1635 zijn de naergleatene goederen van Trijntgen Baltes vercocht.

Residence: Ten huyse van Daniel Jansz. in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Den 2en augusti [1635] zijn de naergelatene goederen van Aeltge Hendricx vercocht.

Residence: Ten huyse van Daniel Jansz. in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Den 18e september [1635]  zijn de naergelatene goederen van Aeltge Jacobs vercocht.

Additional Names: widow of Pieter Appelman
Biographical Notes: On 11 April 1625, Pieter Cornelis Appelman, from Amsterdam, 25 years old, living in the N.Z. Achterburchwal, was betrothed to Jannetje van Coengracht widow of Jan Lucasz., schipper (7 years a widow), living on the Zeedijck (DTB 670/46). It is not clear whether the name of the widow, Jannetje Lucas, refers to her first husband's name or to her own patronymic. Pieter Appelman, apparently living in the same house, de Blauwe Hen, as Sybrand Melchiorsz. Appelman bought lots for 1 f. 16 st. in the Haarlem lottery of 1606 (GAA 117/59 F 873). On 9 April 1622, Pieter Appelman, in association with Jan Geurtsz. and Barent Harmansz. set up a wasbleekerij (bleaching works)  (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven R.G.P. 78(1933), p. 445.) Jan Geurtsz. may be identical with the procureur of R 21492 of Montias2 or with Jan Geurtsz. van den  Bogaert, the brother of the painter Adriaen van den Bogaert of R 20920 of Montias2.  Barent Harmensz. (of R 26683 of Montias2) was probably the lakenstopper portrayed by Rembrandt in the Night Watch.  On 17 November 1628, Pieter Appelman, coming from the Zeedijck, was buried in the N.K. (8 f. were paid on his behalf to the church) (DTB 1054/43vo.)
Intro Text: Den 23en january 1636 zijn de naergelaten goederen van Jannitge Lucas weduwe van Pieter Appelman vercocht.

Residence: Op de N.Z. Achterburchwal achter Arent Bouwers spijcker in Amsterdam.
Biographical Notes: The widower of Maritge Theunis was named Michiel Martsen. It may have been Michiel Martsen, with his (unnamed) wife Maritge Theunis, who had his daughter Fronken baptized in the Lutheran Church on 8 December 1620 (DTB 138/281).
Intro Text: Op den 25e julij 1623 zyn vercocht de achtergelaten goederen van Maritge Theunis.

Residence: Op de O.Z. Achterburchwal in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Den 29e january 1613 zyn ten versoecke van de heerem weesmeesteren vercocht de goederen achtergelaten by Griet Jans.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of the heirs of Guilliaum du Paep
Biographical Notes: The wife of Gieliaem de Paep, named Griet del Paep, was buried on 30 October 1612 (DTB 1043/123).
Intro Text: Opten 28e february 1613 zyn ten versoeck van den erffgenamen van Guiliaum du Paep vercoft de naervolgende goederen. Postscript: Dese penningen zyn betaelt volgende de rekeningen ... den 15en november 1614.

Residence: Op de O.Z. Voorburgwal in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: An earlier inventory was made of the goods left by Jacques Verbeeck on 27 October 1612 (INVNO 544). The INTRO and TEXT of INVNO 544 in R 450 of Montias 1 supply the biographical data for the late Verbeeck.
Intro Text: Op den 27en marty 1613 zyn ten versoecke van den heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Jacques Verbeeck. Postscript: Is geblecken by gemaeckte quitancie van alle de erfgenamen onderteyckent ... alle betaelt te sijn op date den 9 meye 1614 door Gerrit Jacobsz. vertoont ...en 30 Decembris 1617 in all [...]

Additional Names: and Aeltge Pijnappel
Biographical Notes: Guillaume Petiteau, merchant from Antwerp, was first noted in Amsterdam in 1594 (Gelderblom, Zuid-Nederlandse kooplieden p. 311). On 7 March 1606, Guillame Petiteau, from Antwerp, 28 years old, living in the Nes, assisted by his father Jeronimus Petiteau and his mother Tanneken van Liesvelt, was betrothed to Aeltgen Pijnappels, from 's Hertogenbosch, living op de Plaets (de Dam), assisted by her uncle Ambrosius Kemp (of R 37055). Tanneken (alias Anneken) van Liesvelt was the mother of Cornelia Kieff, the wife of the painter and art dealer Jan Basse (of R 7637), of Catharina Kieff, married to Israel Gerbier (of R 23616), and of Anna Kieff, married to Pieter Rodenburgh. Guillame Petiteau was a merchant who did business with France. In 1602, he imported sugar syrop from La Rochelle, which he sold to Guillaume Wijs, sugar refiner (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven R.G.P., 69(1929), p. 602.)  He invested 900 f. in the first subscription to the V.O.C. on behalf of Pieter Boll Cornelisz. living in Haarlem (Van Dillen, Het oudste aandeelhoudersregister, pp. 248-9.) He was a shooter in the company of Adriaen Pietersz. Raep in 1603 (Oud Holland 15 (1897), p. 134). Aelten Pijnappels, wife of Gielgaem Piettoes (sic), was buried on 10 October 1611 (DTB 1043/107). Guillaem Petiteau must have died soon after (in any case, before October 1613 when this sale was held). Hans (or Jean)  Petiteau, who received the proceeds of the auction sale with Jan Hansberch (van Hensbergen)  was a paper dealer. He was probably  a  close relative of  Guillame Petiteau. He was first noted in Amsterdam in 1623 (Gelderblom, op.cit.  p. 311). Hans Petitau and his sister, living on the Cingel, paid a tax of 75 f. in 1631 (Kohier fol. 12, p.4).  On 8 January 1635, Jan van Ceulen, acting on behalf of Bonaventura and Abraham Elsevier in Leiden, insinuated Jean Petiteau. They claimed that 300 bales of paper which they had bought from Petiteau had not been delivered. This had harmed their business and caused idleness among their workers, especially now that the wars in Germany had brought about a great scarcity of paper (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven 144(1974), p.77). On 3 August 1638, Abraham Dies[...], book dealer, 62, and  Anna Petiteau, spinster of major age, 63, declared at the request of Hendrick Braems and Jacomo van Uffele(n) (of R 7706) that Hans Petiteau, merchant in his life time and paper dealer, had died on 14 May 1637 (NA 696A, Not. J. Warnaerts). Anna Petiteau was the sister of Hans Petiteau. On 25 June 1640, the Notary Willem Hasen certified that Abraham de Hertogh was a citizen of Amsterdam and a merchant and that he was lawfully married to Juffr. Anna van Zoelen (one year). Anna van Zoelen was the only heir of Hans Petiteau. Hasen had known Hans's sister Anna Petiteau for 23 years (NA 1601, fol. 57, Not. W. Hasen).   On 27 December 1633, Jan van Hensbergen (cited in the INTRO), as husband and guardian of Elisabeth Pijnappel, Elias van Ceulen (of R 37031 of Montias 2), as husband and guardian of Susanna van Pijnappels, and Bartholomeus van Gennip (of R 27481 of Montias2), as husband and guardian of Agatha (Agnieta) Pijnappels, all daughters of Aeltje Pijnappels, gave a procuration to a resident of Den Bosch to collect moneys due to them from the late Anthony Pijnappel and Margriete Brieven (NA 595, fol. 409, Not. Lamberti). On 17 June 1650, Jan van Heynsberch (probably identical with Jan van Hensbergen) signed an agreement with 23 other creditors of Cornelis van Bruegel (cited in the NOTES to R 35467 of Montias2) in reduction of his debts (DBK 5072/972).
Intro Text: Op den 24en october 1613 zijn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten bij Guilliam Pitiou ende Aeltge Pijnappel. Postscript: Den 12 marty 1614 zyn dese betaelt als blyckt ... van Jan Hansberch ende Hans Petiteau. Actum den 22 november.

Additional Names: widow of Cornelis Pauw
Biographical Notes: On 5 August 1589, Cornelis Cornelisz. Pau, shoemaker, 27 years old, living on the Ossemarckt, assisted by his mother Lysbet Cornelis, was betrothed to Marie Gerrits, 28, livng on the O.Z. Voorburgwal, with no living parents (DTB 663/50). On 1 April 1625, Kornelis Pau, who had lived in the Hoochstraet in de 3 witte schoenen, was buried in the O.K. Bells were rung for 1 1/2 hours and 12 f. 10 f. were paid to the church (DTB 1044/17). The house de 3 witte schoenen was located in the Hoochstraet (Jaarboek Amstelodamum 3(1905)).
Intro Text: Op den 23en octobris 1627 zy vercocht de naervolgende goederen achtergelaten bij Marij Gerrits weduwe van Cornelis Pauw.

Biographical Notes: The owner of the goods was an uitdraagster. Her name is not included in Hilde van Wijngaarden's survey (notes to Scriptie).
Intro Text: Op den 6en novembris 1627 zyn vercoft de goederen .... achtergelaten bij Syntgen Outhuijsen uijtdraegster.

Additional Names: and his wife Lysbeth Dircx
Residence: Op den hoeck van de Hartestraet ingebracht
Biographical Notes: On 6 August 1579, Henrick Gerritsz., from Groningen, was betrothed to Lysbeth Dirxdr., widow of Jochum Heijnrixs.  He was literate, she not (DTB 401/78). On day following the present sale, some clothing, totaling 56 f. 7 st., ingebracht from the Hartestraet, was sold at the request of Abraham Anthonisz., the well-known Remonstrant activist.
Intro Text: Op den 12en decembris 1628 zyn vercocht ...  van Hendrick Gerritsz. ende Lysbeth Dircx syn huysvrouw.

Additional Names: and his wife Hillegont Martens
Residence: Op de Hoeck van de Nieuwe Haarlemmer Sluijs in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 2 September 1621, the children of Jan Michielsz. Block, capiteijn tot water, and of Hillegont Martens (Trijn 14 and Marten 9) were said to be entitled to an inheritance of 2000 f. (WK 5073/789). In 1631, his child, who was one of the orphans recognized (bekent by the Orphan Chamber) paid a tax of 10 f. (Kohier fol. 314, p. 72).  The fact that Trijn, the child of Jan Block and Hillegond Martens, was born about 1607 suggests that Hillegond Martens cannot be identical with the woman of that name of R 29690 who was then married to Dirck Stoffelsz. who died in 1614.
Intro Text: Op den 9en april 1625 zyn vercocht de naerglatene goederen van Capteijn Jan Block ende Hillegont Martens zijn huysvrouw.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Anna van der Laen
Intro Text: 25 april 1626, ten versoecke van Anna van der Laen vercoft de navolgende goederen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Arent Bouwer, guardian of the children of Melchior Bouwer
Residence: Ten huyse van Daniel Jansz. van Beuningen
Biographical Notes: Melchior Bouwer, baptized on 21 June 1582, died on 23 August 1626. In 1621, he lived on the Keysersgracht bij de Tulp. He was a rechtsgeleerde in The Hague in 1609. He married Trijntge Lucas Rotgans (1585-1624) on 10 May 1609. For the goods sold after her death, see INVNO 824 of 10 May 1625. For further information on Trijntgen Lucas,  see R 27856 of Montias2. See also INVNO 537 for the books and other objects inherited by Melchior Bouwer from Hans Bouwer. Arent Bouwer II, at whose request the goods were sold, was the brother of Melchior Bouwer. He was the grandson of Arent Bouwer I, married to Neel Hillebrantsdr., the father of Hendrick, Jasper, Balthasar, Hans, Maritge, and Helena Bouwer. The older Arent Bouwer was buried on 17 October 1585 (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 413). Arent Bouwer II owned a packhuis on the  Ooster Voorburchwal  near the Ste. Luciensteech (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven, R.G.P., 69(1929), p. 834). On the guradianship of Arent Bouwer II over the children of Melchior Boouwer, see also  R 27856 of Montias2. The present sale, which appears to be voluntary, may actually be of the goods left in the estate of Melchior Bouwer.
Intro Text: Op huijden den 17e april 1627 zijn ten versoecke van Arent Bouwer als voocht van de kinderen van Melchior Bouwer secretaris za. vercocht dese naervolgende goederen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Adam Adamsz. van Linsbeeck
Intro Text: Den 8e november 1628 syn ten versoeck van Adam Adamsz. van Linsbeeck vercocht dese naervolgende goederen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Hendrick Lensen and Mr. Joris Dijkman on behalf of child left by Thomas Lourisz. and Giertgen Dircx van Nieuhoff
Residence: Op de Oude Heregracht in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Hendrick Lensen (or Lens) was a merchant, son of Jan Lens, wine dealer in the Kalverstraet. He married Annetge Simons Roch (Elias, Vroedschap p. 255 and R 36475 of Montias2.) On 23 August 1606, he freighted a ship with Nicolaes Balestel (de oude) of R 36475 (Winkelman, Bronnen voor de geschiedenis van het ooszeehandel  R.G.P. 184(1983), p. 305). Mr. Joris Dijckman was cantor in the Nieuwe Kerck. Lensen and Dijckman were the guardians of the child left by the late Thomas Lourisz. and Giertgen Dircx, to whom the goods sold probably belonged.
Intro Text: Den 15e january 1630 zijn ten versoecke van Henrick Lensen ende Mr. Joris Dijckman voorsanger in the Nieuwe Kerck als voogden van 't nagelatene kind van Thomas Lourisz. ende Giertgen Dircx van Nieuhoff vercocht dese naervolgende goederen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of the brothers Jan and Juriaen Roeloff together with Jan Barentsz. smith and Jan Wesselsz. as guardians of the child of Meyndert Jansz. and Aefge Roeloffsz.
Biographical Notes: The goods sold probably belonged to Meyndert Jansz. and Aelfge Roeloffs. Jan Wesselsz. was one of the guardians of the children of the late couple.  Note that two months earlier, a sale was held at the request of Harmen Roeloffsz. and Jan Wesselsz., guardians of the child left by Pieter Evertsz. and Vroutgen Hendricks (INVNO 939).
Intro Text: Ten selven dag [16 january 1630] zijn ten versoecke van Jan ende Jeuriaen Roeloff gebroeders mitsgaders Jan Barentsz. smith and Jan Wesselsz. als voogden van 't naergelatene kint van Meyndert Jansz. ende Aefge Roeloffs echteluyden vercoft de naervolgende goederen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Herman Roeloffsz. and Jan Wesselsz. as guardians over the child left by Pieter Evertsz. and Vroutgen Hendricks
Residence: Op Uijlenburgh tegens de Rapensevest over in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Note that Jan Wesselsz. and Jan and Jeuriaen Roeloffsz. were guardians over the child left by Meyndert Jansz. and Aefge Roeloffs in INVNO 938 of 16 January 1630. The goods sold in this sale probably belonged to Pieter Evertsz. and Vroutgen Hendrix. Pieter Evertsz. may be the kistemaecker (coffin maker, joiner)  whose widow appeared on behalf of her seven children before the Orphan Chamber on 30 August 1632 (see the NOTES to R 30613 of Montias2).
Intro Text: Op den 6e november 1629 zijn ten versoecke van Herman Roeloffsz. and Jan Wesselsz. als voogden over 't gelatene kint van Pieter Evertsz. ende Vroutgen Hendricks vercocht dese naervolgende goederen, te betalen etc...

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Niclaes Cocquus and Pieter de Bitter as guardians over the children left by Femmetge Teunis.
Biographical Notes: Femmetge Teunis was the sister of Maritge Teunis (the wife of the painter Barent Thonisz. of R 21348), and the widow of Rutgert Jansz., whose portrait was recorded in this inventory. Rutger Jansz. was perhaps identical with Rutger Jansz. van Dorssen at whose request goods were sold in 1601 (R 690).  Pieter de Bitter was the guardian of the child of Maritie's  first marriage with Jurriaen Fredericxsz. An initial inventory, taken without appraisals, was made on 16 February 1630. Only four portraits were described by subject. The remaining six schilderijtgens were untitled (GAA, not. Westsfrisius, no. 563A). On Nicolas Cocques (or Cocqus), see R 20336 of Montias2. The house of Femmetge Teunis, which was said to be close by the old Glashuis, seems to be the one on the Kloveniersburgwal, next to no. 38, with which it had a common trap en opgang (I. van Eeghen, De restauratie van Kloveniersburgwal 38, Maandblad Amstelodamum, 62(1975), p. 22.) The Oude Glashuis was the glass making plant of Jan Jansz. Karel (later owned by his son-in-law Floris Soop)  on the Kloveniersburgwal. The woman named Femmetje who bought lots in the Haarlem lottery and was said to be living in the house of Jan Jansz. Carel de jonge, was probably identical with Femmetge Theunis of the present inventory  (see Maandblad Amstelodamum 62(1975), p. 134). On Pieter Cocquu (or Cocques), see the NOTES to R 20336 of Montias2; on Pieter de Bitter, the NOTES to R 23618 of Montias2. It is most doubtful whether the following deposition refers to the same Femmetje Theunis. On 4 September 1635, Joris van Nieulandt, 35, coffin maker (not identical with the father of the painter Adriaen van Nieulandt of the same name), 35, living in the St. Jansstraet, and Albert Dircksz., ebony worker, 35, living in the Stoofsteech, declared at the request Femmetje Theunis, who was once married to Bouwen Lourensz., cloth finisher (droochschilder) that they had known Lourens Bouwens who had gone as a sailor (bootsman) on the ship Prince Willem to the East Indies and they are also aware that Lourens was the son of the petitioner. He was the brother of Emertje Bouwens (NA 597, Not. Lamberti). According to Bredius, Femmetje Teunis of the present inventory  was the mother of the well-known merchant David Rutgers. Femmetge did have a son named Rutger Rutsz. who bought a work of art at the sale of her goods (R 37186 of Montias2)There but he was almost certainly not identical with the silk cloth dealer David Rutgers III, the son of David Rutgers II and of Josua Lamberts, the merchant with whom Bredius apparently confused him.  On David Rutgers II and III, see the NOTES to R 37186.
Intro Text: Den 25e february 1630 zyn ten versoecke van Niclaes Cocquus ende Pieter de Bitter als voogden van de nagelatene kinderen van Femmetge Teunis vercocht dese naervolgende goederen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Pieter de Bitter
Biographical Notes: On Pieter de Bitter, whose relation to Willem de Coster has not been ascertained, see R 23618 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Op den 23e february 1630 zijn ten versoecke van Pieter de Bitter vercocht de goederen achtergelaten by Willem de Coster.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Jacob Jansz. and Leendert Cornelisz., the uncles of the children left by Arent Gerritsz. and Marij Cornelis
Residence: Op de Chingel by de Doelen in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: The goods sold probably belonged to Arent Gerritsz. and Marij Cornelis. The children of Arent Gerritsz., living on the other side of the Breestraet (thus near the Singel), paid a tax of 20 f. in 1631 (Kohier, fol. 18, p. 5). The uncles of the orphan children, at whose request the sale was held, were Leendert Cornelisz., lumber dealer, and Jacob Jansz., beer carrier. On 17 September 1610, a painter named Arent Gerritsz. was named guardian over Claes Jansz. van Soest (WK 5073/513, fol. 138).
Intro Text: Den eersten martj 1630 door last van de heeren weestmeesteren Jacob Jansz. bierdrager ende Leendert Cornelisz. houtcoper als oomen van den achtergelaten kinderen van Arent Gerritsz. ende Marij Cornelis vercocht dese naervolgende goederen.

Biographical Notes: The guardian of the child or children of Junnepgen Melis was named Pieter Jansz. Blaeuwenhelm. He seems to have been the brother of Jan Jansz. Blaeuwenhaen (or Blaeuwenhelm) of R 36448 (he appeared as a witness to the baptism of Pieter, son of Johannes Blaeuwenhelm, the son of Jan Jansz., in 1648). He may be identical with Pieter Blaeuwenhaen, the father of Maghtelda Blaeuwenhaen of INVNO 239 and of Maritge Blaeuwenhaen, cited in the TEXT of R 157 of Montias1.
Intro Text: [de nagelatene goederen van] Junnepgen Melis

Residence: In de Vreesys Armsteegh in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Den 26 marti [1635] zijn de naergelatene goederen van Reickel van Beringe vercocht.

Biographical Notes: There were two individuals living about the same time named Abraham van Eijndhoven. The owner of the goods in the present sale, who lived on the Angeliersgracht, died before 12 December 1635, the date of the sale. The other lived near the Beurs on the Uijterse steechgen on 23 May 1637. It is not known which of the two -- the owner of the goods in this sale who died in 1635 or the one who lived on the Uijterse steechgen in 1637,  was married to whom. On 13 November 1621, Abraham van Eijndhoven, 26, assisted by his father Guill[aume] van Eyndhoven (of R 27656 of Montias2), living on the Coelevriersgracht, was betrothed to Jannetje Willems, no living parents, assisted by her sisters Tryntje and Willeges(?) Willems, living on Uijlenburgh (DTB 426/65). On 4 April 1627, Abraham van Eijndhoven and Jannetje Willems had their son Willem baptized in the N.K. in the presence of Hessel Gerritsz. (presumably the printmaker and cartographer of R 20968 of Montias2) (DTB 40/390). On 7 August 1633, Abraham and Jannetje had their son Abraham baptized in the Remonstrant Church (DTB 301/2). The other couple had children baptized about the same time in the N.K.  On 2 November 1630, Abraham van Einthoven and Sara van Eijnhoven [nee Corput] had their son Abraham baptized in the N.K. (DTB 4/108).  On 16 January 1633, Abraham van Eijnthoven and Sara van de Corput had their son Isaack baptized in the N.K. in the presence of Alijda van Corenput (DTB 41/231). Some clothing in the present sale was bought by Abraham Bouwensz., guardian of the children. This individual, who may have been a painter, is cited in the NOTES to R 32474. But this still does not resolve the problem of identifying the owner of the goods in this sale.
Intro Text: Den 12e december 1635 de naergelaten goederen van Abraham van Eijnthoven vercocht dese naervolgende goederen.

Biographical Notes: Michiel Colijn, a well-known book seller, and his wife Trijntje Markes (Marcus), had a child baptized in the O.K. on 9 October 1609 (DTB 4/258). For other biographical information, see the NOTES to R 22124 of Montias2. Michiel Colijn  paid a tax of 60 f. in 1631, living op 't Water (Kohier, fol. 37, p. 9). On 18 December 1623, the engraver Pieter van der Keere offered Michiel Colijn a number of plates, which he refused to accept (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven, R.G.P. 78(1933), p.515). He signed the Remonstrant petition of 1628.
Intro Text: Den 15 marij 1638 zijn de nagelate boecken kaerten konstplaten houte figuren achtergelaten bij Michiel Colijn vercocht.

Biographical Notes: Hans van Kattenburch may have been the father of Otto and Dirck van Cattenburch, cited in the NOTES to R 25097.
Intro Text: Op den 11e December 1624 zyn ten versoeck van [de weduwe van] Hans Kattenburch vercocht dese naervolgende goederen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Salomon Pietersz.
Biographical Notes: Salomon Pietersz. had goods sold on at least four other occasions (R 871, 872, 875,  and R 787). He may have been a dealer in paintings (see R 872).
Intro Text: Op den 27 junij anno 1624 zijn ten versoecke van Salomon Pietersz. vercocht dese naervolgende goederen.

Biographical Notes: Mr. Willem, schoolmaster, cannot be identical with the well-known schoolmaster Willem Bartgens who died in Zwolle in 1638.
Intro Text: Op den 11en january anno 1625 zyn vercocht de naergelaten goederen van Mr. Willem schoolmeester

Additional Names: and Tryn Jans
Biographical Notes: On 24 April 1610, Jan Adamsz., from Leeuwarden, wheelwright, 23, living on the Breestraet, no living parents, assisted by his swager Baerten Rywers, was betrothed to Trijntje Jans Tubbegen, 25 (DTB 414/289). It is not clear whether Tubbegen refers to Trijntje Jans's family name or her place of origin (Tübingen). On 18 July 1624, the masters of the Orphan Chamber named Gerrit Jacobsz. Haringh (the bode of the Orphan Chamber) along with Egbert Garbrantsz., house carpenter, as guardians over the three children left by Jan Adamsz., wheelwright,  and Tryn Jans (WK 5073/513).
Intro Text: Op den 10e Augustus 1624 zyn vercocht de naergelaten goederen van Jan Adamsz. wieldraijer ende Tryn Jans

Residence: Op de Nieuwe brugh in't Paal huijsgen in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Jacob Pietersen, the father of the painter Pieter Codde (of R 32514),  was paalknecht, a small municipal office which involved the collection of an excise tax  levied on ships that docked near the Nieuwe Brugge. The address of the deceased (and his known date of death) clearly establish the identification. He was born about 1567 and was buried on 25 November 1624.  He  married Marij Jans (born about 1568) on 26 July 1592. She survived him. Their son Pieter Codde was baptized in 1599.  Some of the goods that were appraised and sold at the prices set by sworn appraisers (schatsers) were bought by the son Jan Jacobsz. Kod (baptized in 1597), some by the painter Pieter Codde, and some by his daughter Claer Jacobs (baptized in 1593, married to Claes Hectors, koekebakker on the Nieuwen Dijck in de drie duijven). The painter Pieter Codde should be distinguished from Pieter Claesz. Kod, rope-maker, of INVNO 646, who was related to the poet Pieter Codde. For all these family relations, see Ch. Dozy, Pieter Codde de schilder en de dichter,      Oud Holland 2(1884), pp. 44, 55, and 67.
Intro Text: 17 february 1625 achtergelaten goederen van Jacob Pietersen asslager van de schepen. Postscript: De reste van dese bovenstaende goederen zyn de kinderen aengeschat ende volgen opde ander zyde van dit blad.

Residence: In de Koetsbaen bij de Regulierspoort in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 8e april anno 1621 zyn vercocht de nagelate goederen van Jacob Gerritsen.
Den 28e juny 1622 zyn vercocht de nagelaten goederen van Aeffge Egberts.

Additional Names: widow of Jan Tronquoij
Biographical Notes: On 3 August 1591, Jean de Tronquoy, from Namen (Namur), 35 years old, living with Doctor Silla, was betrothed to Margaret de Bruijn, from Brussels, assisted by her father Denijs de Bruijne and her mother Maycken Etterbeeck (DTB 406/59). He remarried with Aachie Bremans on 25 November 1616. In 1631, Jan Torcquoij, living int Princehoff near the  N.Z. Westerburchwal, paid a tax of 5 f. (Kohier, fol. 243vo, p. 56). In September (?) 1633 (exact date illegible), Jan Tronquoy, deurwaerder of the Admiralty, named Jasper Brant to represent him before the Commissary for Small Affairs (NA 372, fol. 139, Not. W. Cluyt). It is not clear whether Jean Tronquoi, the husband of Aachie Bremans, is identical with Jan Denijs Tronqois, the son of Maria Deymans de Jonge, who had his portrait painted by Jan Lievens, according to a deposition dated 30 April 1682.The portrait would have been painted some time between 1652 and 1666 when Lievens was in Amsterdam (Bredius, Künstler-inventare, p. 201-202).
Intro Text: Op huyden den 28e april 1650 compareerde voor my Joost van Ven notaris ende de naergenoemde getuijgen Jouffr. Aachie Bremans, weduwe van Jan Tronquoij saliger, ende verclarde hoe dat haer man by testament haer gelaten hadde boedelhouster, doch doen sy schuldich was haer konten te bewijsen ende te voldoen ende ten minste ter hinl. recht van legitime portie twelck bedragen sal ten minst vier duysent car. gulden, synde voor beyde haere ongetrouwt dochteren acht duysent gulden, en dat sy comparant geleden heeft soo voor de schade soo door borchtochte voor haer overleden soon beschadigt als onder groote oppressie schaden ende verliesen so wel door haer dochters [etc..]

Additional Names: and his wife Maritgen Selijns
Residence: Op de O.Z. Voorburgwal in de Muijsentorn in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: The wine dealer Willem Selijns (I)  was born on 9 December 1567. He witnessed the baptism of Angnieta, daughter of Wolphert Webber, on 15 June 1608 (R 34387 of Montias2). He married Maria van Dort (called Maritge Selijns in the INTRO to this inventory). He died on 10 October 1617 (Nederlandsche Leeuw 45(1927), col. 114).  He was the brother of Jan Selijns I (who married Appolonia Sprenckhuysen), of Hendrick Selijns I who died in 1606 (the father of Jan Hendricksz, Selijns of R 34387 of Montias2), of Anna Selijns (who married Thomas van Daken), of Niesje Selijns (who married, first, Joost van Bogaert, on 2 February 1618, and, second,  Hendrick Coeck), and of Stijntje Selijns (who married Jan Pietersz. Vlasboom) (Nederlandsche Leeuw, loc. cit.) He is not to be confused with his nephew  Willem Selijns II (of INVNO 1197) who was the son of Jan Selijns I. Willem Selijns II married, first Susanna Rijckaert (on 12 May 1621) and, second, Susanna van Couwenbergh (INVNO 1197). It was apparently Jan Willemsz. Selijns, the son of Willem Selijns II of the present inventory, who married  Angnieta, the daughter of Wolphert Webber (of R 20317 of Montias2), baptized in 1608 (see above)  on 23 August 1630. Jan Willemsz.  Selijns was at that time widower of Anne de Marez and was about 37 years old (born circa 1592). The house  Muijsentooren on the O.Z. Ooster Voorburgwal was owned by the wine dealer Jan Willemsz. Calckoen (married to Aeltgen Temminck) in 1624 (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 656). On Pieter Seulin's relation to Matthis van Ceulen, see the TEXT of R 81 of Montias1.  More research is needed to clarify the family relation, if any, between Willem Seulijns and Pieter Seulin of INVNO 1306.
Intro Text: Op den 23e april anno 1618 zijn vercocht de goederen naegelaten bij Willem Selijns ende zijn huijsvrouw Maritgen Selijns achtergelaten hebbende vier kinderen genaemt Nisgen, Aeriaentgen, Annetgen en Jan Selijns.

Purpose: inventory made at request of creditors
Biographical Notes: It is likely that the owner of the goods was an armorer. Jan Claesz. was apparently insolvent.
Intro Text: Inventaris ende specificatie van de goederen bevonden in den boel van Jan Claesz. Harnasveger. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert ten huyse van Jan Claesz. Harnasveger gestaen in de Breestraet binnen deser stede van Amsterdam den 22 septembris 1611 ter presentie en versoeck van verscheijde zyne crediteuren.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at the request of his creditors.
Residence: On the Nieuwendijck daer de koevoet uythangt in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Emanuel Pelt, the son of Philips Pelt (of R 28903 of Montias2) was baptized in the Lutheran church  on 11 December 1605 (DTB 138/162). He married Anna Verpoorten at some unknown date (before the following baptism). On 21 September 1634, Emanuel Pelt had his daughter Elisabeth baptized in the Lutheran Church in the presence of Abraham Pelt (II)  and Elisabeth Barents (DTB 140/124). On 29 November 1635, Emanuel Pelt had his daughter Anna baptized in the same church in the presence of Hans Verpoorten, Anna and Susanna Pelt (DTB 140/175). On 17 June 1640, he had his daughter Kristina baptized in the same church in the presence of Fransois Lodowycksz. (of the above INTRO)   and Sara Vermeeren (DTB 140/397). Emanuel Pelt  also was a buyer at auction (R 34657 of Montias2).  He seems to  have  been a spices merchant (as his business partner Franchoijs Lodewijcx surely was). On the Pelt family, see the comprehensive genealogy in M. Simon Thomas, Onze IJslandvaarders in de 17de en 18de eeuw, Amsterdam, 1935, appendix G.
Intro Text: Faillit inventory of Emanuel Pelt, son of Philips Pelt (of R 28903 of Montias2).  Franchoys Lodewycksz., his business partner and his brother-in-law  (the husband of Emanuel's sister Catharina ative) was surety for the inventory and promised that no items would be withdrawn from this inventory. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert ende beschreven ten overstaen [van de commissarissen] den negenden november anno 1643.

Op ten 10en october 1605 zyn ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Britge Symons. Postscript: 170 f. 18 st. te tellen aen Claes Hermansz. de voocht van de kinderen van Gerrit Willemsz. Plemp den 5 January 1606.

Residence: Op 't Regulierspoort bij 't Walepadt in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 17 February 1601, Abraham de Goijer, 20 years old, from Eulenburgh, was betrothed to Trijntje Barents (DTB 409/336). On 4 December 1636 he was betrothed for the second time with Elisabeth Suijers (DTB 430/340). His children from the first marriage were said to be of the following ages at the time Abraham de Goijer appeared before the Orphan Chamber after the death of his first wife on 16 July 1621: Huych 17, Weijntgen, 15, Jannetge, 10, and Barent, 4 (WK 5073/709, fol. 184vo.).  All but Huych (Hugo) and Barent had died by the time this inventory was taken. For other details on Abraham de Goijer, see R 24908 of Montias2.
Intro Text: [...damaged by fire ...] buyten de Regulierspoort bijt Walepadt deser stede beschreven door mij Benedict Baddel by den hove van Holanndt geadmiteerde Notaris 't Amsterdam residerende ten versoecke van den eersame Sr. Johannes Treeckels coopman deser stede soo vor hem selven als voor d'eersame Philips Mattheussen end Joris Treeckels, alle drij als testamentel[ijcke] executeurs van den testamemt des voors. overledenen, administrateuren van de nagelatene goederen ende voochdden over sijne onmondige  erffgenamen ten overstaen van de voors. Sr. Johannes Treeckels midtsgaders van Hugo ende Barent de Goijer des voors. saliger Abraham de Goijer twee kinderen ende ter presentie van Christoffel van Akerlaken ende Johannes Harmansz. als getuijgen op dijnsdagh den achthienden dagh der maendt Martij des Jaer 1653.

Additional Names: goods sold at the request of Tryn Claes
Intro Text: Op den 30 may 1624 zyn ten versoecke van Tryn Claes vercocht dese naervolgende goederen

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Aeltje Willems
Biographical Notes: Aeltje Willems may have been the wife of the bookbinder Jan Benningh of R 26500 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Op den 14 juny [1624] ten versoecke van Aeltje Willems vercocht.

Residence: By den Jan Rooden Poort in Amsterdam.
Biographical Notes: Jan Henrixsz. smith, who may have been the son of Henrick Jansz. smith at the same address,  living on the North side of the Jonge Roelenstege, paid a tax of 4 f. in 1585 (Van Dillen, Amsterdam, p. 154.)
Intro Text: Op den 28 setpembris anno 1602 ter versoecke van de Regenten van 't weeshuys vercoft 't naervolgend goet achtergelaten by Jan Henricxsz. smit te betalen met gereet gelt.

Residence: In de Niewsyts dwarstraet in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Engebert van der Voech, born in 1560, married Trijn Volckertsdr. on 26 June 1584. She was the daughter of Vockert Syvertsz., lumber dealer op 't Water in de gulden Swaen. In 1584 van der Voech became deurwaerder vant Hoff van Hollant in The Hague. He was later an attorney (procureur) in Amsterdam in the Dwarstraet. He was buried on 16 July 1602. Their daughter named Eva married Dr. Nicolaes Tulp on 29 June 1617. She died on 3 March 1628 (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 374).
Intro Text: Den 12 November 1602 vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Engbert van den Voech.

Additional Names: goods assessed in the house of her husband Cornelis de Vetter, vettevarier
Purpose: assessment of estate left by owner
Biographical Notes: On 26 December 1598, Cornelis de Vetter, from Antwerp, living in the N.Z. Achterburchwal, widower (12 months) of Magdaleeentge van Exell, was betrothed to Francijntge Smulders, from Den Briel, 38, livng in the Jonge Coolensteegh. He was literate, she was not (DTB 408/532).
Intro Text: Den 14 november 1597 zyn ten huyse van Cornelis de Vetter in 't Gasthuyssteech geschat alle de goederen ... meublen [etc.] die zyn huysvrou Magdalena van Exselle ... besath ende dat ten overstaen van Cornelis de neeff van den kinderen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Anna Agnietings
Intro Text: Op den 16 juny anno 1598 ten versoucke van Anna Agnietings.
ten voors. daghe [27 augusti 1598] ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Machtelt Jans [crossed out; weduwe van [illegible]].

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Willem Jansz.
Intro Text: Op den 31e augusti 1598 ten versoucke van Willem Jansz. vercoft by de Bloetstraet 't geen gevolcht.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Griet Joosten
Biographical Notes: Griet Joosten may be identical with the individual of the same name who bought works of art at auction on six occasions between 1602 and 1618 (R 29744 of Montias2). She may have been an uitdraagster.
Intro Text: Ten selven dage [29 augusti 1600] opt versoeck van Griet Joosten vercoft.

Residence: Op de Oudezyts achterburchwal in den knagende hoven in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Anthony Nijs was the first recorded member of this name (there were later two others including the one in R 7616 of Montias2) in I. van Eeghen's chronicle of the family, Het geslacht Nijs ..., Jaarboek Amstelodamum 60(1968).
Intro Text: Op de 9e augusty anno 1601 ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren syn vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Anthonis Nijsz. ende zyn huysvrou .... 6 weecken.

Biographical Notes: Jan Jansz., the late owner of the goods sold, was a shoemaker.
Intro Text: Op den 25e ende 26e aprilis 1602 ter ordonnancie van de heeren weesmeesteren syn vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Jan Jansz. schoemacker in de Kalverstraet.

Residence: Opt hoeckgen van de wyde kercksteech aen de verdezyde van de Rosbart
Intro Text: Op den selven dach [27 april 1602]

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Salomon Pietersz.
Residence: ten huyse van Jan Dircx [van Beuningen] in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Salomon Pietersz. had goods sold on at least four other occasions (R 790, 850, 875 and 878). He may have been a dealer in paintings (see R 875).
Intro Text: uts. [29 augusti 1620] zyn ten versoecke van Salomon Pietersz. vercocht.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Salomon Pietersz.
Residence: uts. [ten huyse van Jan Dircx [van Beuningen] in Amsterdam]
Biographical Notes: Salomon Pietersz. had goods (mostly paintings)  sold on at least four other occasions (R 790, 850,  874 and 878). He seems to have been a painter and  a dealer in paintings. In 1606, he lived in de Schildershant on the Rokin (Haarlem lottery, 95/17 F 714). The name of his house in de Schidershant suggests he may be identical with Salomon de Schilder who also caused some goods to be sold in 1620 (R 772 of Montias1). On 14 October 1623, Salomon Pietersz., painter, 25, no living parents, assisted by his sister Mayken Pieters, living in the Restraet, was betrothed to Mayken Miters, from Haarlem, widow of Jan Jansz. Tin (one year a widow), living in Outewael (DTB 428/219). On Jan Jansz. Tin, see the NOTES to R 28501.  On 22 March 1631, Salomon Pietersz., from Amsterdam, painter, lving in Houtewael, was betrothed to Trijntje Heijndrix, 23, assisted by her aunt Bely Jacobs, living in the Breepadt. She was illiterate (DTB 437/124). He seems to have been the brother-in-law of the painter Adriaen Geurtsz. Bogaert. Salomon Pietersz. assisted his sister Geertgen Pieters upon her betrothal to Adriaen Geurtsz. on 25 January 1615 (Bredius, Künstler-inventare, p. 2033.) On 24 September 1624, a notary insinuated various innkeepers, including Salomon Pietersz., at the request of Boudewijn Hackes, master of the tax on the three gulden, concerning the poor state of their business (slappe neringe) (NA 389, fol. 144). (It is by no means certain that the innkeeper was identical with the painter and occasional art dealer).  On 16 March 1625, Solomon Pieter Pietersz., painter, and Maijke Mijters had their son Pieter baptized in the O.K. in the presence of Estranti Cornelisz. (DTB 6/110). On 9 December 1635, Salomon Pieter Pietersz. and Trijn Heindrics had their son Pieter baptized in the O.K. in the presence of Dirck Pietersz. and Sara Jelis (DTB 7/167). Dirck Pietersz., the witness to the above betrothal, may have been the painter Dirck Pietersz. Wittepaert. Dirck Pietersz. was the husband and guardian of Tuijntje Pieters, the daughter of the painter Pieter Pietersz., who in turn may have been the father of Salomon Pieter Pietersz.  On 23 October 1629, Salomon Pietersz., living in the Houte Wael, declared that the inventory made after the death of his wife Maijke Jans (Mijters?)  (goods held in common) was complete. The only works of art in this inventory were 8 portraits of the husband, the wife, and the children (INVNO 1312). On 3 September 1631, Grietge Gerrits, widow of Jan Jansz. Tin (perhaps of R 28501), assisted by her father and guardian Gerrit Pietersz., on one hand, and Griet Jans, wife of Willem Cornelisz., Tryn Symons, wife of Abraham Jansz., due to their respective husbands' absence, with Salomon Pietersz., their designated guardian, came to an agreement. Salomon Pietersz. was left 26 f. from the estate of the late Jan Jansz. Tin (NA 568, fol. 455, Not. Lamberti).  On 10 November 1631, Salomon Pietersz.  gave a procuration to his wife Trijntgen Hendricks to collect 9 f. 9 st. from Samuel Beijer in Rotterdam for two still lifes (bancket schilderijen) belonging to him (NA 913, fol. 181vo., Not. B. J. Verbeeck). On 9 December 1635, Salomon Pietersz. and Trijn Hendrix had their son Hendrick baptized in the O.K. in the presence of Dirck Pietersz. and Sara Jelis (DTB 7/67). He must have died before 19 November 1639 when Trijntje Hendriks, widow of Salomon Pietersz., was betrothed to Julius Andriessen (DTB 453/16).
Intro Text: uts. [5e september 1620] zyn ten versoecke van Salomon Pietersz. vercocht.

Biographical Notes: The presence of an appel coopsters hoet in the sale suggests that the late Stoffeltge Joosten may have bought and sold apples.
Intro Text: Op den 20 julij anno 1621 zyn vercocht de naergelaten goederen van Stoffeltge Joosten.

Residence: Op de hoeck van de Heerepadt in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 10 May 1618, Gerrit Otsen, 38, and Arent van Lijsvelt (Liesvelt), 24, wine distributors (wijnverlaters) declared at the request of Jan Pietersz. van Delft that they had received a quantity of Nantes brandy wine loaded onto a lighter (NA 200, film 111, Not. J.F. Bruyning). The widow of Gerrit Otsz., wine distributor,  appeared before the Orphan Chamber on 25 October 1628. She was a buyer at the present sale (WK 5073/789). She may be identical with the widow of Gerrit Otten, living on the O.Z. Voorburchwal, who paid a tax of 10 f. in 1631 (Kohier, fol. 133, p. 31).
Intro Text: Op den 4en januarij anno 1622 zyn vercocht de naergelate goederen van Gerrit Otsen ende dat voor gereet gelt mits dat 't gene die borgen hebben gestelt zullen mogen genieten den tijt van zes weecken.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Salomon Pietersz.
Residence: ten huyse van Jan Dircksz. in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Salomon Pietersz. had goods sold on four other occasions (R 790, 850, 874, and 875). He may have been a dealer in paintings (see R 875).
Intro Text: 16e september anno 1622 zyn ten versoecke van Salomon Pietersz. vercocht dese naervolgende goederen te betalen als voors. [op 6 weecken].

Biographical Notes: Pieter Belten de oude was born in Antwerp in 1565 and died in Amsterdam in 1626. He was married, first, to Levina Caluwart Simons (1566-1612) and, second, to Maria van Goesbergen. He was one of the firt directors of the Westindische Compagnie. He lived in a house in the St. Anthonijbreestraat near the St. Anthonijsluijs, which he had bought from Hans van der Voort (I),  the brother of the painter of the painter Cornelis van der Voort. This house was bought by Rembrandt in 1639. His son Pieter Belten de jonge (1606-1639) married Constantia Coymans in 1627.  On 16 February 1634, Hendrick Voet, Pieter Belten (de jonge) (the son of Pieter Belten de oude), together as the nearest relatives and guardians over Johannes, 7 years old, the son by his second marriage (naesoon) of Pieter Belten (de oude) with was Maria van Goesbergen, declared before the Orphan Chamber that he (Johannes) was entitled to 36,000 f. for his mother's inheritance (WK 5073/789). On 22 February 1627, Anthonie Thijsz. (cited in the INTRO), widower of Elisabeth Bachers (the daugher of Andreas Bacher), 32 years old, assisted by his uncle Anthonius Thyskens, professor of theology at Leyden University, living on the Breestraet, was betrothed to Magdalena Baltes, from Amsterdam, 27 years old, assisted by Pieter Belten de oude (DTB 432/66). On the baptisms of the couple's children, see the NOTES to R 987. After Anthony's death, she remarried with Anthony's cousin Christoffel Thijsz. in 1634. On 19 August 1635, the newly married couple had their son Christoffel baptized in the N.K. in the presence of Pieter Beltens (de jonge) (DTB 41/395). On 25 October 1637, their son, again named Cristoffel, was baptized in the N.K. in the presence of Samuel de Bacher (the son of Andreas de Bacher) (DTB 42/49).  Magdalena Beltens  and Christoffel Thijsz. sold the house on the Breestraet to Rembrandt on 5 January 1639 (Dudok van Heel in Kroniek van het Rembrandthuis 97/1-2, pp. 7-9.) On Hendrick Voet, see R 20357 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Inventaris ende specificatie van allen de goederen nagelaten bij zaliger Pieter Belten in sijn leven coopman ende burger deser Stede Amstelredamme zulx his die metter dood ontruijmt ende nagelaten heeft. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert in Amstelredamme inden sterfuijse vande voorschreven zaliger Pieter Belten gestaen op de breestraet desen 26 ende 27 november 1626 ten versoecke ende bijwesen vanden Edele Seigneurs Hendrick Voets, Antonie Thijsz., Jacob Belten ende Pieter Belten mannen van goeden geloove, etc..

Additional Names: goods sold at request of David Fransen cruijdenier
Residence: uts [Op de N.Z. Voorburchwal bij de Deventer Houtmarckt] in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: David Fransen was a buyer at an Orphan Chamber auction in 1637 (R 21903 of Montias2). In January 1633, he and Gysbert van Wieringen set up a company to deal in spices. The capital invested was to be  shared equally, as were the profits (NA 843, fol. 475, Not. Hoogeboom). See also the NOTES to R 21903.
Intro Text: ten voorschreven daghe [3 february 1625] zyn ten versoecke van David Fransen cruijdenier vercocht dese naervolgende schilderijen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Dirckge Jans
Residence: Op de Zeedijck over  de Convoij in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 29e april 1625 zijn ten versoeck van Dirckge Jans vercocht dese naervolgende goederen.
Op den 28e decembris anno 1617 zyn vercocht de goederen van Ingeltge Claesdr. naergelate hebbende een kint genaemt Claes Pietersz.

Additional Names: goods ceded to Jacob Rombouts
Purpose: goods transferred as security for loan of 1787 f. 12 st.
Biographical Notes: On Coenradt de Wilde Martensz., see R 30051 of Montias2. Rombout Jacobs is probably identical with Rombout Jacobs de jonge of R 26967 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Op den 19e september anno 1630 compareerde etc.. Coenradt de Wilde Martensz. poorter dese voors. stede d'welcke verclaerde dat onder den transporte bij hem gepasseert ten behoeve van Jacob Rombouts voor mij notaris ende sekere getuijgen in dato 14 february 1629 mede specialijk vervaet ende begrepen waren de goederen hierna genomineert, te weten: After the paintings listed and various household items, postscript: ende hij comparant nochmaels acquesterende in de voors. transport, doch onder novatie en prejudicie van dier, gaff over aen den voors. Rombouts ... een somma van 1787 gulden 12 stuivers hem comparant tevooren ten vollen verstreeckt.

Biographical Notes: The late Gerrit Arentsz. was a schuytemacker, a barge builder.
Intro Text: Opten 12e marty 1612 zyn ter ordonnantie van de Heeren Weesmeesteren vercoft de goederen achtergelaten by Gerrit Arentsz. schuytemacker. Postscript: Betaelt als blyct by onderteyckeninge ende quit[ancie] van Jan Martsz. backer ende Dirck Henrixsz. [...] in dato den 27 may 1612 onder de cedulle staende [...]

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Ypen Ypensz.
Biographical Notes: These goods were sold at auction at the request of Ype Ypensz. (Ibe Ibensz., IJpe IJpensz.), who was also a buyer at auction (R 22046).  On 10 December 1621, Ype Ypesz., sieckentrooster (comforter of the sick),  was named guardian of the innocent son of Aert Caessyn by the Orphan Chamber (WK 5073/513); on 30 June 1626, he was named guardian over the children of Hendrick Govertsz., caffawercker (ibid.) He may have been at least an occasional reseller of second-hand goods.
Intro Text: Op den 22e decembris 1625 zyn ten versoecke van Ypen Ypensz. vercoft dese naervolgende goederen.

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Hendrick and Willem Kemp
Occupation: Merchant (largescale) |a Wine, brandy (Hendrick and Willem Kemp)
Biographical Notes: Hendrick Barentsz. Kemp  and Willem Anthonijs Kemp were both from 'S Hertogenbosch. Hendrick Barentsz., 39 (19 ?), was betrothed to Catharina Juliaens , from Cologne, on 24 January 1619. She was assisted by her parents Joost Juliaensz. and Catarina Laurens (DTB 423/142). Hendrick Barentsz. Kemp, living in the Warmoesstraet,  paid a tax of 60 f. in 1631 (Kohier, fol. 106vo., p. 25). He was also a buyer at auction (e.g. R 38065). For a document concerning the delivery of wine in which he appeared (at which time he seemed to be living the house of Dirck Bontius, dealer in spices), see the NOTES to R 38065 of Montias2.  On 10 January 1604, Willem Anthonijs Kemp, assisted by his parents Anthonij Kemp and Mayken Jan Willemsdr., 22 years old, having living 3 years on the Warmoesstraet, was betrothed to Janneken de Clerck Mattheusdr., 21, assisted by her petemoeye Maritgen Wouters (DTB 411/123). On 8 December 1618, Zeger Pietersz. Crab named procureur Boon to defend him against Willem Kemp, wine dealer (NA 381, fol. 544).  He signed the Remonstrant petition of 1628.  The anonymous owner of the goods sold may have been a diamond cutter, as the sale of a diamant slippers meulen on 29 December (bought by Alexander Colpijn over de Bank van Lening) for 20 f. 10 st. suggests. It is not clear whether Hendrick Barentsz. Kemp is identical with Hendrick Barentsz. wine distributor (wijnverlater), who was said to be 37 in a document dated 25 February 1636. If he is so identical, then he must have been 19 and not 39 at the time of his betrothal (NA 414A, fol. 166). On 25 May 1635, Adriaen Spierincx, boremacker (probably a borer of wells), claimed that he was owed 337 f. by Barent Kemp, wine dealer, living in Zwolle (NA 843, Not. Hoogeboom).   On 9 February 1637, Hendrick Barentsz. Kemp, mr. wijnverlater, drew up a procuration to collect money in Goor (NA 415, film 6432).
Intro Text: Op den 23e december 1625 sijn ten versoecke van Hendrick and Willem Kemp vercoft dese naervolgende goederen.

Biographical Notes: Burchgert Otten, tanner of chamois leather, was the son of Otto Borchers, of the same trade, and, probably of Jutgen Hermans. On 10 November 1602, Otto Borchers, seemtouwer, and Jutgen Hermans had their son Herman baptized in the O.K. (DTB 4/148). On 15 December 1620, Otto Burchertsz., Hetto Hermansz., and two other tanners were authorized to oversee the work of tanners in the suede-leather mills of the Elandstraet (see the NOTES to R 38080 of Montias2. Hetto Hermansz. may have been the brother of Otto's wife Jutgen Hermans. The owner of the goods sold, Burchgert Otten, possessed a musquet with bandelier and other shooters' equipment. On 19 June 1621, Burchert Ottens, from Zutphen, seemtouwer (chamois leather tanner), living in the Elandstraet, assisted by his father Otto Burchertsz., was betrothed to Trijntje Lodewycks, from Amsterdam, 20, assisted by her father Lodewyck Jansz. (DTB 426/114).  On 17 August 1622, Burger Otten, zeemtouwer ,  appeared before the Orphan Chamber, and declared that his son Lodewijck, whose late mother was Styntgen (Trijntgen ?)  Lodewycx, was entitled to 1300 f. for his mother's inheritance. Otto Burgertsz. and Albert Burgertsz., the father and uncle respectively of Burgart Otten, were guarantors (borgen) of the promised sum (WK 5073/789). In the present sale, Anneken Pauwels, d'vrou in huys bought 3 kinderen lyffges at the auction. She is probably identical with the woman of that name who was married to Hans Hermansz. of R 23692 of Montias. If so, she was Burchgert Otten's aunt (who may have lived in the house of her brother-in-law Otto Burchers). Also at the present sale, Otto Burchertsz. bought 1 capstock, 2 hoofgens for f. 1:13:--. A tax of 5 f. was paid in 1631 for Burchert Otten seemtouwers soon, one of the orphan children recognized by the Weeskamer (Kohier, fol. 314vo, p. 72).

Additional Names: and his wife Truijtie Pieters
Biographical Notes: On 31 December 1606, Hans Jansz., silversmith, from Breda, and Lijsbet Matthijsen had their daughter Annetje baptized in the O.K. (DTB 4/185). On 4 April 1631, Hans Jansz., jeweler, appeared before the Orphan Chamber and declared that his three children, Jacobmyne, 23, Jacob, 18, and Maritjen, 16, whose late mother was Lysbeth Mathys, were entitled to 6,000 f. for their mother's inheritance (WK 5073/954). On the next day, Hans Janszen, from Breda, jeweler, widower of Lysbeth Mathys, living on the Rockin, was bretrothed to Tuijntje (Truijtie)  Pieters, from Antwerp, widow of Ambrosius Jansz., living as above (41 months a widow) (DTB 437/145). On Ambrosius Jansz., wine dealer, see R 808 of Montias1. On 13 June 1633, Hans Jansz. jeweler, and Hans Heiden, Moskovisvaerder (shipper of goods to Moscovy), signed a contract whereby Heiden would travel to Moscovy and handle the affairs of Hans Jansz. there, for a salary of 450 f. a year (Economisch-Historisch Jaarboek 2(1916), pp. 275-6). On 24 December 1634, Hans Hitseson, sworn broker, as guardian of the children of Trijntje (sic) Pieters of the first bed, procreated by Ambrosius Jansz., constituted himself surety for Gerrit Remmen who had been condemned to pay Hans Janssen 70 f. 12 st. 8 pen. (NA 520, film 6505, Not. Westfrisius). The wine dealer Gerrit Pietersz. Amstenraet, cited in the INTRO, was the father of Andries Amstenraet of INVNO 124 (R 31 of Montias1). Hans Jansz. seems to have been still alive on 7 August 1637 when the tailor Herman Pietersz. declared at the request of the widow of the cloth merchant Jan Thielens that he had bought 5 ellen of cloth on the order of the requirante from the shop of Hans Jansz. jeweler (NA 844, film 570). At the sale of books left by  Pieter Ruttens, bachelor, of 24 January 1618 (WK 5073/954), Hans Jansz., goldsmith living bij 't Weeshuis, bought various books, including 1 uijtlegginge van de Psalmen for f. 3:15:--. For another inventory of Hans Jansz. and Truijtie Pieters, taken in January 1634, see INVNO 456.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de goederen, roerende ende onroerende, in en uytschulden ... bij de eersame Hans Jansz. juwelier en Truijtie Pieters wijnkoopster, volgende heurluyden houlixe voorwaarden 'tsamen gepossideert en nu bij de gemelte Truijtien metter doot ontruijmt ende achtergelaten. Beschreven door mij Pieter Karels, notaris, ... ten overstaen van de voors. Hans Jansz. ende Henrick Barentsz. Wachtmans als procuratie hebbende van Gerrit Pietersz. Amstenraet ende Klaes Klaesz. Listingh wijnkopers als voogden over de drye  nagelate kinderen en erfgenamen van de voors. Truijntjen by de selve geeligeert ende door de heeren weesmesteren geauthoriseert, ende sijn d'selve bevonden in sulcker voegen als volgende uytgedruckt staet. Postscriptum: Verclaerde de voors. inventarisent [Hans Jansz.] met ware woorden in plaets van ede alles getrouwelyck geopenbaert ... te hebben ... desen boedel aengaende ... Aldus gedaen in Amsterdam ten overstaen van Hendrick Barentsz. ter presentie van Cornelis Pietersz.  ende Dr. Claes Burgers volvoert den 28en january 1634. Among the debts to the estate for wine delivered:  Willem Luyten, smith, 2 f. 16; Mr. Claes barbier in the Gravestratien, 8 f. 8 st.; Claes Elias, schilder (of R 8367); Michiel Prent (Parent) of R 24983; Baltus de stadtsbode (of R 23609); Antony Galjart (Gaillart) (de jonge) (of R 22087); and Abraham de Goyer (of R 24908, all of Montias2). Among the assets of the estate: een huys en erf leggende op de West sijde van den Here Marckt.

Additional Names: and his wife Barber Jans
Biographical Notes: Bart Pietersz. was betrothed to Barber Jans, 20, on 6 April 1619 (DTB 423/207). On 3 February 1626, Bartelt Pietersz. and Barber Jans had their daughter Bartge baptized in the N.K. (DTB 40/331).
Intro Text: Op den 17e marty 1626 zyn vercocht dese naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Bart Pietersen ende Barber Jans syn huysvrou

Residence: In de Voetboochs doelen in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 25 marti anno 1626 zyn vercocht dese naervolgende goederen achtergelaten by Thijmon Jansen op de Doelen.

Residence: Op de N.Z. Achterburgwal achter Arent Bouwers spijckers in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 16 april anno 1626 zyn vercocht de goederen van Anna Jacobs

Additional Names: goods sold at request of Harmen Jansen Blanck and Hendrick Dominicus
Residence: ten huyse van Gerrit Jacobsz. in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 15e october 1626 zyn ten versoecke van Harmen Jansen Blanck ende Hendrick Dominicus vercocht dese naervolgende goederen

Biographical Notes: On 10 October 1598, Hans Haelbos, from Antwerp, widower of Catelijne Nijmegens, was betrothed to Susanna de Vries, from Antwerp, 30, living op 't Water, assisted by Hans Verspreet, her master (DTB 408/400). On 1 March 1601, Hans Haelbos, widower of Susanna de Vries, was betrothed to Geertruit van den Bremden (DTB 409/341).
