Biographical Notes: In 1631. the three children of Christoffel Mendez, recognized as orphans by the Orphan Chamber, paid a tax of 200 f. (Kohier fol. 316vo, p. 72).
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meuble goederen ende huijsraet bevonden in den boedel van Abraham Franco Silvera, alias Christoffel Mendes

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at the request of his creditors under the supervision of the DBK
Biographical Notes: The owners of this insolvent individual seems to be the third individual named Jeremias Tradel. Jeremias Tradel I married Isabella van der Brugghen on 19 January 1619 (DTB 423/137). He may be the merchant of that name who freighted four ships from Hamburg to Arkhangelsk in 1638 (Wijnroks, Handel tussen Rusland en de Nederlanden 1560-1640, p.307). He is likely to  be the individual named Jeremias Tradel who was buried on 26 October 1652 (DTB 1100B/113). Another individual named Jeremias Tradel (II) was buried on 5 May 1670 (DTB 1101/104). The following is believed to be the owner of the goods in the present inventory. On 4 August 1665, Jeremias Tradel and Catrina van den Broeck had their daughter Cornelia baptized in the N.K. in the presence of Pieter Woorhamer and Isabella Tradel (DTB 44/112). If Isabella Tradel was his sister, as appears probable, then the following document, which records the betrothal of another sister named Susanna, refers to him. On 29 January 1663. On 29 January 1663, the painter Melchior d'Hondecoeter, signed a pre-nuptial contract with Susanna Tradel. He was accompanied by his uncle Abraham de Hondecoeter, surgeon, and his swager A[...] Cleynhens. She was assisted by her brothers the herren Jeremias and Jean Tradel and by their sister Isabella Tradel (Bredius, Künstler-inventare, p. 1214). On 11 February 1663, Melchior d'Hondecoeter and Susanna Tradel were betrothed (Obreen, Archief voor Nederlandsce kunstgeschiedenis, 5(1882-3), p.288).   On 18 September 1681, Jeremias Tradel, broker, widower of Catharin van den Broeck, living on the Prinsgracht, was betrothed to Sara van der Wijen, 55, op de Couriergraft, parents dead, assisted with [left blank] (DTB 509/192).
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meubilen ende huijsraet in den boedel van Jeremias Tradel. Marginal note: De volgende meubilen ende huijsraet heeft de huysvrou van Jeremias Tradel voor seeckere somme [...] blijckende by de acte staende int xxi-e register van de mobilen. Postscript: Aldus gedaen den 13 ende 14 maert 1673, mitsgaders getauxeert ende gepriseert bij Grietie Arents gesworene schatser ...  den 23 november volgende. Second postscript, fol. 42: Op huijden den 26 maert 1673, heeft Johannes de Jongh coopman hem gestelt cautionaris ende borge.

Purpose: Inventory drawn up at the creditors of Pieter Jansz.
Intro Text: Inventaris van Pieter Jansz. steenhower ten versoecke van de crediteuren van Pieter Jansz.

Residence: Op de westzyde van de Seedijck in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Aert de Haes who supervised the inventory under court order was probably the first of this name (INVNO 175). Michel de Vries is unknown.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de goederen ende meubelen bevonden ten huyse van Mr. Michel de Vries gestaen binnen deser stede op de westzyde van de Zeedijck ten versoecke van d'eersame Aert de Haes curaror by den E. gerechte deser stede daerover gestelt. Postscript: Aldus bevonden ende beschreven ten overstaen van Heydrick Heyndricksz. Muijden den statroeper ende Paulus Jansz.  ende Pieter Pietersz. heeresdienaerts den 4 augusty 1634 in Amsterdam.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual, recorded once without prices and once, less completely, with prices
Residence: Op den Oude Schans at the sign of de Blaue Haen in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Clement van Sorgen. the son of Nicolaes van Sorgen, textile merchant in Delft, and of Janneken van Rhijn, was born in Amsterdam on 28 July 1600. He married Cornelia van Heemskerck (born 9 May 1595) on 30 August 1622. She was the daughter of Paulus Beest van Heemskerck (cited in the NOTES to R 31250 of Montias2)  and Anna Clant. Clement van Sorgen, who owned a print of Hugo de Groot, signed the Remonstrant petition of 1628.  He registered as a broker on 9 November 1647 (after his insolvency of the end of 1644). On 24 July 1660 he was replaced as a broker after he left Amsterdam. He died in Amsterdam on 25 July 1671 and was buried in the N.K. on 28 July (W. Musse, 'n Familieboek van Sorgen, Jaarboek C.B.G. 1957, p.153). Adriaen Braems, of R 25313, helped administer the Orphan Chamber. The two sureties (cautionarissen) were Jacob van Loon, probably one of two possible buyers for the lot described in R 32810, and Rutgert Nederhof, probably a potash merchant, cited in R 28162 of Montias2. On 17 April 1632, Clement van Sorgen, merchant, made a trip to Hamburg. He gave a procuration to  his father-in-law  Paulus van Heemskerck and to Cornelia van Heemskerck, his beloved (beminde) wife, to collect money  from the (Wissel?)bank in Amsterdam in his absence (NA 843, Not. Hoogeboom). On 3 July 1636, Claes Hendricksz. Stopper of R 20012, tax farmer for the three gulden per barril, made a declaration at the request of Clement van Sorgen, who had a procuration from Pieter Jansz. Blanckert, brewer in De Arent  in Rotterdam. The impostmeester had apparently arrested him (Sorgen?) (NA 1276, film 2271,  Not. Barcman).
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meublen ende huysraet competerende den boedel van Clement van Sorgen, sulcx de selve bevonden sijn in tzijnder woonplaetse staende op den Oude Schans uijthangende de Blaeuwen Haen. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert ende beschreven op den 2e december 1644. Signed Frans Bruyning. Second postscript: Taxatie van de meublen ende huijsraet van Clement van Sorgen, gedaen by Engel Jacobs. Third postscript: Aldus geinventariseert ende beschreven ten overstaen van Adriaen Braems als by de heeren commissarirssen gestelt to curateur over de voors. boedel van Clement van Sorgen den 33 february 1645. Op huijden den 10e february 1645, hebben Jacob van Loon ende Rutgert Nederhoff tsamen ende elcx in solidum  sonder renunciatie vant benefitie ordinis divisionis et exclusionis als die effecte van dien, verstaende by desen gestelt causionarissen ende borgen voor de meublen ende huijsraet den boedel van Clement van Sorgen in de voorstaende inventaris gespecificeert ende getaxeert. Belovende alle tgene daer van bevonden soude mogen werden vermist ofte verandert, als hen eijgen schult selff op te leggen ende te voldaen et..
column25: David Colijn and Adriaen van Nieulandt (see NOTES to R 49294 of Montias2)

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at request of creditors
Residence: In the Runstraet near the Academij between the Keyser and Prince gracht in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: As explained in the TEXT of INVNO 1017 (the inventory of the painter Hendrick Aertsz.), it is very doubtful whether the insolvent individual in the present inventory is identical with the painter. Note that he was bode (envoy, courrier) to Nijmegen.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meublen ende huysraet bevonden ten woonplaets van Hendrick Aertsz. glasemaecker, gesworen boode op Nijmegen staende in de Runstraet byt Academij tusschen de Keyser ende Prince ggraft. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert ende beschreven ten overstaen van Mr. Abraham Dockman den 8 Augustus 1645.

Additional Names: and his wife Annetge Gerrits
Purpose: death inventory of goods owned in common
Intro Text: Inventaris van de achtergelaten goederen van wylen Doede Sybrantsz., in syn leven lindecoper in de Pijlsteech binnen Amsterdam gelyck in de selve tot op sijn sterfdach met syn huysvrouw Annetge Gerrits int gemeenschap gepossideert heeft. Postscript: Aldus oprecht ende sonder arge of list den sesten septembris anno 1619 t' oirconde. Among debts to estate (apparently for canvas used in painting): Antoni d'Aigremont, in the Pijlsteech (of INVNO 1008): f. 10: 7: 8.; Teunis Claesz., painter, f. 155:18:18; (Abraham) Vinck, the painter: f. -: 5: 4. The estate owed Jan de Marees (probably Jan Jansz. de Marees de oude) f. 4,352: 8:--.

Additional Names: widow of Jan Claesz. Bont
Purpose: Inventory drawn up for orphan heir
Residence: Opt Oude Cingel oft Coninxgracht in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: A distribution by lots took place after the inventory was drawn up. Cornelis de Bruijn (perhaps of R 22616 of Montias2) was allotted various textile goods valued in total at 56 f. The two crucifixes and the Virgin Mary are suggestive of a Roman Catholic inventory.
Intro Text: Staet ende inventaris van de goederen naegelaten by Griet Pieter Ruynsgendr., widow of Jan Claesz. Bont opt Oude Cingel ofte Coninsgracht.

Biographical Notes: This is a supplement to INVNO 645 of 9 November 1637.
Intro Text: Op huyden den 18e novembris 1637, de navolgende goederen, juwelen van gout ... nagelaten by Samuel Koorn ... by Aeltje Claes ande Engel Jacobs. Postscript: Aldus gedaen in Amsterdam ... ter presentie van Jan Riewertsz. ende Cryn van Seventer als getuijgen. Actum .... signed by Adriaen Braem, Craen Seventer, Johannes Riewertsz. ende Jan Geurtsz.

Additional Names: and his late wife Maritje Douwes
Biographical Notes: The late Maritje Douwes Amelandt was the daughter of Douwe Cornelisz. Amelandt, who was perhaps the brother of Willem Cornelisz. Amelandt, cited in the TEXT of INVNO 1222. She was apparently the buyer at R 20641 of Montias2. She was married to Revert Sykes who survived her.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de goederen bevonden ten huyse van Revert Sykes, staende op te Egalentiers graft ende bij het overlijden van de selfs huysvrouwe Maritje Douwes beschreven ... ter requeste van Reynier Harmens Backer ende Cornelis Volckertsz.. Postscript: Actum in Amsterdam opten 2 junij 1634 ten overstaen van de requiranten mitsgaders Rutgert Nolbeeck, Douwe Cornelissen Amelandt, vader van den overleden.

Residence: Op de Oost Indische Kaij at the the sign of the Kopere booch in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: The brothers Hendrick and Wouter Bosschaert were both from South Netherlands (Gent or Antwerp). (A note in the present inventory cites an accounting concerning Johannes Andriesz. Bosschaert in Antwerp from uncle Bosschaert). Hendrick Bosschaert was married to Catrijn le Maire, the daughter of Adam le Maire, the son of Jacques le Maire, an important overseas trader (Wijnroks, Handel tussen Rusland en de Nederlanden 1560-1640, p.98).   There were two men named  Paulus Bosschaert in the next generation, one was the merchant Paulus Hendricksz. Bosschaert (or Busschaert) of the present inventory, who died in 1620, and the other, his cousin, the cake baker Paulus Woutersz. Bosschaert of R 27456 of Montias2. It appears from a note to the INTRO that Paulus Hendricksz. Bosschaert was married to the sister of Catharina van Solt, who died before him. Note the portrait of Wouter Bosschaert and his wife in the inventory. Catharina van Solt, married to Abraham Seewens, was the daughter of Hans van Sol(d)t I of R 29281 of Montias2. The portraits of Melanchton and Luther in the inventory suggest that Paulus Hendricksz. was Lutheran.
Intro Text: Specificatie van de goederen ende imboel nagelaten by Paulus Busschaert in sijn leven coopman in deser stede sulcx hy de selve door sijn doot deser werelt ontruymt heeft. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert ende gespecificeert in Amstelredam  ten huyse van de voors. Paulus Busschaert, gestaen op de Oost Indische Kaij genaemt de kopere booch ter presentie van David Petaen van Antwerp, inwoonder, end Jan Dircksz. poorter deser stede. Among the notes to the inventory: Een donatie van 9,000 f. gedaen by Paulus Bosschaert aen Juffr. Catharina van Solt, de suster van zijn overleden huysvrou in dato 10 September 1620.

Additional Names: goods owned in common with his late wife Evertie Willems Bussen
Purpose: inventory of goods owned in common, after death of wife.
Biographical Notes: Willem Buss, who supervised the inventory, may have been the father-in-law of Evert Janssen. He was probably closely related to the white wood worker Jan Willemsz. Bus of INVNO 219 (who is likely to have been the brother of Evertie Willems Bussen). Evert Janssen remarried with Josyntge Cornelis with whom he passed his testament on 5 December 1636 (NA 751, film 5179, Not. Persenne).
Intro Text: Inventaris van den goederen .... van Evert Janssen kistemacker ende Evertie Willems Bussen zal. die sij in gemeen hebben gepossideert, ten overstaen van Willem Buss ende Aries Pietersz. Postscript: Aldus gedaen ende getaxeert op ten xxvi november anno 1630 ten overstaen als boven.

Additional Names: widow of Jacob van Neck (Cornelisz.)
Residence: Op de Oude Schans in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Jacob Cornelisz.  van Neck, the husband of Margareta (Griete) van Neck, was the son of Cornelis Barendsz. and of Weyn Pieters van Neck. He was born in 1564 and died on 8 March 1638. Margareta van Neck, daughter of Jacob Egbertsz. and Maria Claes Gaeff (see the NOTES to R 27935 of Montias2), was born in 1585 and died on 18 November 1652. Jacob Cornelisz. van Neck was a member of the Vroedschap from 1621 until his death in 1638. He paid a tax of 300 f. in 1631.  He was burgomaster in 1622, 1623, 1625 and 1626. He was admiral of a fleet that sailed to the East Indies in 1598 (freighted by the Nieuwe Compagnie van de Vaart op Oost Indie) and returned with the ship Hollandia to Texel on 27 July 1599 laden with spices. He lived, first, on the O.Z. Voorburgwal and later on the Oudeschans. His daughter Weyntge van Neck (1610-1682) married Jean Le Gouche (1588-1669) on 8 May 1635. His other daughter Maria van Neck (1612-1645) married Ferdinandus Schuylenburch (of R 25764 of Montias2) on 11 January 1639 (Elias, Vroedschap van Amsterdam, pp. 335-6). His son Jacob (Jacobsz.) van Neck II  was born on 1 April 1629. He died unmarried on 13 January 1687. He served in the Vroedschap from 1662 until his death in 1687 (Elias, op.cit. p. 520). Jacob Barendsz. van Neck of INVNO 1256 was born in Texel in 1602. He was a member of the Vroedschap from 1652 to 1673 and left Amsterdam in that year in the wake of his bankruptcy. He was captain of the militia in 1650 (Elias, op.cit. p. 478). On Simon van Hoorn, see the NOTES to R 27381 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Inventaris van alle de goederen, huysraet, ..., achtergelaten bij Margareta van Rijn in haer leven weduwe van de heer burgomeester Jacob van Neck, gemaeckt ten versoecke en overstaen van d'heer Jan le Gouchie [Le Gouche], als man en voocht van juffr. Weyntje van Neck, mitsgaders juffr. Catharina en Elisabeth van Neck Jacobs. item de Heeren Jacob van Neck Barentsz. en Mr. Symon van Hooren, raeden deser stede, ten huyse van de voors. Margareta van Hoorn, gestorven is opden Schans binnen deser stede. Postscript: Aldus gedaen ende gepriseert ten overstaen als boven ter presentie van Gillis Valckenier ende Gerrit Brant als getuijgen.

Biographical Notes: Lucas Keilart (II) belonged to an extensive R.C. family, which included his brother, the R.C. priest Hermanus Keilart of INVNO 467. They were the sons of Lucas Keilaert I, from Hasselt, and of Tryntgen Goosen van Flory. The merchant Lucas Cuylart (Keilaert) was noted as a handelaer in Amsterdam in 1628 (Gelderblom, Zuid-Nederlandse kooplieden, p. 298).  On 18 May 1638, Lucas Cuijlaert I  declared at the request of Isbrant Heder that he had received on commission from Heder a number of clocks which he had shipped to Moscow to be sold on Heder's account. All the clocks were sold, except one, weighing 805 pounds, which had a basic fault in the metal (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven R.G.P. 144(1974), p. 197). The children of Lucas Keilart (Keijlaert)  II, according to the INTRO, were Philips, Marie, married to Christiaen Hageman, and, probably, Margarita and Gosewijn.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de goederen en middelen naergelaten en metter doot ontruijmt bij Lucas Keilart zal. in sijn leven gewoont hebbende ten huyse van Sr. Philips Keilart, syn soon, gemaeckt by my Adriaen Lock, Not. Pub. ... ten versoecke van de selve Sr. Philips Keilart, Christiaen Hageman als getrout hebbende juffr. Maria Keilart soo voor haer selven als neffens Sr. Pieter Verbeeck gestelde voogden over het nagelatene kindt van Margareta Keilart zal. als mede van het achtergelaten kindt van Gosewijn Keilart zal., alle erfgenamen van de voors. Lucas Keilart zal. Actum in Amsterdam den derden februari anno 1678. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert ... ten versoecke als int hooft ... ter presentie van Joannes du Hue en Joannes Verheven als getuijgen.

Residence: In de Leydel (or Niesdel) in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Some of the movable goods of Hans van Rickenoy were sold on 3 December 1621 (INVNO 671). The presence of the Instituto Calvinis in the inventory suggests that Rickenoy was Reformed(Calvinist). Unusual perhaps for a shoemaker is the presence of a book of Titius Livius in the inventory. On 17 July 1622, an inventory was taken of the clothing left by Abraham van Rijckenoy, son of Hans van Ryckenoy, some of which had been bequeathed by testament to Abraham's brother Pieter van Ryckenoy.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meublen ende huijsraedt mitsgaders alle goederen bevonden ten huyse van wylen Hans van Rickenoy in sijn leven schoenmacker overleden in de Leydel. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert ende beschreven by my Jacob Meerhout ten overstaen van de kinderen van den voorn. Hans van Rickenoy ende mede van Gerrit Jacobsz. Haringh knecht van de weeskamer deser stede by de heeren weesmeesteren geauthoriseert, Actum in Amsterdam den 15en octobris 1621.

Additional Names: goods owned in common with her husband Albert Aerentsz. Sleijvelt(?)
Residence: Op de hoeck van de Reestraat in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On Adriaen Cornelisz. Hardebol, who may be identical with one of the guardians of two children left by Soonentgen Hendricx and Albert Aerentsz. Sleijvelt, see the NOTES to R 27980 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Inventaris van alle de goederen roerende ende onroerende, actien, crediten ... laest metter doot ontruymt ende achtergelaten bij Soonentgen Hendricx, sulcx sij de selve in haer leven heeft beseten ende over ende achtergelaten sijn bij Albert Aerentsz. Sleijvelt(?), ten versoeck van Francois van Nieulandt apothecaris, Jan Heyckesz., en Arent Hardebol voochden van twee onmondige nagelaten kinderen van de voors. Mr. Albert Sleijvelt ende Sonnentje Hendricx, by my Albert Eggericx, not. pub. etc.. Postscript: Aldus gedaen en geinventariseert ter presentie en overstaen van Isaac Cheynkens en Gerrit Brant als getuijgen hier aengestaen.

Additional Names: widow of Jacob van Campen
Residence: Op de Singel at the sign of het boerinnetgen in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Jacob Cornelisz. van Campen (1598-1668)  was the natural, legitimized son of the merchant  Cornelis van Campen (1564-1636) and of Sijtgen Gerrits. He married Geertruid van Delft (1603-1676) at an unknown date.  The architect Jacob van Campen was his half brother, procreated by Cornelis van Campen and Catharina Queeckels (1578-1632). From the INTRO it emerges that the merchant Jacob Cornelisz. van Campen had a son named Gysbrecht and that the latter had children named Cornelis, Willem, Anna, and Jacobus, who were still of minor age or unmarried at the time of Geertruid's death. On the Van Campen genealogy, see Jacob van Campen, Het klassieke ideaal in de Gouden Eeuw, Exh. Catalogue, Royal Palace, Amsterdam, 1995, pp.24-5).
Intro Text: Inventaris van de goederen ende middelen naergelaten ende metter doot ontruymt by Geertruijdt Delff in haer leven weduwe van Jacob van Campen, gemaeckt by my Adriaen Lock, Not. Pub. ten versoecke van de heeren Hendrick Molenaer, Nicolaes Gelehandt ende Michiel Kieck, als codicille voochden over Cornelis, Willem, Anna, ende Jacobus van Campen, naergelatene ... onmondige kinderen van Gysbert van Campen zal., soone van de voors. Geertruyd Delft en is desen inventaris begonnen den sevenden april 1676 ende enige dagen daernaer voltrocken. Postscript: ... Op den xxxe decembris voors. compareerden voor my Adriaen Lock ... ende verclaerden [alles oprecht?]

Biographical Notes: Given that there were no musical instruments at all among the movable goods of Aert Cop of the present inventory, that he was a full-fledged wine dealer, and that the lute player Artus Cop would have had to be born in 1540 at the latest, it is apparent that the owner of the goods was Aert (or Arent) Cop II, one of the three sons of Nicolaes Cop I of R 30624 of Montias2, and not their grandfather the lute player Artus Cop I.  In the 1612  testament of Nicolaes Cop I and Elisabeth Aerts Burlon, Arent Cop (II), probably the owner of the goods in the present inventory,   and the painter Nicolaes Cop II were both left 3,600 f. Since Gerrit Cop,  the third son of the couple, was still alive (see the deposition dated 23 October 1621  in the NOTES to R 30624 of Montias 2), it is not clear what portion he received of the inheritance. It should be noted that one of the paintings in the present inventory was said to belong to Hendrick Keyn, bode to Antwerp, who was involved in the transaction with Rubens cited in the NOTES to R 30624. Aert Cop II was married to Koniertie Wouters, who presumably predeceased him.  The principal creditor with a claim on the present inventory was Jacob Bicker, who is likely to be identical with Jacob Bicker Jacobsz. (1589-1626), who was a member of the Vroedschap in 1625 and 1626 (Elias, Vroedschap, p. 359). The names of the other creditors were illegible in microfilm.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meublen ende huijsraedt mitsgaders de wynen berustende ten huyse van Aert Cop wyncoper binnen deser stede. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert by my Jacob Meerhout Not. Publ. .. ten overstaen van den E. Jacob Bicker mitsgaders ... crediteuren van den voorn. Aert Cop, actum in Amsterdam den 16en juli 1621.

Biographical Notes: Jan Jansz. van Nesch is believed to have been the son of Jan Pietersz. van Nesch and  the brother of Pieter Jansz. van Nesch of R 24929 of Montias2. He was the nephew (by marriage?)  of Tobias Pietersz. and Marchellis Pietersz. cited in the NOTES to R 24929. Jan Jansz. van Neschen bought several expensive lots in the Haarlem lottery of 1608, at which time he lived in De vergulde camel in the O.Z. (Zyd)arm (139/18F and 139/65F). On 3 August 1613, Jan Jansz. van Neschen and Geertgen Pieters, as father and mother of Jannetje Jans van Neschen, assisted Jannetje Jans in her betrothal to Thomas de Letter, from Antwerp (DTB 763/21). The marriage took place at the Town Hall. However, it is not known what religion the Van Neschens belonged to.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meublen en huysraet mitsgaders [...]werck bevonden ten huyse van Jan Jansz. van Neschen. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert by my Jacob Meerhout ten overstaen van Marchellis Pietersz. ende Tobias Pietersz. beyde broeders van den overledens huysvrouw van Jan Jansz. van Neschen mitsgaders Jacob Jacobsz. van Slooten de broederssoon van de voorn. Jan Jansz. van Eschen ende Jan van Hemskerck ... op den 4e Septembris anno 1623.

Biographical Notes: Pieter (Pierre) Seulin (Seullin) was the son of Mattheus Seulin (Seullin). He was first married to Sara van Collen, the daughter of Abraham van Collen (Ceulen), born in Aachen, who was buried in Amsterdam on 25 July 1624. Abraham van Collen was  married to Maria Seulijn in Aachen. On their son Jean or Johannes, see below.  After the death of Abraham van Ceulen,  Maria Seulijn remarried with Pieter Carlier, also from Aachen, on 14 April 1626. On 16 January 1638, the honorable Pierre Carlier, resident merchant, named Isaack Hochepied to represent him over differences that had arisen over the succession of Jean Buret (de oude)  (NA 952, Not. B. Baddel). On the estate of Jean Buret (Burett) de oude, see also the TEXT of R 81.  Pieter Seulin's sister Hester Seulin was married to Steven de Lespierre (of R 33167). On these relations, see Jaarboek C.G.G. 1972, pp. 197-8. Mattheus Seulin may have been a brother of Jean Seulin I, married to Apollonia Sprenckhuysen, cited below.  On 9 April 1614, Peter Seulin, widower of Sara van Keullen (Collen),  was betrothed to Maria van Ceullen (Collen), who may have been the sister of Sara van Collen (DTB 418/39). Portraits of the Oude Keulen and of his wife in the inventory are probably those of Seulin's father- and mother-in-law, Abraham van Ceulen (Collen) and Maria Seulin. The children of Pieter Seulin (I)  at whose request the inventory was drawn up were Catherina Seulijn, the second wife of Jacques Boursse (I); Agatha Seulin, married to Francois Tayspel; Sara Seulin, married to Willem Pecock; and Maria Seulin, spinster. On Jacques Boursse I, see the NOTES to R 20074. Jean Seulin II  was the brother of Willem Seulijn (of INVNO 1197) and of Hendrick Seulijn, the father of Jan Hendricksz. Seulijn of R 34388 of Montias2. He was a regent of the Waalsweeshuis in 1636 and 1637. He was betrothed to Marguerite Boursse, of St. Malo, 19,  daughter of Jacques Boursse I, on 1 October 1622 (see the NOTES to R 20074 of Montias2).  Pieter (or Pierre) Seulin (I)  was a merchant, apparently importing English textiles. For a declaration of 1624  at his request, see the NOTES to R 20238 of Montias2. On 19 February 1638, sr. Emanuel Mandeville, merchant in Amsterdam, declared that sr. Pieter Seullin (I), likewise merchant, had obtained a discount and bought in cash four bales of legiesyde (silk good): two bales sold to Catharina Varlet, widow of Severyn Haeck (of R 22043), one bale of the same to Jan van Heusden of R 36233 and one bale of the same to Gillis Bierman, under guarantee of Samuel de Lange. Seullin had been paid in full (after granting the rebates) (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven R.G.P. 144(1974), pp.191-2). Pieter Seulin de jonge was probably his son. On 4 April 1640, sr. Johannes van Ceulen, merchant in Amsterdam, for the account of and having received written directives from, Pieter Seulin de jonge (II) hired Jan Albertsz., master copper smith (coperslager) to go to Brazil with the first opportunity to serve there on Van Ceulen's as copper smith for 42 f. a month plus free board and lodging (Van Dillen, op.cit. pp. 266-7). Johannes van Ceulen (Collen) was the son of Abraham van Ceulen (Collen) and of his second wife  Maria Seulin (Elias, Vroedschap van Amsterdam, p. 643).  On 12 April 1644,  Johannes van Ceulen, merchant and drogist in Amsterdam took on apprentice for three years (text in French) (ibid. p.410). On 28 May 1650, sr. Jean van Ceulen drew up the specifications for hearth sculptures that he wished to install in his house that was being built on the Rokin on the corner of the Wyde Steech. The sculptor Hoecgeest was to carry out the work (ibid. p. 555). Both Willem Pecock and Francois Tayspel cited above were cloth dealers who signed a petition to the Vroedschap in 1665 concerning certain prohibitions on the import of English cloth (Van Dillen, Bronnen tot de geschiedenis van het bedrijfsleven R.G.P. 144(1974), Willem Peakok (Peacock) was also a dealer in whalebone stays (ibid. p. 859). p.737).
Intro Text: Inventaris van de huys[raet] ende imboel bevonden ten huys van wylen Pieter [Seulin] soo en sulcx hij die metter doot [ontruijmt] ende naergelaten heeft. Gemaeckt opt versoecke ende door aengeven van Catharina Seulin, huysvrouw van Jacques Boursse, Francois Tayspel, man ende voogt van Agatha Seulin, Willem [Pecock],  als man ende voogt van Sara Seulin, tante [Maria Seulin?], bejarde dochter, alle kinderen ende [erffgenamen] van wylen Pieter Seulin, ende sijn de [meublen] (ex. de schilderyen) gepriseert door [...] Jacobs ende Kunertge Hendricx gesworen schatsers dese stede, ten pryse soo achter de selve goederen staet... In kennisse ... Gerrit Coren, Not. Publ... ter presentie naergenoemt. Postscript: Aldus gedaen in Amsterdam in presentie van Dirck Danckertsz. ende Gerrit [...] inwoonders deser stede als getugen den 2en april 1649. Signed: Anna Hendricx, Catrina Seullin, Frans Tayspel, Willem Pecock, Maria Seullyn, Dirck Danckertsz., Gerrit [Coren?]
column25: Barbara [...] and Kunertje Hendricx and, for the paintings, other appraiser(s)

Biographical Notes: Jacob Noirot II, the grandson of Jacomo Noirot of INVNO 227, was baptized in the N.K. on 19 June 1629 and was buried in the same church on 20 October 1680. He  was the son of Adriaen Noirot and of Susanna de Wilhelm, the sister of Paolo de Wilhelm II of INVNO 197. He was first married to Margaretha Grafland (1641-1676). He remarried with Catharina Aletta Pels (1638-1711) on 15 March 1678 (Elias, Vroedschap van Amsterdam, p. 524).
Intro Text: Inventaris van alle de goederen behorende tot den boedel van sal. Jacob Noirot in syn leven koopman tot Amsterdam overleden, gedaen macken ende beschreven door de selfs weduwe Aletta Pels op 21 Octobris 1680 ... bevonden syn geweest. Postscript: Aldus gepasseert voor my Mr. Cornelis Hoogeboom openb. not. ... ter presentie van Guillame Pels ende Jan Barentsz. van Meulen den 19 Januaris 1681.

Additional Names: goods owned in common with his wife Elisabeth Prince
Purpose: Death inventory of debtor  under court-ordered supervision
Intro Text: Staet ende inventaris van alle de goederen van wylen Hendrick Backer in sijn leven procureur voor den E. Gerechte deser stadt, ende sijn nagelaten weduwe, zoo ende sulcx sijluijden int gemeen gepossideert ... hebben, mitsgaders bij de voors. Hendrick Backer zal. met de doot ontruymt ende nagelaten heeft. Gemackt opt aengeven van Cornelia Backers ten versoucke van Margrite Backers, [huysvrouw van] Captain Cornelis Hooft(?), mitsgaders Lucretia Backers, tesamen nagelaten kinderen van wylen de voors. Hendrick Backer ende in dier qualite erffgenamen onder benefitie van inventaris van de selve Hendrick Backer zal. Vermogens de open brieven van benefitie van inventaris by hun luyden geimpetreert. In kennisse van den eersame Jeuriaen Jaspersz., deurwaerder van de Hoge Raed van Hollant ende my Frans Uyttenbogaert, Not. Pub. ... Postscript: Alle welcke voors. meubelen ende huijsraden by Aeltge Claes ende Annetge Hendricx beyde gesworen schatsers binnen deser stede gepriseert sijn soo achter de selve hierboven staet. Among the debts due to (or by?)  the estate: Isaacq Marcus  f 2: 2:--, Grietge Bennincx (the mother of Jan Benning of R 26500), f 74:12:--,  Gillis de Vielle, verwer, f 18: 2:--, Hendrick de Graeff, f 2: 8:--, Roeloff Gerritsz., vettevarier f 1:16:--, Jan Dorthout f 29:14:--; Jan Brouwer, cruydenier, f 113: 8:--, Anna Jans Cat, f 3:18:--; Hendrick de Vries f 2: 8:--, de weduwe van Albert Schuijt (Anna Bernard?), Hendrick Hendricksz. Grambergen (of INVNO 326), f 7:18:--, Laurens Charles (of R 20464 of Montias2),  f 55: 3:--, Willem Willemsz. van Amelandt (of INVNO 1222), and Coenrad Hendricksz. van Ceulen, f 21: 8:-- On Isaack Marcus, Portuguese, see the TEXT of R 467 of INVNO 566.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at the request of his creditors.
Biographical Notes: On 11 April 1643, Gerrit Lunden, painter, was betrothed to Agniet Mathijs, assisted by her mother Geertruyd van den Hecken, 23.
Intro Text: Inventaris van wijnich meubijlen ende huijsraet bevonden in den boedel van Gerrit Lunden gewoont hebbende op de Singel. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert den 16e january 1671.

Biographical Notes: Partially burnt and illegible INTRO. On 3 June 1622, Hans van Asperen, from Ceulen, 24, showing his mother's consent, assisted by his brother Jacobus van Asperen, living in the Calverstraet, was betrothed to Catharina Kip, from Aachen, no living parents, assisted by her uncle Abraham Kip, living on the Koningsgracht (DTB 427/160). On 7 May 1623, the couple had their son Jacob baptized in the N.K. (DTB 40/210).
Intro Text: Inventaris van ... Hans van Asperen soo ... in sijn huijs Hendrick Tiercksz. de Vries alsulck recht in proportie daerop is hebbende en in conformite van authoriteyt van de heeren schepenen ... seker [apostille] huyden date, bevonden als volcht, in kennisse van my not. pub. Postscript: Op huijden den 6en april 1649 zijn de schilderyen in den voors. inventaris ge[....\] door Sr. Hendrick Meerman schilder .... ten prijse als achter d'selve staet . In kennisse van my Gerrit Coren notaris ... Second postscript: Aldus gedaen binnen Amsterdam ter presentie van Jan Jansz. ende Adam Nijs inwoonders ...  den xxix april 1649.

Additional Names: widow of Pieter van der Loo
Residence: West side of the Keizersgracht in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 13 September 1619, Joost Palman, diamond cutter, and Pieter van der Loo, likewise diamond cutter, were said to own an obligation issued by Pieter Jacobsz. van Rijn (of R 27935) for 422 (Fl.) pounds dated 7 August 1619, another for 630 pounds issued by Anthony Moens and another for 342 pounds issued by Abraham de Marees de jonge  (WK 5073/789). On 23 April 1637, Mettge Wonders, widow of Pieter van der Loo (I), of the present inventory,  jeweler, named Abraham van der Voort (probably of R 32595 of Montias2), to collect money due to her (NA 597, fol. 181, Not. L. Lamberti). The widow owned a house on the West side of the Keisersgracht. Pieter van der Loo (II), his son, was named in the INTRO.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de goederen roerende ende onroerende, actien en gerechticheiden in sulcken voegen Mettje Wonders, weduwe van za. Pieter van der Loo in sijn leven diamant snijder end juwelier [beseten ende met der doot ontruijmt heeft, beschreven] ter requisitie ende ten overstaen van d'eersame Hans van Immen sijdereder behoude oom, testamente vooght ende executeur [over] Jan van der Loo [naer] Oost Indien zynde, Maiken van der Loo, Pieter van der Loo, Christiaen van der Loo, ende Grietgen van der Loo, kinderen ende erffgenamen van de voorn. Mettje Wonders. Postscript: Verclarende ende affirmerende de gemelte Mayken van der Loo, Christiaen van der Loo ende Grietge van der Loo alle de goederen in den gemelten boedel ... geinventariseert te zijn ... in presentie van Jan van Erpekom, koopman, ende Willem Wernaerts inwoonder .. den 11 November 1641.

Biographical Notes: A marriage contract was signed by Frans Jansz. van Hocxbergen, bachelor, and Grietje Jacobs van Hops on 30 March 1656 (Bredius, Künstler-inventare p. 533). He was living in the Breestraet on 12 September 1659 when his child was buried. He paid the church 4 f. (ibid.) On 3 December 1660, Frans van Hocxbergen, fijnschilder, lent juff. Maria Aller 400 f. (ibid., p. 534). By 20 June 1662, when he again had a child buried, he was living in the Dyckstraet (where he was living when he had his inventory drawn up). He was said to be 46 years old in a deposition dated 14 November 1671. On 9 April he was living on the Zeedijck when he gave Jannetge Claes a procuration. (Bredius called Jannetge Claes the wife of Frans Hocxbergen, but this cannot be correct). Grietge Jacobs (Hops) was again named as his wife when she drew up her testament on 13 August 1676. She left Jannetje Claes 100 f. She was owed 200 f. by Jan Symonsz. Dobber. She was then living with Jannetje Claes in the Schoutensteeg (next to the Zeedijck)  at the sign of Wesel. There was no mention of Frans van Hocxbergen himself (except as the husband of Grietge Jacobs) (ibid. p. 535). On 7 December 1679, Frans van Hoxbergen, living on the Zeedijck near the Stormsteech, was buried. 15 f. were paid to the Oudezijds Kapel on his behalf (ibid.) On the reasons for Van Hocxbergen's bankruptcy and a list of creditors, see the TEXT to INVNO 13110.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de goederen bij afwesen van Frans Hoxbergen schilder, sijnde in de huysinge vooraen in de Dijckstraet, toebehorende Gysbert Kruijf, meester timmerman en houtkoper, van welcke huysinge gemelde Frans Hoxbergen de sleutel gelaten hadde in handen van Annetje Jacobs, daeromtrent wonende, die thuijs geopent hebbende ... wert bevonden 't geen als volcht

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at the request of his creditors under the supervision of the DBK
Biographical Notes: See the NOTES to INVNO 1311.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meubelen end huijsraet bevonden in den boedel van Frans van Hoeckbergen. Postscript: Aldus gedaen ende geinventariseert den 5e augustij 1662. On 14 August 1662, Frans van Hoeckbergen had another inventory drawn up of his possessions, which was introduced as follows: Staet en inventaris gedaen maecken door my Notaris (A. de Jager) ten versoecke van Frans van Hocxbergen van de gelegentheyt desselffs boedel en dat hij in soodanigen staet en verloop van schulden is geraect, dat hij genootsaect is sich met het miseraebel benefitie van cessie te behelpen. Follows a list of creditors die uyt crachten van obligatie en boeckschulden te pretenderen hebben: De Heer van Weede, Domheer te Utrecht, 350 f.; Davidt Colyn (of R 21775), 20 f.; Egbert, the framemaker, 25 f.; David Eversdijck (painter) opt Water, in de vier Kraenen, 90 f.; De doecke plumuyrder (canvas preparer) in the St. Jacobstraet, 14 f. These debts may be (partly)  offset by the household goods and furniture that will be sold by the Concierge (of the DBK), and there are also some goods deposited with Annitie Jacobs at the Beginenhoff valued at ... [not filled in]. Follows an explanation for the painter's bankruptcy: Alsoo de voornoemde Frans van Hocxbergen met syn handtwerck van schilderen mits dese benauwde tijt niet veel te doen hebbende gehadt en sooveel niet cunnen winnen waermede hy syn huysvrouw en kinderen op verre na heeft cunnen onderhouden, en dat hy met coopen en vercoopen van schilderijen oock merckelycke somme van penningen heeft verlooren en daerenboven nu de tijt van omtrent seven jaren is belast geweest met vrou ende kinderen en dienvolgende verscheyde oncosten van craemen, sieckten en begraeffenisse van twee van syn kinderen als andersints heeft moeten doen ende uytstaen, sonder dat hy ofte syn huysvrouwe eenige capitalen ofte middelen bij den anderen hebben gebracht waermede sy hetselve soude hebben cunnen doen en dat syn hantwerck off schilderkunst om reedenen als vooren daertoe weynigh ofte niet heeft mogen helpen sulcx dat daerdoor veroorsaect is tot syn Frans van Hocxbergens groot leetwesen, date hy syn voorn. crediteuren van tijt tot tijt als verleegen en in benautheijt synde om gelt, tot onderstandt van syn huyshoudinge heeft moeten aenspreecken en gelt op interesten neemen met meeninge om  by fortuijn en beter geleegentheyt van tyt, yder 't syne wederom te doen hebben, doch is Godt betert! tot syn groote droefheijt alles in syn voors. huyshoudinge tot nooddruft  geconsumeert.

Additional Names: goods owned in common with her husband Salomon Pietersz.
Biographical Notes: For bio information on Maijke Jans and Salomon Pietersz., see the TEXT of R 875.
Intro Text: Inventaris ende specificatie van alle de goederen nagelaten bij z. Maijke Jans in haer leven huysvrou van Salomon Pietersz., herbergier tot Houte Wael sulcx sij by de selve mettet doot desen werelt  ontruymt ende met Salomon Pietersz. int gemeen beseten heeft. Postscript: Compareerde Salomon Pietersz. wonende in Houte Wael ende verclaerde [the inventary to be complete]. In Amsterdam desen 23e October 1629 in presentie van Joan Buys ende Harmen Hendricksz.

Residence: Op 't Water ontrent de Nieuwe Burch daer de Delfsche Bybel uythangt in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 20 June 1624, Gysbrecht van Goedesberg, from Wezel, 29, wonende op de Torensmarckt, was betrothed to Magdalena Jans, from Amsterdam, 18, assisted by her father Jan Evertsz. and her mother Geertie Joppen, living op't Water. Both signed Goedesberg (DTB 429/170). On 4 July 1627, Ghysbert van Goedesberch and Magdalena Jans had their daughter Marija baptized in the O.K. in the presence of Pieter Gumbst, Elisabeth Nerings and Jannetje Everts (DTB 6/177). Marija Goesbergen became the second wife of Pieter Belten de oude of INVNO 980.  On 16 November 1628, Ghysbert van Goesbergen and Magdalena Jans had their son Jan baptized in the O.K. in the presence of Jeronimus Broeckhuysen, Geertje Joppen, and Jan Evertsz. van Heerde (DTB 6/222).  On 28 May 1630, Gijsbert Goedsberch and Magdalena Jans van Haerden had their son Jan baptized in the N.K. (DTB 41/82).
Intro Text: Inventaris van alle de goederen metter doot ontruymt en achtergelaten bij Gysbert van Goesbergen in syn leven weduwenaer van Magdalena Jans ten huyse van den selven Goesbergen is komende ... overleden opt water ontrent de Nieuwe Burch daer de Delfsche Bybel uythangt ... ten overstaen van Gerrit en Maritje van Goesbergen, kinderen voor hen selfs en in naem van Jan, Abraham, Jsaacq, Lysbeth ende Anna van Goesbergen, susters en broeders noch onmondich synde by myn A. Eggericx in presentie van ... getuijgen. Postscript: Aldus gedaen ende geinventariseert ten overstaen van Marritje Jans der kinderen moeye .. en Steven Galliart, man ende voogt van Lysbet Jans ... de kinderen oom en moeye ter presentie van Jan Jacobsz. ende Aelbert Eggericx als getuygen desen 21en dach van junij 1650.

Additional Names: widow of Jacob Dircxsz. de Lange
Biographical Notes: Elisabeth Reael was the daughter of Johan Pietersz. Reael, receiver of taxes for Amsterdam, burgomaster in 1604 (1543-1621). She was born in 1582 and died on 9 May 1644. She married Jacob de Lange Dircksz. on 22 January 1606. He was born in Gouda in 1576 and died in Amsterdam in 1616. He was soap boiler on the Ouwe Lastasij in the seperij van Muijden. Her siblings were the merchant and freighter Pieter Jansz.  Reael of R 28042 of Montias2  (1569-1643); Maria Reael (1580-1601) who married Augustijn Wttenbogaert of R 27441 of Montias2; Reynier Reael (1588-1648), cited in the INTRO,  who married Maria Oetgens, daughter of  Frans Hendricksz. Oetgens; Jacob Reael (1590-1639), who went bankurpt in 1629; and Bartholomeus Reael (1592-1654), of R 7668 of Montias2,  also cited in the INTRO, who became city secretary after going bankrupt in 1632. Their son Dirck de Lange (1607-1671) became captain of the militia in 1650. He married Elisabeth Backer (1614-1669), daughter of Joris Jorisz. I, the father of Joris Jorisz. Backer of R 8340 of Montias2, and of Annetge Willems Backer (Elias, Vroedschap van Amsterdam, pp. 261-3).
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meubelen imboel ende huysraden van wijlen Juffr. Elisabeth Reael, weduwe van wijlen Jacob Dircxsz. de Lange, soo end sulcx zij die metter doot ontruijmt ende nagelaten heeft. Gemaeckt opt versoeck ende den aengaven van Srs. Dirck de Lange, voor hem selff, ende Claes Pietersz. van Hoorn, geprocureert bij wijlen Juffr. Souffia de Lange, tsamen indien qualite mede-erffgenamen ab intestato van wijlen de voors. Elisabeth Reael, als moeder ende schoonmoeder restpective. In kennisse van my Frans Wtenbogaert not. publ. ende den getuijgen naergenoemt. Postscript (fol. 12vo): Aldus gedaen binnen Amsterdam ter presentie van de heer Reynier Reael out schepen deser stede ende de heer Bartholomeus Reael secretaris alhier als getuijgen hierover gestaen den 24e may 1644.

Additional Names: goods transferred in precario  to Jeronimus Rans as security for debt
Purpose: goods ceded in precario as security for debt
Biographical Notes: The owner of the goods, Cornelis Dircksz., tobacco dealer, who ceded these goods to Jeronimus Rans(t) in precario, has not been identified. Jeronimus (or Hieronimus) Rans was baptized in the Z.K. on 21 December 1607 and buried on 21 December 1660. He was the son of Lenaert Rans (1576-1619) and of Constantia Coymans (1582-1652), the daughter of Jeronimus Coeymans,  cited in the NOTES to R 31375 of Montias2.  He was a dealer in East Indies goods. He lived on the Oude Schans in de twee Tygers and had himself a house built by Philips Vinckboons in the Purmer, not far from Edam. He was Lieutenant of the Militia in 1658 and a regent of the Rasp- en Tuchthuys in 1657.  He married Barbara Carel (1611-1678), daughter of Jan Jansz. Carel de jonge  and of Anna Jans ten Grootenhuys on 1 October 1630 (Elias, Vroedschap van Amsterdam, p.542).  Jeronimus Rans(t) was a prominent figure, as was (his brother?) Pieter Rans, in the extraction of peat in the Beemster in the period 1616-1618 (Jaarboek Amstelodamum 39(1942), p.13). Jeronimus Rans was named guardian by the Orphan Chamber over the children of Gommer Spranger of INVNO 305 on 25 November 1640 (WK 5073/789; for details, see the NOTES to R 31375). On 14 August 1648, together with his wife Jacoba,  he assisted his niece Jacoba Rans when she signed a pre-nuptial contract with Gillis Valckenier (for details see the NOTES to R 20402 of Montias2).   In 1657, he was cited as the guardian of the children of Floris Soop of INVNO 315.
Intro Text: Op huyden den 16en martis 1650 d'eersame Gerrit Dircksz. burger ende tabackvercoper ... bekende schuldich te wesen aen den eersame Jeronimus Rans 4,000 f. ter saeck van verschieten ende verstreckte penningen by hem comparant ... genoten ... soo heeft de comparant  aen hem [Rans] gecedeert, getransporteert ... alle syne imboel ... van zyde, tinnen ende wollen, coper, tin, item houtwerck, ringen, cleynoden ende juwelen, oock syn imboel ende huysraet noch eertijt lanck onder hem te laten ... naer precario. Volcht de specificatie van de getransporterde ende vercochte goederen. Note that the tobacco ceded to Jeronimus Rans was evaluated at 300 f. and the tobacco equipment at 500 f.]

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at request of his creditors
Biographical Notes: On 29 November 1659, Anthony Waterman (signs Watterman), from the Grafschap of Lip, sugar refiner, 29, no living parents, assisted by Joachim Engels, living on the Conincxgracht, was betrothed to Engeltje Gerards, 18, assisted by her mother Aeltje Gerrits (DTB 480/300)
Intro Text: Inventaris van de goederen, meubelen ende huysraden bevonden in den boedel van Anthonij Waterman suijckerbacker. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert ende beschreven den 6e april 1662. On 8 april 1662, Wynant Robyns declared himself guarantor or surety for Anthonij Waterman.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at the request of creditors
Biographical Notes: On the inventory of the goods owned by Maritie Teunis, the late wife of Hendrick Hendricksz. Gramsbergen, dated 23 September 1645, see INVNO 326. The biographical information on Gramsbergen and his wife is recorded in the TEXT of R 244.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de goederen bevonden in den boedel van Hendrick Gramsbergen in de Roosestraet. Postscript: Aldus geinventariert ende beschreven den 26e junij 1662.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at the request of his creditors
Biographical Notes: Gysbert Cornelissen Schouten, who was undoubtedly related to the wealthy burgomaster of Weesp, Lambert Cornelisz. Schouten (see the NOTES to R 7613), has not been identified.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meubelen ende huijsraet bevonden in den boedel van Gysbert Cornelissen Schouten. Postscript: Aldus gedaen ende geinventariseert den 16e april 1663. Some goods were added on 17 April 1663.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at the request of his creditors.
Biographical Notes: On 11 November 1637, Jacques de Lambre, 63, silk dyer, testified at the request of Jan de la Court (of R 23699 of Montias2) concerning a purchase of 600 wonde sonden (?) that he had made from the requirant. He signed par moi Jacques de Lambre (NA 952, Not. B. Baddel). This individual, Jacques de Lambre I, is likely to be the father of the faillit individual in the present inventory.  The inventory contained a book with the History of Annibal in French.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de goederen bevonden in den boedel van Jacques de Lombre wijncooper. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert ende beschreven den 19en april 1663.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent indidual drawn up at request of his creditors
Biographical Notes: On Anthony de Bordes who was surety for Godefridus de Leeuw, see the NOTES to R 8367 of Montias2.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de goederen, meubelen ende huysraet bevonden in den boedel van Godefridus de Leeuw. Postscript: Aldus getauxeert ende gepriseert by Susanneken Anthonis ende Commeryntje Cornelis, gesworen taxeertsters, opten 21 april 1664 ende schilderyen by Loduwyck van Ludick ende Gerrit Uylenburgh opten 24 daeraen volgende, monterende ter somme van 1709 gulden 15 stuivers. Actum utsupra. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert ende beschreven den 2 october 1663. Second postscript: Op huijden den 5en october 1663, hebben Anthony de Bordes, Johannes Walterus ende David Boerse (signs Boursse) hen tesamen ... gestelt cautionarissen ende borgen.
column25: Loduwijck van Ludick and Gerrit Uylenburgh (Susanneken Anthonis and Commeryntje Cornelis for items other than art)

Residence: Op de Nieuwzyts Achterburchwal achter Arent Bouwers spijcker in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Op den 16 april 1626 zyn vercocht  de naergelaten goederen van Anne Jacobs

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at request of his creditors
Biographical Notes: On 4 February 1662, Joachim Nicolaes Tonnebinder, from Berlin, merchant, 35, living on the Fluwele Burgwal, was betrothed to Constantia Slighers, assisted by her uncle Gerart Sligher, living on the Swanenburghs Burghwal. The banns were said to have been announced in the Waalse Kerck without hindrance (DTB 482/478). Gerard Sligher was probably related to Anthony Sligher of R 20039, but the exact relation has not been ascertained.  On Hans Goverts, who was surety (cautionaris) for Joachem and Niclaes Tonnebinder, see R 1066 of Montias1 and R 7602 of Montias2. Joachim Nicolaes Tonnebinder was apparently a spices merchant (the inventory contained various merchandise, including raisins, prunes, sugar, and pepper).
Intro Text: Inventaris van de goederen ... van Joachim Niclaes Tonnebinder. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert ende beschreven den 22 september 1663. Second postscript:  Op huijden 5 October 16... hebben Hans Goverts ende Steven Dupon (signs Dupont)  cooplieden tsamen ende elcx in solidum gestelt cautionarissen.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at request of his creditors
Residence: In house of Adriaen Willemsz. in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 5 September 1641, Andries Laurenss Paus, from Amsterdam, 26, painter, no living parents, was betrothed to Fijtje Jans, from Delft, widow of Anthonij van Bronckhorst, assisted by her niece Margret Everdyck (DTB 456/244). On 11 December 1644, Andries Laurens Paus and Fijtgen Jans Verhooch had their daughter Cattrijn baptized in the O.K. in the presence of Hendrick Verhooch and Teuntje Reyniers (DTB 8/35). On 25 February 1646, Andries Paus and Fijtjen Jans had their daughter Jannetgen baptized in the O.K. in the presence of Heindrick Verhoeff (Verhooch?) (DTB 8/82). On 7 November 1649, Andries Laurensz. Paus and Sofje Verhooch had their daughter Jannetje in the O.K. in  the presence of Eelsie Joris and Hendrick Dircx Verhooch (DTB 8/240).
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meubelties en weijnich huijsraet concernende de boedel van Adriaen Paus, bevonden ten huijse van Adriaen Willemsz., aldaer den selven Paus gewoont heeft. Poscript: Aldus gedaen ende geinventariseert den 29en october 1665.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at request of his creditors
Biographical Notes: Joost Glimmer, cited in the INTRO, who stood surety for Godefried de Leeuw, was a Mennonite. Jan Joost Glimmer may have been his father. On 24 September 1635, Jan Joost Glimmer, 50, and Thomas Cornelisz. Out, 30, testified to the good character of an individual living in Haarlem (NA 412A, Not. Nic. and Jacob Jacobsz.)
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meubelen ende huijsraet bevonden in de boedel van Godefriedt Dircks. Postscript: Aldus gedaen en geinventariseert den 29e october 1663. Second postscript: Op huijden den 29e october 1663 hebben Joost Glimmer ende Pieter de Lange hen tesaemen en elcx in solidum bij desen gestelt cautionarissen. Third postscript: Op huijden den 24en novembris 1663  sijn door Susanneken Antonis ende Commertie Cornelis   gesworen schatsers de voorenstaende meubelen ende huijsraet getauxeert.  Fourth postscript: Commissarissen gehoort het versoeck by mr. Lerinus Cats als procuratie hebbende van de heeren Thomas Montanus ende Goswijn Montanus schepen en out schepen resp. tot Enckhuysen als mede gesien de tauxatie van de meubelen ... de taxatie monterende f. 819: 7:-- ... daervoor de voorn. mr. Lerinus Cats de selve meubelen was aennemende. Actum 27e october 1663.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at the request of his creditors
Biographical Notes: At least three men with the name of Cornelis Rengers (Rengersz., Rengerss) are known, all three with a connection with the garment or cloth trade. On 18 April 1609, Cornelis Rengers, hat retail merchant (hoedecramer), 29, living in the Warmoesstraet, assisted by his uncle Hans Vorsten, was betrothed to Gijsbertje Gijsbers, from Dordrecht, living in the Huydevetterstraet, assisted by her mother Pleuntgen Bastiaens (DTB 414/34). He was the father of the following. On 13 August 1638, Cornelis Rengerss, cloth merchant, 26, from Amsterdam, assisted by his father Cornelis Rengersz. de oude, living on the corner of the Oudebruchsteech, was betrothed to Geertruyt Jans, from Amsterdam assisted by Matheus Evertsz. her former guardian, living on the Nieuwe Dijck (DTB 449/257). The most probable owner of the goods in this bankrupt inventory was the following. On 27 April 1656, Cornelis Rengerss, from Amsterdam, cloth merchant, 28, assisted by his mother Hester Bosijns, living in the Gravenstraet, was betrothed to Dorothea Wouters, from Amsterdam, 27, assisted by her mother Cornelia Jacobs, living on the Heeregracht (DTB 476/22). Hester Bosijns was probably the daughter of Abraham Bosijn (of R 38605) and of Hester Cleuteringh.  The name Sara given to a daughter of Cornelis Rengerss and Dorothea Wouters also  supports the hypothesis that Hester Bosijns was the daughter of Abraham Bosijn, whose mother was named Sara Keyser. Sara Bosijns, cited below, was probably Abraham Bosijn's sister. On 20 March 1657, Cornelis Ozeas Rengerss and Dorothe Wouters had their son Oseas baptized in the N.K.  in the presence of Hester Bosijns. On 17 September 1658, Cornelis Rengersz. and Dorothea Wouters had their daughter Sara baptized in the presence of Gerrit Cornelisz. and Sara Bosijns (DTB 43/392). On 16 November 1646, Cornelis Rengers, cloth merchant, who is likely to be identical with the faillit owner of the goods in the present inventory,  lodged an insinuation against Willem Sicx (of R 25271 of Montias2), claiming that some French cloth that he had given him to dye had come back damaged (see the NOTES to R 25271). On 11 September 1650, Cornelis Rengers witnessed the baptism of Jacob, son of Jacob Aertsz. Colom (of R 33555) and Sara Rengers (who may have been Cornelis's sister) (DTB 8/285).
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meubelen ende huijsraet mitsgaders comenschappen bevonden in de boedel van Cornelis Rengers. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert ende beschreven den 26 February 1664 ende getauxeert den 10 Marty daeraenvolgende door Susanneken Anthonis end Weijntje Willems. (The glass, belonging to Rengers's stock-in-trade was evaluated by Corstiane Struijs, glass mercant).

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at request of his creditors under the supervision of the DBK
Biographical Notes: On 15 February 1663, Johannes Rigo, from Rotterdam, bookkeeper, 22, assisted by his father Jeronimus Rigo, living in the St. Jorisstraet, was betrothed to Pieternella Rochus Vasthoff, from Amsterdam, 22, assisted by her stepmother Margrieten Meerhuijsen, living in the Kalverstraet (DTB 685/257). On 18 June 1670, Joannis Rigo and Petronella Rochus Vasthoff had their son Jacobus baptized in the R.C. church 't Boomtje in the presence of the godmother Jeanne des Bossu (DTB 316/126).
Intro Text: Inventaris vant weijninge bevonden in den boedel van Johannes Rigo. Postscript: Aldus gedaen den 18e martij 1664.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at the request of his creditors
Biographical Notes: On 18 March 1654, Carel Frick, from Copenhague, merchant, 28, his father Mauris Frick living in Copenhague, was betrothed to Sara Runtvlijsch (signs Runtvles), 24, no living parents, assisted by her niece Clara Runtvlijsch (DTB 682/115).
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meubelen ende huijsraet bevonden in den boedel van Carel Frick.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at request of his creditors
Biographical Notes: Jan Abelis, cited in the INTRO, is identical with Jan Abeels, son of Jonas Abeels (cited in the INTRO and in  the TEXT of R 79 of Montias1), who was   married to Anna de Bra. She was the sister of Isaack de Bra. On 15 January 1649, Jan Abeels, 30, assisted by his father Jonas Abeels, living on the Keysersgracht, was betrothed to Anna de Bra, from Neurenburgh, assisted by her father Abraham de Bra, living on the Conincxgracht (DTB 466/321). There is some likelihood that Isaack de Bra was a bachelor at the time his bankrupt inventory was taken.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meubelen ende huysraedt bevonden in den boedel van Jsaak (Isaak) de Braa. Postscript: Inventaris niet voltrocken ... [huijsvrouw van] Jan Abelis suster van Ysaaq de Braa. Second postscript: Commissarissen Jan Blom ende Gerrit Uijlenburgh ...  omme te taxeren ende priseren de schilderyen concernende den boedel van Ysaack de Braa. Actum den 9 september 1665. Third postscript: Aldus getauxeert ... den  25en september 1665. Signed: Jan Blom, Gerard Uylenburgh, and Laegerstort.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at request of his creditors
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meubelen ende huijsraet bevonden in den boedel van Simon Francisco Bernal. Postscipt: Aldus gedaen ende geinventariseert den 19 augustij 1665. Second postscript: Manasse de Heera and David Arerij declared themselves sureties (borgen) on the same day.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at request of his creditors
Biographical Notes: In 1660, Gerbrant Warnaers, who is probably identical with the owner of this insolvent inventory, was listed among the horse lovers belonging to an elite manege in Amsterdam (Jaarboek Amstelodamum 65(1960), p. 75). On 24 October 1664, Otto Coornhardt, merchant, 28, assisted by his mother Grietie Grols, living on the Heregracht, was betrothed to Margerite Branthouts, from Amsterdam, 19, assisted by her father Garbrant Warnartsz. Branthoud, living on the Voorburgwal (DTB 486/158). On 30 March 1666, Otto Coornhardt and Margrita Branthout had their son Pieter baptized in the N.K. in the presence of Gerbrant Warnaersz. and Grietge Grolle (DTB 44/134).  The betrothal of Pieter Volckertsz. Coornhart and Grietie Grols (Otto's parents) took place on 3 June 1632 (DTB 439/103). Pieter Volckertsz. Coornhart was the son of Volckert Dircx Coornhardt of R 7628.
Intro Text: Inventaris an de meubelen ende huijsraet bevonden in de boedel van Geerebrandt Warnaerts Branthout maeckelaer. Postscript: Aldus gedaen ende geinventariseert den 5en octobris 1665. Second postscript: Op huyden heeft Otto Coornhardt ... cautionaris ende borg.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at the request of his creditors.
Biographical Notes: On 3 July 1651, Dirck Steenover, accompanied by his mother Annetje Claes and his brother Jan Steenoven, his brother-in-law Frederick Stam (cited in the NOTES to R 24437), and Govert Lems, his acquaintance,  signed a pre-nuptial contract with Margariet Verwers, assisted by her uncle Ghysbert Vlamingh van Oudshoorn (NA 988, act 63, Not. J. Bosch). Gijsbert de Vlaming van Oudtshoorn, the son of Volckert de Vlaming and of Maritge Braems (daughter of Pieter Braems, wine dealer of R 31430 of Montias2),  was buried on 4 September 1652. He was captain of an infantry company of 200 men in 1651. His sister Maria de Vlaming van Oudtshoorn married Hendrick Claesz. Verwer (the father of Claes Hendricksz. Verwer of R 7667 of Montias2) on 17 July 1633. Margariet Verwers was presumably the daughter of Hendrick Claesz. Gijsbert's brother Arnold de Vlaming van Oudshoorn, married Maria Ruttens (of INVNO 492)  in Batavia in 1641. She was the daughter of Hans Ruttens and Clara Pieters Elekaert of INVNO 121 (Elias, Vroedschap van Amsterdam, p. 229). The Bordeaux wine in the cellar seems to part of the coopmanschappen in the inventory. It suggests that Steenoven was a wine merchant.
Intro Text: Inventaris mitsgaders coopmanschappen in den boedel van Dirck Steenoven. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert den 17en january 1666.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at the request of his creditors
Residence: Op het Nieuwe Eylant aende Buytencant in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: The bankrupt owner of the goods in the present inventory has not been identified. He may have been a cloth merchant, as was Jacob Elant who guaranteed the integrity of the inventory (as borg).
Intro Text: Inventaris van de goederen bevonden in den boedel van Jacob de Block op het Nieuwe Eylant aende Buytencant. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert den 29e marty 1669. Second postscript: Op huijden den 25e april 1669 heeft Jacob Elant laeckencooper hem verobligeert ende verbonden ... [borg]

Residence: Op de Princegraft in de Nieuwe Vergrotinge Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 5 May 1661, Cornelis Kick, from Amsterdam, 27, assisted by his mother Stijntje Cornelis Duyster, widow of Simon Kick, living in the Koninghstraet, was betrothed to Cornelia Spaeroogh, from Amsterdam, 24, assisted by her father Harmen Claesz. Spaeroogh (of INVNO 131), living in the Nes. Stijntje (Christina) Cornelis Duyster was the sister of the painter Willem Duyster. The painter Simon Kick (1603-1652) married Christina Duyster in 1631. On 10 June 1662, Cornelis Kick and Cornelia Spaeroogh, living in the Koninghstraet, drew up their testament (Not. J. de Winter, cited in Bredius Künstler-inventare, p. 790). On 27 August 1665, the honorable Johan van den Broeck, as father and guardian of his son Elias van den Broeck, signed a contract with Cornelis Kick whereby his son Elias van den Broeck was apprenticed for four years to learn the art of painting with Kick. The father promised to pay Kick 140 f. in learning money per year and an extra 100 f. at the end of four years (these were unusually high amounts) (Bredius, op.cit., p. 791). Johannes van den Broeck, baptized on 20 December 1593, was Commissaris van 't Klein Zegel in The Hague in 1624 and thereafter Commis ter Financie, and Knight of St. Michel. He married Machelina Rotgans, daughter of Jacob Lucasz. Rotgans of INVNO 463, on 17 December 1624 (Elias, Vroedschap van Amstedam, p. 171).  On 27 September 1671, Cornelis Kick (not Eyck as in the GAA's DTB files) and Cornelia Spaeroogh had their twin sons Johannes and Balthasar baptized in the Amstelkerck in the presence of Jacob van Ruysdael (the painter) and Annitie Bressaert. Christina Cornelis Duyster, widow of Symon Kick, in her testament  dated 30 May 1673, left her daughters Annetge, Hendrickge and Grietge most of her movable goods, a total of 1500 f. in cash, seeing that her son Cornelis had already received 500 f. at the time of his marrage. She also left her son Cornelis a portrait of her late sister Barber Cornelis Duyster painted her son or in place of that, at his choice, a picture of a kraembewaerstetie (a laying-in woman), made by the testatrix's late husband (Simon Kick) (Bredius, op.cit. p. 794). A painting of this subject, which was only evaluated at 4 gulden, was recorded in the present inventory (LOT 0004).   On 21 December 1674, Cornelis Kick, widower of Cornelia Spaeroogh, living in the Utrechtsestraet in Amsterdam, was married to Machteltje Dircks de Rechte from Leiden (Bredius, op.cit. p. 792). On 21 May 1675, Cornelia Kick and Machteltje Dircks transferred to Johannes Spaerooogh, Kick's brother-in-law (Cornelia's brother), all their movable goods, clothing etc. as collateral for a debt of 4,000 f. for which Johannes and his father (Harmen Spaeroogh) had constituted themselves sureties (ibid.) Machteltje in de Rechten was buried on 1 December 1679. On 18 June 1681, after the death of Cornelis Kick, his brothers-in-law declared that they they would be responsible for his burying costs but not for his debts (ibid.) On 25 February 1695, Willem Cornelisz. Kick, son of the late Cornelis Kick, declared that 156 f. was left from his share in the inheritance from his grandfather Herman Spaeroogh as well as from his brothers Simon (II) and Harman Kick (Bredius, op. cit. p.793).
Intro Text: Inventaris van alle de goederen by wijlen Cornelis Kick in zijn leven schilder binnen deser stadt Amsterdam op dn 18 Juny anno 1681 overleden metter doot ontruijmt ende achtergelaten.... getaxeerd door Catharina Schaack, gesworen schatser. Cornelis Kick left four children of minor age: Maria, Symon, Harmanus, and Willem.  The estate comprised 72 f. in cash; it owed 300 f. in debts, including one to the painter Johan van Kessel for 12 f. in money loans and 287 f. in burial costs.

Biographical Notes: Hans van Uffelen II was the son of Hans van Uffelen I, the son of the very rich  Hamburg merchant Dominicus van Uffelen. Hans I migrated to Amsterdam from Hamburg in 1584. He was the brother of Jacomo (Jacques)  as well as of Marcus, Daniel, and Dominicus (II) van Uffelen. He was married to Agnieta van Liefvelt, sister of Anna van Liefvelt, the wife of Jeronimius Petiteau, the father of Guillaume Petiteau of INVNO 928. He paid a tax of 25 f. in 1585, a very high amount for that period.  He became a citizen of Amsterdam in 1591. He died between 1603 and 1605 (Gelderbloom, Prosopographic Data Base). Hans van Uffelen II was born about 1576. He spent some time in Seville and Malaga before settling in Amsterdam where he was first noted in 1601 (Gelderbloom, ibid.) He wrote an account of a trip to Brazil dated 1598, which actually took place in tha year (Wijnroks, Handel tussen Rusland en de Nederlanden 1540-1640, p. 260). The manuscript account was found in the present  inventory.  Hans van Uffelen II bought 8 lots of drawings, two tronien and one lot of paint (smalt)  in the WK auction of Gillis van Conincxloo in 1607 (R 30510 of Montias2 etc..) He drew up his testament on 10 February 1613, two days before his death.   He died as a bachelor on 12 February 1613 in the house of his brother-in-law Hendrick Broen (of R 7618 of Montias2). Hendrick Broen was married to Hans II's sister Anna van Uffelen. For further details on Hans van Uffelen I and II, see the NOTES to R 30510 of Montias2. Hans van Uffelen III, whose relation to Hans van Uffelen I and II has not been ascertained, was brewer in the Rode Ancker according to an act of 9 July 1632, on which date Matheus Capoen, 46, declared at the request of Jan Claesz., biscuit baker, that 3,600 pounds of ship's bread had been delivered to Hans van Uffelen (III) (NA 943, Not. Arent Engel).
Intro Text: Inventaris ... ten versoeck van Lucas van Uffelen ... den 3en julij 1613.

Additional Names: goods pledged to Hendrick Uijlenbroek de jonge
Owner Full Name: Ceulen, Cornelis Jansz. van, de jonge
Biographical Notes: The owner of the goods, which were pledged against a loan of 400 f.  to Hendrick Uijlenbroek de jonge, was Cornelis Jonson van Ceulen, the son of the better known portrait painter Cornelis Jonson van Ceulen I. The son was born after 1622 in London, traveled with his father to Holland in 1643, and was living in Utrecht with his mother in 1664. He married as a widower in Utrecht in 1681 and was still mentioned there as a miniature painter in 1698 (Thieme-Becker, Algemeines Lexicon, vol. 19, p. 144). It is possible but unlikely that the loan provider Hendrick Uijlenbroek de jonge was a son of the well-known dealer  Hendrick Uylenburgh, since no child of the latter with the first name Hendrick has been identified. It should be noted that two of the painters (Franz Kleyn or Cleyn and Jacob de Ryger or Reyger) represented in the inventory lived in England, as did Cornelis Jonson van Ceulen I and II.
Intro Text: Cornelis Jansz. van Ceulen de jonge, schilder,  woonachtig tot Uytregt, tegenwoordigh ter stede, declares that he owes Hendrick Uijlenbroek de jonge 400 f., for which gives the following paintings as collateral.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at the request of his creditors under the supervision of the DBK.
Residence: Op de Nieuwe Heeregracht in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: On 17 April 1664, Johannes Wybrants, from Amsterdam, 25, parents dead(?), assisted by his mother Magdelena Paters, living on the Keysersgracht, was betrothed to Adriana Hinlopen, 17, assisted by the heer Jacob Jacobsz. Hinlopen, former alderman and member of the Vroedschap, her father, and Anna Tholinck, her mother, living on the [...] Burgwal (DTB 485/336). Jacob Jacobsz. Hinlopen, who declared himself surety for Johannes Wybrants on 22 December 1676, was baptized on 18 July 1621 and buried on 19 August 1679. He married Anna Tholincx, baptized on 14 April 1622 and buried on 6 October 1672, on 30 December 1642. Anna Tholincx was the daughter of Diderick Tholincx (of R 27472) and of Adriana van der Wel (Elias, Vroedschap van Amsterdam, p. 507).  On 13 September 1667, Johannes Wybrants and Adriana Hinlopen had their daughter Anna Jacobs baptized in the N.K. in the presence of Hendrick Wybrants and Anna Hinlopen (DTB 44/181).
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meubilen ende huysraet bevonden in den boedel van Joahannes Wybrants, gewoont hebbende op de Nieuwe Heeregracht. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert ende beschreven den 22en december 1672. Op huijden hebb ick Jacob Jacobsen Hinlopen, out schepen ende raedt deser stede ende Jacob Hinlopen schepen der selven stede hen tesamen ende elcx in solidum bij deesen gestelt cautionarisen voor de verantwoordinge ende van de verminderinge van de [...] huijs, silverwerck ende juwelen concernende den boedel van Johannes Wybrants ... actum den 22 december 1676. Op huijden den 25en january 1673, sijn de meubilen en anders .... gepriseert ende getauxeert ... bij Susanneken Anthonis ende Lysbeth Martens, de juwelen bij Hans Sipel, paerden bij Bartholomeus Verburgh, de caros ... bij Baltens Hanck sadelmacker.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at the request of his creditors under the supervision of the DBK.
Biographical Notes: On Otto Broock, see the TEXT of R 48. There are no obvious overlaps between this inventory and INVNO 137 of 13 July 1671.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meubilen ende huysraedt bevonden in den boedel van Otto Broockx, coopman. Postsript: Aldus geinventariseert ende beschreven den 10en october 1675, getauxeert by Susanna Anthonis. Op huijsen den xi octobris 1675 hebben Hendrick van der Does ende Hendrick Dijckman goutsmit hen tesamen ... by desen gestelt cautionarisen.

Additional Names: widow of Jacob Croesen
Biographical Notes: The only one individual identified of those mentioned in the INTRO is perhaps  Christoffel Croesen, who appears to have been a son of Jacob Croesen and Aletta van Delft. He was married to Judith de Marte. An individual of that name was a member of the wine dealers' confrerie and was said to be 40 on 1 June 1630 (see the deposition in the NOTES to R 23614). However, if he was born in 1590, he is unlikely to have had children of minor age in 1678. He was perhaps the son of the wine dealer.
Intro Text: Inventaris van alle de goederen, middelen en effecten, mitsgaders uyt en inschulden, soo ende sulcx dese metter doot ontruijmt en achtergelaten syn van Aletta van Delft, weduwe van Jacob Croesen ... en door 't aengeven van Sr. Barent Abbingh, getrout met Gertruyd Croesen, Celia Croesen, weduwe van Roeloff Thesingh, Judith de Marte als moeder ende voogdesse van haer minderjarige kinderen geprocreert by Christoffel Croesen, Theodor Croesen als procuratie hebbende van Johannes Croesen ende daer beneffens by de heere schepenen deser stede geauthoriseert om het recht waertenemen van Pieter Croesen, mitsgaders Lodewijck Bruijn, als testamentaire voocht over Catharina ende Elisabeth Croesen, kinderen ende kintskinderen resp. van de voors. Aletta van Delt, ende syn de goederen als volcht. Postscript: Aldus getauxeert ende gepriseert door Jan Rosa end Jan Bloom (Provoost) als bij de heeren schepenen daertoe genomineert volgens appointement ... op de requeste by de voorn. Dr. Bruijn in qualite [...] op den 3en november 1678 ... Actum in Amsterdam den viffden november 1678

Additional Names: widow of Pieter van Alteren, wife of Jan [...]
Biographical Notes: On 23 January 1652, Pieter van Alteren, from Middelburgh, fiscal of the Lords of the Admiralty, assisted by his father Sym van Alteren, was betrothed to Anna Boom, from Amsterdam, 21 years old,  assisted by her uncle Salomon van Schoonhoven, reeve of Armveen, and her nichte Sara Roch (DTB 469/427). Because the original document has been burned, it is not clear whether Anna Boom remarried after the death of her first husband Pieter van Alteren and with whom. No such second husband is mentioned by Elias (Vroedschap van Amsterdam, p. 433). According to Elias, Anna Boom. baptized in Amsterdam on 29 December 1630, was the daughter of Dr. Cornelis Boom and of Maria van Schoonhoven. He was counsellor and Advocaat-Fiscal of the Admiralty and reeve of the Beemster in 1667, the year of his death. As a widow, Anna Boom was taxed on the basis of wealth estimated f. 283,000. The marriage produced four children, including Catharina van Alteren who married Jacob Sas van den Bosch, also a counsellor of the Admiralty,  cited in the INTRO. Daniel van Geel's wife (N.N.) was the sister of Anna Boom (ibid.) After the death of her husband, in 1669,  Anna Boom bought a house on the Keysersgracht from Dr. Francois de Vicq for f. 10,000. She and her brother-in-law Daniel van Geel submitted plans for the house to the city (Jaarboek Amstelodamum 7(1909), p. 77).
Intro Text: Inventaris van alle de goederen roerende ende onroerende ... actien, crediten ... metter doot ontruijmt by vrouw Anna Boom, vrouw van Jan [illegible, due to burning of paper], gemaeckt by my Cornelis van Polenburgh deurwaerder van den Hogen Rade uyt cracht van seckere open brieven van benefitie van inventaris in dato den 30e september 1678 van den selven Hoge Rade geimpetreert ... wegen de E.E. heeren Jacob Sas van den Bosch gecommitteert raed tot admiraliteyt int Hoonder Quartier, als in houwelyck hebbende Catharina van Altena, item Daniel van Geel, heer van Sparbroeck, Cornelis Roch radt en oud schepen, als by testament van wylen Anna Boom versoght ende gestelt tot vooghden over de selfs minderjarige kinderen, sijnde de meublen ... mitsgaders gout ender silver getaxeert door Susanneken Anthonis ende Grietje Arents, gesworen schatsers. Schilderyen ten sterfhuijs bevonden getaxeert door Srs. Barent Graat ende [left blank] Backer, als by de heeren schepenen deser stede daertoe gecommitteert ten prijse als volcht. No postscript. Dated just before 14 March 1679.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at the request of his creditors under the supervision of the DBK.
Residence: In the Warmoesstraet in Oudt Hamburgh in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Isaacq de Hiese was a merchant selling imported English serge cloth.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meubilen ende huysraedt mitsgaders coopmanschappen bevonden in den boedel van Isaack de Hiese wonende in de Warmoesstraet in Oudt Hamburg. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert ende beschreven den 2 ende 4 may 1671.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at the reques of his creditors under the supervision of the DBK.
Residence: Op 't achterburchwal in den Os in Amsterdam
Biographical Notes: Neither Gaver nor his surety Zacharias Maurits has been identified.
Intro Text: Inventoris van de meubelen in den boedel van Domicus de Gaver wonende op 't achterburchwal in den Os. Postsript: Aldus geinventariseert ende beschreven den 16 juny 1671. Op huijden 26 juni 1671 Sacharias Maurits syde reeder hem gestelt cautionaris ....

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at the request of his creditors under the supervision of the DBK.
Biographical Notes: On 19 October 1674, Hendrick Kip, apothecary, 30, living on the Reguliers Breestraet, assisted by his neef Jacob Harlan, was betrothed to Johanna Vuijst, 30, her parents dead, living on the Raamgraft, assisted by her uncle Pieter van der Cruijs (DTB 501/63). Hendrick Kip was buried on 5 July 1692 (DTB 1075/2vo). Johannes, Abraham, and Hendrick van der Voorde declared themselves sureties for Abraham Kip.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meublen ende huysraet bevonden in den boedel van Hendrick Kip. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert den 22e ende 23e octobris 1671. Op huijden 29en octobris Johannes, Abraham ende Hendrick van de Voorde hen tesamen ... gestelt cautionarissen.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at the request of his creditors under the supervision of the DBK.
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meubilen ende huysraedt als anders concernende den boedel van Caspar Craij berustende ten huyse van Cornelis van Polenburgh als curateur van den boedel van de voors. Craij. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert ende beschreven den 10en decembris 1673.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at the request of his creditors under the supervision of the DBK
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meubilen, huysraedt ende anders bevonden in den boedel van Adam Modens brouwer int Amsterdams waepen. NB dat Adam Modens ende de selffs boedel naederhandt van de caemer syn uytslagen(?) volgens acte staende tot 22e register. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert ende beschreven den 3 junij 1674.

Additional Names: goods owned in common with his wife Fytge Cornelis
Residence: Op de O.Z. Voorburgwal by de Sleutels Brugge in Amsterdam
Intro Text: Staet en inventaris gemaeckt van de goederen, uytschulden achtergelaten ende mettet doot ontruymt by Mr. Johannis Carius van Bont ende by hem int gemeen beseten met Fytge Cornelis syn huysvrouw ende syn nagelate weduwe bevonden tsynen huys op O.Z. Voorburgwas by de Sleutels Brugge alwaer de selve Mr. Johannes Carius overleden is. Postscript: Aldus geinventariseert ende beschreven door my ondersch. notaris ten versoecke ende door ordre van de eerbare Fytge Cornelis, weduw wylen Mr. Johan Carius van Bont mitsgaders Pieter Melchiorsz. Veris ende Mr. Johan Garlick chirurgijn als by testamente gestelde voogden over de dry nagelate kinderen van wylen Martyntje van Bont die voors. Johan Carius dochter was, in Amsterdam den 30 marty ende 26 july des jaers 1656. The house of Johannes Carius was sold for f. 6,000 with the consent of the masters of the Orphan Chamber. The movable goods were sold at auction by the afslager and brought, after deduction of the auctioneer's salary, f. 1806: 8:--. In addition, silver possessed by the widow brought f. 113:14:--, or a total of f. 1920: 2:-- Among the debts due by the estate, Johannes Jacob is owed f 2:10:-- for couranten. The widow's share of the estate was f. 519:14:14. The children's share was the same amount.

Purpose: Inventory of insolvent individual drawn up at the request of his creditors under the supervision of the DBK.
Biographical Notes: On 1 February 1669, Victor Engelbricht [signs van den Lippe], merchant, 32, parents dead, living on the Calverstraert, was betrothed to Maria Boschreder, 18, from Amsterdam, assisted by her guardian Jan Carpenje Bruyn, living on the Voorburgwal (DTB 687/304).
Intro Text: Inventaris van de meubilen, huijsraedt ende coopmanschappen bevonden in den boedel van Fictor Engelbrecht van den Lippe, gewoont hebbende op de Waeter.
